PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TITLE.XREF: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 23 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 and an amendment moved by Senator Margetts to insert a new item to schedule 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —When we left the debate at the end of the last sitting week Senator Margetts had moved her amendment. The government indicates that it will be opposed to this and other amendments. We believe that the amendments go to a significant policy issue and are well outside the technical nature of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly, the amendments would have the effect of encouraging employees to engage in industrial action involving bans and limitations knowing that they could pressure their employers to paying them, irrespective of the effects of the action on their employers' businesses.

These amendments would allow employees to be paid even if they impose bans on critical elements of their work and their employers' businesses, simply because particular tasks in relation to which bans have been imposed happen to involve little actual working time. This is precisely the type of damaging conduct that the government's legislation is designed to discourage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no compulsion in the relation to industrial relations in the sense that, if a person conducts some form of industrial action, their employer cannot take some sort of the action in relation to their pay. All this section does is remove the compulsion to dock pay from employers. We know that Senator Murray's proposed amendment goes part of way towards that, because he specifically mentions those elements of industrial action where the employer accepts or even approves of the action and some of it can go to workers' health and safety and other issues.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in hospitals, schools, universities or areas where there is a great deal of dedication there is a desire not to push for industrial strike action or work to rule. Those dedicated people who serve the community would prefer to make their point in a way that is not overly harmful to their jobs. These amendments will enable them to make their point and put some pressure for negotiation and arbitration into place. That is a very useful thing more many people to do.

The government would prefer there to be full industrial action. We are trying to indicate that it should not be compulsory for employers to dock the pay of people who work to rule. It is still open, of course, for employers to do that. There is nothing that indicates that it will be illegal for them to issue warnings or something of that nature. There is nothing that I can see that would make it illegal for there to be pay deductions, if work to rule were to be a problem for them. However, all it says is that it is not compulsory for employers to exempt that level of compulsion from employees for something that might be as simple as work to rule.

With teachers it could be something as simple as them saying that they will refuse over a certain period to take excursions. Teachers may say that they will work to rule in non‐contact hours or non‐school hours and not take the kids away, but they might not actually be doing anything in their paid work time that is a problem. They might be doing everything in their full day, but when it comes to the normal expectation for teachers to do things in their own time, they may say, `You are not listening to us, so for this period of time we are not going to put in that extra effort in our own time.' That may well be considered to be work to rule.

However, why should someone have to dock someone's pay in those circumstances? It does not make sense. I believe it will mean that there will be more industrial action rather than less. It is a thoroughly sensible approach to say that work to rule should not be all lumped in to any kind of industrial action. There may be limited industrial actions for workers' health and safety. We know that the government has peeled back a lot of the protections for workers' health and safety and this might be one of them.

This specific work to rule provision may be one way—or it might be the only way—a workplace has of bringing home those points. We have proven in the 1996 legislation that there are limitations on the other kinds of industrial action that can be taken in relation to unsafe working conditions. The government has not allowed them into the allowable matters in awards and, if a person refuses to work in a specific job, only the person in that specific area is allowed to refuse to work in that specific job. There might be other ways in which workers can actually save their own lives, for instance, by giving a very subtle or not so subtle message in some form of work to rule campaign. It is only fair to simply remove the compulsion of an employer to dock pay under these circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Margetts is right. It is an extraordinary business when two people who are negotiating over the table cannot agree on what people will be paid or whether they will be remunerated in particular circumstances. If the workplace reform is based upon the idea of contract, equal parties negotiating, we on this side of the chamber say that they are not equal parties, and that therefore there should be—as there is under the Trade Practices Act, for example, where people are at a disadvantage—a means of evening up. But where the basis of the Workplace Relations Act is that parties should be able to agree about what happens, to be prohibited from agreeing in a circumstance where industrial action takes place is terrible and seems to be, as Senator Margetts says, inconsistent with the philosophy behind the Workplace Relations Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition went to the people on the basis that it was going to introduce a new philosophy, a new program, into the workplace where there would be exchanges between the parties, and that the unions and everybody else would be excluded except for those negotiating. Yet the government itself intervenes in one of the crucial areas where one would have thought the issue of privity contract might operate, where people might want to agree to pay in particular circumstances. In a situation where there has been industrial action, where people have been on strike for example, why shouldn't the parties as a means of negotiating a settlement use that privity contract without interference from government?

Senator Parer would understand that this is big government at its worst. It is an awful thing to see a government come in and interfere with private enterprise in the way they are doing here. I must confess that it comes as a bit of a shock to find that Senator Campbell, Senator Parer and Senator Calvert should be party to this interference by big government in the marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot add to what has been already indicated so eloquently by Senator Cooney. I endorse the comments of Senator Margetts. We will be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the government regards the loss of that question as an important one. It does cut across the legislative package. As I stated in my intervention, the amendment falls way outside the technical nature of this amending bill, which is seeking to be a tidying up bill. I did not seek to delay the committee's consideration of the bill by spending another five, six or seven minutes in calling for a division. But I ask that the vote of those coalition senators in the chamber be recorded and, most importantly, that it be recorded that we regard this as a serious amendment which the government will have to consider when it goes back to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Schedule 9, page 23 (after line 12), after item 2, insert:
Insert:

EMPHASIS.TAB: 187AE Industrial action not to include certain action

PARA.TAB: For the purpose of this Part, industrial action does not include action by employees that is authorised, agreed to or accepted by the employer of the employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't think there is any problem with content?

—No, I do not. I will speak to the amendment if I may, but if I am persuaded otherwise then we can discuss it afterwards. The proposed section I am referring to is 187AE. The section that Senator Margetts has just attended to was 187AA, so it is a different section. I will be guided by the chair in this matter, but I consider it to be a separate area.
—I am in no position to make a judgment with my limited legal knowledge. You had better put the arguments—unless Senator Margetts has some particular position.

—It was always my intention that my amendment should be moved and, hopefully, passed in conjunction with Senator Murray's amendment. So I see it as no contradiction. We had no advice in the drafting of it that there were any problems, so I am certainly hoping that Senator Murray's amendment will be passed. I think as a pair they will go very nicely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the assistance of senators. I want to return to the remarks of the Parliamentary Secretary. It is not entirely true that Senator Margetts's amendment was anything other than materially technical because there is a question of the intention of the new act as moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly I never intended a situation to arise where, if employers genuinely, individually, personally wished to—not forced to—continue to pay employees when they were taking limited action, they should be prevented or in any way pressured not to do so. The converse is the case. We do strongly support the intention of the act to prevent employees being paid when they are on strike. But this is not about people being on strike; this is about people doing a full day's work, the employer being prepared to accept it and the people being paid for it. That particularly applies, and quite frankly is in the interest of the country, when you are dealing with such areas as essential services. I would always personally encourage nurses, or police officers or those sorts of people to take limited action rather than to strike and withdraw their labour completely, because of the harm that can cause to the community.

So the act does pick up as a strike any performance of work which is different from how it is customarily performed. But the employer under the law is obliged, it seems, not to pay them. We had thought that there was common law protection in that area. When we dealt with the legislation, the government placed great emphasis on the rider to the definition of industrial action in section 4, which says, `An employer is not engaged in industrial action if the employee's action is agreed to by the employer.' You would think `agreed to' would mean acceptance by the employer of the work that was being performed. It is for this reason, Parliamentary Secretary, and I appreciate there is a difference of opinion between you and us, that we regard this as an interpretative matter arising out of the original intention of the act and not a new matter being introduced. That is why I say that, whilst it is material, we still consider it to be technical. If we turn to our amendment, we see that it reads:
For the purpose of this Part, industrial action does not include action by employees that is authorised, agreed to or accepted by the employer of the employees.

You need to have consideration as to what those words mean. `Authorised' has to be in some formal or identifiable manner that which has been authorised, and `agreed to' would have the same meaning. You then have to ask, `Where does "accepted by" take us with this? How does it add to the definition we put there?' We put that in deliberately in case `authorised' or `agreed to' was historically based—in other words, it was contractually based or in some way based on agreements in the past where `accepted' means `accepted at the time'. So if nurses, to give an example, take limited action and that is accepted by the employer, then our view is that the employer should, if they wish to, pay them and should not be obliged by direction from the government not to pay them.

It most affects employers where the relevant department or relevant minister may take a hard line and resist paying people who embark on some kind of limited action, such as work to rule. We have moved the amendment to try to ensure that the definition of industrial action, for the purposes of the act, does not include action which is accepted of their own volition, of their own free will, not in any standover or forced manner, by the employer of the employees. I think Senator Margetts gave a fuller motivation for these kinds of considerations, so I will not indulge the committee's time any further by motivating any more than she has with my additional remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting the amendment.

—The government's view, not surprisingly, is the same on the Democrat amendment as to the previous Green amendment that has got up. I will not hold up the committee much longer, because the arguments are fundamentally the same. We do believe, Senator Murray, that they are in fact material, not materially technical; but I will not get too technical about the definitions of what is material and what is technical. They do make a quite fundamental change in the interpretation and application of that part of the law. We do believe that the government's intent, our pre-election policy, our post-election policy and our continuing policy in relation to the use of work bans and work to rules has been implemented as intended in this legislation and this will materially change it. We do regard it as a serious breach of our policy and, as I said, the government will have to look at the situation when the legislation goes back to the House of Representatives for a vote. The government will be voting against this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a rather bizarre kind of explanation by the parliamentary secretary, first of all indicating that some how or other the Senate has no place to be moving such amendments in a `technical' bill. It is not; it is called the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. If the government is claiming that it is tidying up issues associated with the workplace relations bill, so are we. If the parliamentary secretary recalls, he will know that during the debate in 1996 it was not clearly known by the minister at the time what was meant by the definition of industrial relations for the purpose of the act. We had to go questioning backwards and forwards before we found out that it really was intended, supposedly, by the government to actually lump all kinds of industrial action into this very restrictive section.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the code that Senator Campbell is making to Senator Murray is that this was part of the original agreement. I do clearly recall Senator Murray saying at the time that it was not part of their original understanding of the bill. That is why I am pleased to see the Australian Democrats have changed their position in relation to that. If that had been made clear at the time, if the government had been clear enough perhaps even to the Democrats in their negotiations at that time, it may never have been voted for or been part of any negotiation at the time. But unfortunately it was, so now is the time—it is the first opportunity that we are both using, I guess—to rectify an unfortunate situation regarding something that was at the time a technical clarification which I and many others believe was an abuse of the definition of `industrial action'.

In some ways this is a technical clarification as well going back to perhaps what it should always have been; that is, that you do not get ham‐fisted in relation to penalising people. It does not help in relation to industrial action. The suggestion that somehow or other you called a bill something and nobody else can make their own changes to definitions within the process of debate is bizarre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —If I made that implication, I did not seek to. All I did was have a debate with Senator Murray over what is technical and what is material. I think Senator Margetts agrees this is a material change.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to reflect on how the Senate voted last time or how it is about to vote. I and the government regard this as a material change, Senator Murray regards it as materially technical and Senator Margetts regards it as somewhere in between. We understand each other: you support the change; we do not. I am just saying that the government's understanding was quite clear at the end of last year and it remains clear in 1997.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 28 (after line 11), at the end of Schedule 10, add:
Repeal the paragraph, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (a) the dominant purpose for which the conduct is engaged in is related to environmental protection, consumer protection, protection of human rights or promotion of peace or Aboriginal land rights.

TAB.TAB: Note: The heading to subsection 45DD(3) is replaced by the heading:

PARA.TAB: "Dominant purpose of conduct related to environment protection, consumer protection, protection of human rights or promotion of peace or Aboriginal land rights ".

SPEECH.PARA: Repeal the paragraph.
Repeal the subsections.

I have moved this amendment because I, on behalf of the Australian Greens, have continued to have the concern that the legislation as amended will potentially penalise a whole range of community groups, including unions, in Australia if they undertake secondary boycott action or what appears to be secondary boycott action in the interests of social justice, consumer protection, protection of human rights or the promotion of peace or Aboriginal land rights, for example. These do not come within the ambit of the exclusion clause, which refers to the environment and consumer protection. Last year we had a long and detailed discussion or debate in this chamber about these clauses in the legislation.

My legal advice is that community organisations from the Wilderness Society through to Greenpeace, the maritime unions and social justice groups will be threatened with up to a $750,000 fine if they take part in action which is found by a court to be secondary boycott action when their intent is to promote civil rights, peace and Aboriginal rights, for example.

I gave the prospective example during the committee hearings last time that, were Aboriginal groups or certainly environmental groups or social justice groups joined with Aboriginal groups to blockade a uranium mine—for example, the Jabiluka proposal specifically—they have the threat of this legislation hanging over their head. I would be very pleased indeed if the minister could reassure the committee that that is not the case. It would clear the air.

I became all the more concerned about this legislation after it was passed because 23 days after its enactment on 1 January a seaman aboard a foreign vessel jumped ship in Newcastle and almost lost his life escaping from the deplorable situation aboard that ship. The maritime unions were unable to take the usual course of putting bans on that ship while things were rectified aboard because the threat of legal action under this section was hanging over their head.

The shipping company involved took legal action. I am not sure whether it was specifically under the new provisions of the Workplace Relations Act but that threat was there. Let us remind ourselves that it is not just a threat of community service. It is a $750,000 fine—and it is a $750,000 fine because the intent of this legislation is to put unions and community groups out of business, to bank rupt them, effectively, to make them insolvent. That is a very serious matter for the officers of the community groups or unions to take into account.

There has been conjecture within conservation groups as to whether, for example, a blockade on a woodchip ship or a coal carrying or uranium carrying ship might not invoke the penalty of a three‐quarter of a million dollars fine of a group that was directly involved or that had even given advice about such a blockade. It would help greatly if the minister or Senator Parer were able to stand up in this committee and say, `These concerns are wrong. Under this legislation, community organisations, environment groups, social justice groups and Aboriginal communities will not and cannot be penalised. This $750,000 threat does not apply to them.' That would help clear the air.

It would further help clear the air if the parliamentary secretary was able to say something about the unions with a humanitarian record like the maritime unions, which have effectively brought to dock the ships of shame with deplorable conditions. We have heard about them. This includes torture, rape and depravation of basic human rights, throwing overboard basically imprisonment on ships without pay—not for months but for years—of seamen who happen to find themselves under a flag of convenience on the wrong ship with the wrong captain in the hands of the wrong company.

That has not been allowed in Australia. These ships coming into our waters have had to come good. They have had to improve their standards and repay moneys where seamen have not been paid for years. That is because the union has been able to say, `Until you do the right thing and until you act in a responsible manner, this ship goes no further.'

The legislation as I read it says, `Well, a maritime union group that wants to take such action against such deplorable conditions in Australia'—we are talking about ships in Australian ports—`runs the risk of a three‐quarters of a million dollar fine.' I would like to know that that is not so. Unless I can get a categorical assurance from the government that that is not so, I stick by this amendment, which goes some way to making that assurance. It says that group actions, `the dominant purpose for which the conduct is engaged in is related to environmental protection, consumer protection, protection of human rights or promotion of peace or Aboriginal land rights', are not under such a threat. It is as simple as that.

I do not know what Senator Murray's position on this is, but I hope that, with the passage of time, the Democrats may have reconsidered the awful potential consequences for community groups and unions of this quite draconian section of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to give Senator Brown some assurances which were given in the debate late last year. They were assurances that I gave on behalf of the government. The government does believe that this amendment is not necessary. We will therefore be opposing it. We do not think a specific exemption in section 45DD of the Trade Practices Act to cover protest action relating to human rights, peace and Aboriginal land rights is required because protest action for these purposes is highly unlikely to amount to boycott conduct within the meaning of sections 45D, DA or DB of the Trade Practices Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to clarify it for Senator Brown—I hope this is clarification enough for him to withdraw the amendment—to be caught by section 45D, boycott conduct must involve a person acting in concert with one or more other persons in a way that, firstly, hinders or prevents a third person from supplying goods or services to a fourth person—that is, the target—or, secondly, hinders or prevents a third person from acquiring goods or services from the target fourth person. Further, the action must be taken for the purpose of causing substantial loss or damage to the business of the target and have or likely to have the effect of causing substantial loss or damage to the business of the target. Social protest action is highly unlikely to meet these criteria.

I think the other point that should be made is that the Green amendment would go a lot further than just giving a narrow exemption to those sorts of protests. It would, because of its wording—I suspect, in the dominant purpose part of it—cover industrial action in the form of boycotts for reasons related to environmental or consumer protection or social protests. The government, I repeat, does not believe that such actions should fall within the section 45DD exemption because there is no doubt that industrial action of this type will inevitably harm employers who are clearly the innocent parties in respect of these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, that confirms my fears. If the wording that I have put forward is simply redundant in terms of protecting environment and consumer groups that might take action, no harm is done. But the parliamentary secretary's assertion that it is highly unlikely to amount to such a thing gives me no assurance at all. It means that there is a risk involved. It is that risk that is held over the heads of community organisations by big corporations time and again in these situations. I once had North, Australia's biggest woodchipper, which marauds Tasmania's forests, warn me that anything said as a Wilderness Society spokesperson that they thought was injudicious went before at least four QCs. It was a very clear threat by that corporation to shut up a community group that was opposing the destruction of forests in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The same applies here. No more was I able to get four QCs to give me the assurance that I could proceed without great caution in what was said than were community groups, including conservation and social justice organisations, or unions for that matter. No more are they going to be able to match the legal firepower of these big corporations.

This legislation is meant to stifle community protest. It is meant to stifle community concerns about social justice, the environment, Aboriginal interests and peace, and it will have that effect. As I explained, there are already examples of it having that effect. Let us take the Jabiluka example. If conservation or social justice groups joined the local Aboriginal community in opposing the ship ment of goods in or out of the construction site of the uranium mine as wanted by the uranium mine owners, they would be in the gun. They are facing the draconian penalty: three‐quarters of a million dollars. It is the threat of that which can put people out of action—and the government knows it.

This has already led to a re‐adjustment of the ability of community groups right around this country to be up‐front, active and involved in social justice and environmental issues. It is a draconian penalty. It is a threatening, immobilising law. It will be used against community groups further down the line. It is there because it is intended to be used and this amendment by the Greens is meant to knock it out. It is meant to give some protection to community groups to allow them to be able to use their civil rights, their rights in a democratic country to dissent, to protest and to do so without the threat of simply gargantuan fines penalising them and putting them out of action; completely destroying community groups.

We have not seen that before in legislation in this country, but we are seeing it here. It does have the ability to destroy community groups simply by dint of the size of the fine that is involved. I stand very strongly by this amendment and I hope that our friends in the Democrats will at least exercise the benefit of the doubt in favour of the community groups which are threatened by this legislation. We have had in the past conflicting legal advice, but in that situation I think the benefit of the doubt must go to the community organisations involved. If this amendment to protect these interests is unnecessary or redundant, no harm done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is very little doubt that the ability that has been given in the 1996 Workplace Relations Act to industry is used and is there as a threat. It is certainly the case that social justice groups, consumer groups, environment groups, Aboriginal land groups, people concerned about, for instance, rain forests, the impact on the environment and the impact on those people whose habitat has been removed are going to find it very difficult, if not impossible, to take on multination al corporations with a wallet of QCs—the collective noun for QCs—behind them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is certainly not the case that in any way we should allow a situation where the best legal advice the government can come up with is they do not think it will apply, because if the law is not clear enough to make this sure, then it will be used again and again to make sure such actions, based on human rights, environment or basic social justice concerns, will be prevented. The sum of $750,000 might not be a lot of money to the coalition, but people who put hours and hours of voluntary service in for the environment and for social justice—and there are thousands and thousands across Australia who operate these kinds of services on the smell of an oily rag, or the smell of a non‐oily rag, depending on whether you are an environment group—will have no means of survival. This is obviously what the government is suggesting. Nobody will take the risk, even if they believe they have an absolutely firm case that nobody can really prove that what they did was technically to harm an industry.

If you really do not want someone to bring in rainforest timber, what you want to do is prevent that import. How do you then be sure, with virtually no resources, that you are going to be able to fight and win that case, because every time, even if you do win a case, there will be an appeal? There is no way. It is a bit like a game of poker, where the person with the least to lose can keep going until the other person has to blink. We all know that that is the case. I have seen the case with slap suits in Western Australia, how the law is used to beat people on the head who in fact have a winnable case but who do not have the ability to take on the risk, to take on a multinational corporation. Therefore, the Greens (WA) will strongly support this amendment which Senator Brown has moved and which is the same as the amendment he moved in the industrial relations bill when we debated it the last time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate we will be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a look through my papers on this stuff and I recall the very intense debate that occurred around this issue. Those on the progressive side of politics do feel very strongly about the question of persons not engaged in industrial action but engaged in primary boycotts on consumer, environmental or human rights grounds being appropriately protected. I argued then that the Democrats had successfully found the appropriate protection. Senator Brown quite rightly says that the legal advice he had differs from that we had—and, as we all know, lawyers do differ. There is always a problem, therefore, arising from excessive reliance on one or the other until it is resolved in fact.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to questions of fact that I think we should address ourselves. That is, we should ask whether Senator Brown's fears have as yet been realised. I think his question to the parliamentary secretary really drew attention to what is still a query as to whether there will be a negative effect on those protest movements who need to be supported in our society and that the movements will not in any way be threatened or diminished.
I had a look at the legal advice that was offered by Sydney lawyer Tim Robertson to the conservation council. I will quote again, because they are still relevant, aspects from his opinion. He said:
I have carefully considered the contending claims of Senators Murray and Brown concerning the effect of the secondary boycotts amendments to this Bill.
The bill at that time was the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill. He continued:
Essentially Dr Brown is incorrect in contending that a wide variety of legitimate protest action would be caught by the Bill as amended.

Dr Brown's legal advice was erroneous, because it ignored the broad exemption of all consumer boycotts from these provisions of the Trade Practices Act: s.51(2A), and it failed to examine recent decisions which have broadly defined the term `environment' and consumer action.
In a later paragraph, he said:

The concept of `environmental protection' which is a permissible purpose for undertaking otherwise prohibited boycott action will be broadly construed by the Courts in accordance with the High Court's decision. It will be construed to include, for example, the living conditions of indigenous groups whose dispossession is as much an impact on the environment as a consequence of the environmental impact of the extractive industry whose presence causes that dispossession. I have used this example because it was relied upon in the legal advice to Dr Brown as an example of a purpose which would not be protected.

The two most common forms of protest engaged in by human rights and consumer and environmental groups have been consumer boycotts and picketing. Picketing can be for any number of reasons, including those to do with the environment. Consumer boycotts are expressly excluded from the operation of the Trade Practices Act by section 51(2A), and pickets have been upheld again and again by the courts as a valid and legal form of protest.

The Federal Court in the 1993 J‐Corp case held that peaceful picketing was not a secondary boycott. It is my belief always that it is a primary boycott. This is because the purpose of the picket was not to hinder and to prevent trade but to affect and hinder the outcome, which would be contrary to that which would normally be undertaken in industrial action.

Except for one instance that I can recall, under Labor's laws—they were harsher in this area than are these laws because we had built in the protections we have through our amendments—environmental groups have not been challenged or threatened in court action. Unless that has happened and can be proven to have happened since the passage of this law 10 months ago, I think it would confirm the Democrats' and my belief that, in all those areas which Senator Brown quite rightly feels strongly about, in respect of environmental and consumer protection in the broadest way in which it has been defined in the courts—it includes cultural and peaceful and other motivations—we are still appropriately protected.

Accordingly, having considered again at length Senator Brown's proposal, and knowing as you do where we stand on environmental and human rights issues—you know what our policies and our positions are—we do not think that the government has put us at any risk. We will continue to support the act as it is written.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept we are at an impasse here. The telling component of my argument is if this amendment does nothing that the bill already does then why oppose it. Why not be sure? The very terminology of the spokesman for the government—that it is highly unlikely that this legislation would be used against community groups—fills me with terror.

SPEECH.PARA: The very fact that we have conflicting legal advice—mine comes from Gary Corr, who is an eminent barrister—fills me with terror. It leaves it open to the community groups to front up to multinational corporations to sort it out. The corporations have got the money and the power. We ought not allow that situation to persist. It is up to us to clear the air.

My amendment clears the air. It states categorically that such groups are protected. But if we leave it as it is, and if this amendment gets turned down by the government and the Democrats, the onus is on community groups to protect and defend themselves with the legislation as it stands—unsorted out. That is very onerous on such groups; it is unfair; and it is going to lead to them being put in an invidious situation further down the line. The threat is hanging over their heads anyway.

I cannot understand why this amendment is not being supported. I cannot understand why, if it simply endorses the protection that is in the legislation, the air is not cleared by this being supported by the Democrats. But that is as it stands.

Fear is embodied in this legislation as far as potential action is concerned. I repeat that it involves fines of three‐quarters of a million dollars going against social justice, environment, Aboriginal and peace groups in this country. The problem with this legislation is that the defending is left to those groups, not to us as parliamentarians.

I am here to defend their interests. The Greens are here to stand strongly with those groups—to stand strongly for the right of community organisations to protest without having the might of multinational corporations wielding QCs—a wallet of QCs as Senator Margetts put it—putting them out of action. One thing we do know is that this legislation is so confused on this point that not one community group is going to be able to sort it out. The multinationals might be able to, but the community groups certainly will not.

I am very sad that the Democrats are not going to join the rest of us on the progressive side of politics—as Senator Murray put it—to make sure that progressive groups in the community are not left with a question mark and a threat hanging over their head but are free to undertake their time‐honoured course of community action, enlightenment and protest, which is going to be trammelled here simply by the threat of this legislation if not by the invocation of the draconian penalties that it contains.
