PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ian Campbell) read a third time.

BREAK.XREF: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 October, on motion by Senator Parer:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —There are nine bills involved in this package of legislation. I would like to indicate that the opposition does not oppose the package of measures that have been introduced by the government. There are two elements to the package. The first can be described as the fuel substitution package. The second comprises two pieces of legislation and is also tied to the issue that was debated in the other place, the House of Representatives, in response to a decision handed down by the High Court on the collection of excise as a result of a challenge launched by the state of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to firstly say one or two things about the fuel substitution package, which is a package of seven bills. The measures that are to be set out in this legislation will implement the government's budget decision to combat revenue lost through the minimisation of fuel substitution and to improve compliance in the payment of customs and excise duty. The measures will provide for the addition of chemical markers to concessional petroleum products. They will impose penalties for the use of marked products and sale of marked products for use as internal combustion engine fuels and for the blending of marked and unmarked products. What that means in plain English is that they will dye the fuel so you can work out which is right and which is wrong.

As a result of these measures, there will be some enhanced record keeping requirements that will be imposed on fuel users. The use of a chemical marker will enable the Australian Customs Service to detect when these products are blended with or substituted for excisable fuel. This package is designed to prevent the substitution of heating oil for diesel fuel. Heating oil attracts a much lower excise duty than diesel fuel. It can be substituted for it but with considerable danger because it has a much lower flashpoint and can result in damaging effects to the vehicle in question.

As I have said, the opposition supports this move on both safety and environmental grounds. It will provide a standard of proof to enable prosecution of people found illegally selling or illegally blending fuels for on‐road use. We believe that giving customs officers these additional powers to monitor abuses in this way is a good advance. It is an attempt to prevent people substituting environmentally degraded products in fuels and therefore causing environmental damage. What it does is say that if people do the wrong thing then by having an appropriate chemical marker in place the government officials will be able to determine this and, as a consequence, a penalty will be imposed. As I have said, we support that move.

These particular bills, the Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , the Customs Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Misuse (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Sale (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Blending (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel (Penalty Surcharges) Administration Bill 1997 , Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 all deal with the same issues. They are primarily concerned with addressing a revenue problem for the government. If you understand the complexity of how all of those bills interrelate you are doing far better than most of us. But the opposition does recognise that the introduction of these measures will address loopholes in existing excise legislation. In addition to bringing benefits of increased collection of revenue to the government, they will benefit consumers through ensuring safer petroleum products. They will also provide protection to the petroleum products distribution and retail system.

Prior to this package being debated in the House of Representatives, the opposition received correspondence from oil recyclers and oil re‐refiners, voicing their concerns that this package of legislation will result in a more onerous excise regime for them, thus making them less commercially competitive. The opposition obtained advice from Customs that there would be a differential excise regime for oil recyclers and oil re‐refiners that would address the concerns that they have raised. I would like the minister to confirm that this will be the case and I am sure he will do that.

In conclusion, I will say that the opposition does not oppose the fuel legislation package. However, in preparing this package the government engaged in consultation with parties with an interest, including oil companies, oil distributors, the National Farmers Federation, motoring organisations such as the NRMA, the RACV and the RACWA and consumer affairs bodies. In his second reading speech the minister made a commitment to take into account any ongoing concerns about the operation of these measures. I take this opportunity to remind the government of that commitment. We understand this is to be a message from the government that they will fix any unintended problems that will arise as a result of this package, and I would like to ask the minister to confirm that for the record. With those remarks, I do indicate that the opposition will support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill, the Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , is a bill which could have been handled simply but in fact has been handled very badly by the government. There have been discussions over time and the concerns that have been expressed over time have not been dealt with. They could have been dealt with very simply. In my contribution today I will explain how those issues could have been dealt with. The fuel oil bills presented here are not ones that I, nor I think many people, have any substantial problems with. I do not think anyone objects to ensuring that the use of unprocessed waste oil to thin out ordinary fuel is not promoted. Currently, the system of excise means that such oil can be added to reduce fuel taxes, which does provide incentives for such practices.

SPEECH.PARA: The practices referred to often mean that contaminated or inappropriate products are mixed with fuel, with the result that emissions from burning such fuel are even more polluting than normal. Contaminants can result in chemical combinations from burning which are further recombined when struck by sunlight in what are called photochemical reactions. These occur with the burning of most petroleum products, but adding additional contaminants and further decreasing the efficiency of burning greatly increases the type and volume of chemicals in the photochemical mix. The resulting products are often toxins to either animal or plant life: carcinogens, mutagens or other kinds of nasty substances. The Greens support any measures that will reduce the chemical load we and the ecology are exposed to.

On the other hand, this issue seems to specifically affect waste oil. In 1994, there were about 213 million litres of waste oil produced. Of that, about 120 million litres were collected for recycling or some other use. That is 120 million litres that did not get tipped down waste water drains or get dumped into the earth and eventually into ground water. The figures also mean that some 97 million litres of oil were dumped into the environment. We are talking about an environmental disaster equivalent to an oil tanker accident occurring each year in Australia.

Currently, there are efforts to recycle oil. In garages and motor repair shops around the country, and in industries doing a lot of transport, there are often drums in the corner to collect the waste oil. Home mechanics are asked to catch the waste oil when changing oil and take it to their local service station to put in their waste oil drums. It is then collected by private industry, who pay a small fee for the oil. There is no requirement for recycling oil in most places. It is a voluntary activity.

As with most recycling, the major cost is in collecting a highly dispersed product. Coming from an oilfield or a refinery through to distributors to retailers, the chain is then reversed, needing to come from customers and auto mechanics back to retail sites all over the country, where formal collection takes place. It is then re-refined, or filtered and cleaned, and redistributed back to customers again. As a recycled product, it generally cannot attract the same price as the new product. The collection process is one of the more expensive, labour intensive aspects of recycling. It is one of the factors that keep profit margins in recycling industries close to the bone.

Currently, there are some very good recycling companies. Wren Oil in Western Australia collects and processes millions of litres of oil, and uses a fairly high level of technology to clean the impurities and contaminants from the oil. Our worry has been to ensure that this bill does not adversely affect the recycled oil industry, particularly those who are acting responsibly and doing a good job cleaning the waste oil. We want to ensure that they are not directly affected by having a punitive excise put on their product, nor affected indirectly by putting the excise on the use to which their major market puts the oil.

This has been an ongoing issue with us in respect of both Wren Oil and other oil recyclers. These companies sell oil for blending to Western Power, the public sector power provider. The oil is used in diesel power stations in Broome, Derby, Exmouth and Esperance. By blending 20 per cent processed recycled oil with ordinary industrial diesel oil, IDO, the outcome is that the fuel for these remote, off-grid state power stations is cheaper and the cross-subsidies in power provision are thereby reduced. It also means that there are avenues for marketing recycled oil, which then does not have to be disposed of by government at a cost to taxpayers. It means that the oil can be used instead of dumped into the environment, and it means that the import of diesel oil is reduced, improving our balance of trade.

It angers me that this bills is being brought forward in this way now. I understand that there is a new minister trying to show that he can push the Senate around, and that means in this case pushing around the Greens for having the temerity to bring these matters up, and not wanting to address them. But that does not really excuse this. The bill was listed as non-controversial three weeks ago. At that time, I discussed our concerns with the minister's advisers. They acknowledged them, talked about what a great job Wren Oil and other recycling companies were doing, expressed appreciation of the magnitude of the problem of waste oil and said they recognised that these companies, with millions of litres of waste oil in their holding tanks, would be adversely affected by this legislation.

The advisers said they not only recognised the problems and issues but were committed to trying to act to resolve them. I said, `Fine. If you get the oil recycling issue resolved, we will be happy to support the bill as non-controversial. Until you do, there's no way we can.' I was assured that we would get something, possibly before the Thursday lunchtime. That did not happen, and I asked for it to be taken off the non-controversial list until the issues were resolved. That was three weeks ago. On Friday, we saw that these bills were scheduled for today. We said, `This is still a problem unless the oil recycling issue is resolved. Once it is resolved, we are happy to see them pass quickly as non-controversial or as ordinary legislation, with only a few minutes comment and congratulations from us.'

Instead, what we got was a letter, which has not been sent, from the minister to Wren Oil saying that the government proposes to put in place a mechanism—an undefined regulation—to exempt the four power stations in Western Australia from the legislation. We were also told that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has not approved the letter, the regulation has not been drafted and, as a consequence, the oil recyclers have not accepted it and there is no real assurance that Treasury will support the modifications. We are told that Jeff Ashauer from Customs will fly out next week to finalise the regulations with the recyclers. We are told that the regulations will then go to executive council and be put in place before the legislation comes into effect at the new year.

It seems that there are a lot of unknowns and provisional commitments in here. If the Treasurer agrees then a letter can be sent, and if it is sent then a regulation can be negotiated, and if the regulation is drafted then it can go to executive council, and if that regulation actually deals with the issues of the industry and if it is passed by the executive council by 1 January then it resolves the short-term crisis which passage of this bill in its current form will—not just might—cause to the oil recycling industry. That is not terribly reassuring. There are far too many ifs in this chain.

On the other hand, we have suggested that if the process already put in place continues and Customs come up with a formula of words which meet the concerns of the industry and, in the meantime, agreement is reached for the support of the Treasurer then this bill becomes one which gets support on all sides and will pass through this place easily. With the current timetable that we are assured already exists these things could be in place by next week. In such a case, we have said that we would be happy to see these bills treated as non-controversial. I thought we had some agreement on that. Instead, we see the minister has decided to confront the Senate and waste its time by fighting this out in the chamber instead of taking the commonsense approach. I do not understand why this is happening.

I am not prepared to support this bill in its current state. I have not seen any evidence that substitution of fuels is a massive problem nor has the Oil Recyclers' Association. They can very easily imagine that it could be a problem—they are assured that some big oil companies are involved in unscrupulous practices using unprocessed waste heating oil to thin fuel, but at least some of the members have not actually seen such actions. That being the case, I am not happy to support a bill that will potentially substantially damage the capacity to commercially collect and recycle waste oil, and I will argue against its passage. If there was something that was urgent and these practices were going on then it surely would be incumbent on them to make sure that the requests that we made three weeks ago could have been dealt with urgently. So, if the answer is, `This is urgent and we have to deal with it now,' then the response could have been dealt with and could have been made available.

As far as I know, the decision was made to push ahead with this bill without even waiting to see whether the Treasurer will support the first step in the chain—the sending of a letter, of which I have been given a draft, to Mr Wren of Wren Oil. I am happy to be disabused about the Treasurer's support for this, and if we do not get any response from the minister now we will be asking questions in the committee stage. This letter makes limited assurances but even if they are undertaken they will not be enough to assure that there is no damage to current industries—so the letter itself does not really help that much.

As far as I can tell, the state of play today is almost exactly what it was three weeks ago. There is understanding of this issue by Customs and the advisers of the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss). There is a proposal for a solution by regulation. There is no draft of what the regulation should be. There is no agreement from Treasury. There is no commitment that adequate regulations will be in place by the time the legislation takes effect. This was the situation three weeks ago and nothing has changed. I cannot see that progress has been made.

You want the Senate to pass this bill in the hope that maybe things will start happening, maybe the Treasurer will approve and maybe the regulations will be in before damage is done. Is that what the minister is asking? This really is not good enough. If it was some industry that was dear to the heart of the government I am sure that you would be listening to the concerns. But maybe it is because is it an oil recycling industry. Maybe the people who have the ear of the government are those people who use oil—perhaps lots of oil. Maybe those are the people the government is listening to. It is interesting at a time when people are talking about fossil fuels and greenhouse gas that the government might be taking that approach. I would hate to think that that was the case.

If any link in that string of maybes breaks down then once this legislation is passed there stops being any reason for Western Power to buy recycled oil from the recyclers and the tanks will overflow. After a few months the oil recyclers may well be in trouble economically—a few months may be all that is necessary to do it. Other people in the industry might be happy about that. I do not know about the government. If they fold then no-one will collect the waste oil. This is a disaster and I do hope that the minister takes it into consideration and gives me some very clear reasons why this is being done in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cook and Senator Margetts for their contributions to the debate on the Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 and related legislation. I note that they both basically support the legislation. Senator Cook raised a couple of questions. One was in regard to the differential regime, and I think that he would appreciate, as would other senators, that under the legislation some products previously escaping will be caught by the legislation. That is one of the reasons it was brought in—the recycled oil was being used in the transport system and not for the purpose it was originally intended.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the issues raised by Senator Margetts, I say from the outset that this government is very enthusiastic to see that this oil is recycled rather than ending up in places where it should not. But Senator Margetts has raised specifically the issues in regard to power stations in Western Australia and the companies that produce recycled oil in Western Australia, which include not only Wren oil, which she has mentioned, but also Oil Energy Corporation Pty Ltd.

On 20 October last, the then minister for customs put the view to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) that the existing concessional situation should be maintained in view of the following factors: the immediate environmental effect of removing the market for products derived from the recycling of up to 11 million litres of oil a year in Western Australia; the comparatively small amount of revenue involved; the fact that this revenue was not part of the $25 million increase expected from the fuel substitution minimisation legislation, as it was not known at the time that the blended fuel was being used for the remote power station; the advisedly relatively short time frame of the requested concessions, as the Western Power Corporation's submission advises that three of the power stations mentioned are likely to convert to alternative fuel sources within a two- to three-year time frame; in addition, a sunset clause could be imposed; and the fact that it appears possible to quarantine a concession to fuel to the four power stations concerned. In addition, for operational reasons, there is a limit on the percentage of recycled material which the power station operators are prepared to utilise.
As indicated, that is the current position. It is important for this legislation to go through because, in the process—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your current position? You haven't stated it.
—Senator Margetts, I have just spelt out the current position.
—No, you haven't. Are you going to leave these people floundering?
—Order! Senator Margetts, you can ask those questions when we get into committee.

—It is important for the legislation to go through, because it addresses current areas where there is pollution. As Senator Cook quite correctly pointed out, in some areas the use of this particular oil in the wrong circumstances, because of its low flashpoint, can be dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the second matter I should address regarding the queries raised by Senator Margetts, it is important for the bill to go through to enable the regulations to be proceeded with. Without the passage of the bill, we cannot prepare the regulations. So, just in conclusion, I believe that the issues of concern to senators here either have been or are being addressed.
(Quorum formed)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister confirm that about 20 per cent of residents in some nursing homes have been given incorrect income assessments? Can he also confirm that many other residents have not received an income assessment at all and that this means nursing homes will have to charge them the maximum $443.10 weekly fee for their care? Isn't this just further evidence that the government's nursing home policy is in absolute disarray?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for the question. No, I am not aware of those points that Senator McKiernan raised. It was interesting that the opposition's spokesman on the Channel 9 Today program said that nursing homes were in `desperate straits'. If they are in desperate straits and Labor was in power for 13 years, the opposition has something to be accountable for to the Australian public.

ANSWER.PARA: However, with all due respect, it is not entirely the opposition's fault. It is important for everybody to recognise that one in eight of the population in this country is now over the age of 65 and 50 per cent of the bed days in public hospitals are occupied by people over the age of 65. Therefore two‐thirds of our health care dollar in this country is spent on people over the age of 65. There are enormous problems, but at the same time there is good news. The fastest growing group in this community are people over the age of 80.

TALK.START.PARA: —The good news is that hopefully, you won't be a minister too much longer.

—Senator Schacht did not hear that because he had his mouth open and his ears closed, so I will repeat it. The fastest growing group in the community are those over the age of 80. I hope one day that Senator Schacht is there, because they are the fastest growing group and people have to take this into account. However, only 30 per cent of people over the age of 85 need residential care. So we are discussing a relatively small population.

ANSWER.PARA: I note today is Breast Cancer Awareness Day and it reflects on the fact that more than half of the population are female. That age group is predominantly female—there are twice as many females over the age of 85 as males. I come back to Senator McKiernan's question. It has to be recognised that there are many problems that this country must face.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Herron was specifically asked if he could confirm that a significant number of residents in nursing homes have been given incorrect income assessments. He was also asked if he could confirm that many other residents had not received any income assessment at all and that would mean that nursing homes would have to charge them a maximum $443.10 weekly fee for their care.

INTERJECT.PARA: That is not to say the issues that Senator Herron is canvassing are not important. Every senator in this chamber and many listening on television would accept that they are important issues. But this is no attempt at all to answer the specific questions that were directed to Senator Herron by Senator McKiernan about nursing home care. I do ask you, Madam President, to ask him to answer those questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron certainly dealt with Senator McKiernan's question in the beginning and than strayed from it. Just prior to your intervention, he said, `To come back to Senator McKiernan's question', and I certainly hope that that is what he is doing and it is what should be happening.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was doing that. I just wanted to seize the opportunity to bring home to the Senate the importance of the ageing population in this country that has to be addressed. All of these problems that we are addressing would have to be addressed whoever was in power and it is important that they be recognised. It is all very well to have political point scoring, but there is a very major issue facing this country.

BREAK.PARA: My response to Senator McKiernan's question was that I said, no, I was not aware. I meant that to be generic in the sense that it was an answer to both the questions. I was not aware of those things, but I will check with the minister to see if the department is aware of that, or in fact if they are occurring. I do not always accept the statements made by the other side as being correct. Senator McKiernan may have had some evidence in that regard, but I would not accept that as being absolute. I will get back to him with an answer from the department and the minister in reply to the questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true as reported in the Daily Telegraph last Friday that computers at Centrelink, the organisation that does the income testing, and the health department cannot crossmatch the data between each other? Is it any surprise then that so many nursing home residents have been given incorrect income assessments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I now see where Senator McKiernan got the information. I do not believe everything I read in the papers. I find that statement surprising. I did read it myself and I was surprised by it. I am unable to say whether it is true or untrue, but again I will get back with an answer to Senator McKiernan as soon as possible.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. In the last election campaign the coalition was up front with the Australian public in foreshadowing the sale of one-third of Telstra. Is this government's approach to the sale of one-third of Telstra fully consistent with its election promise, and are there any other approaches worthy of being taken into account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, what the government has done to date is entirely consistent with what we said prior to the last election, and that was that we would put our proposal before the people at the appropriate time, as we did. We argued our case. We were elected on the strength of it and the policy then went on to make it clear that, if we are were ever minded to go further, we would once again put that matter before the Australian public. That, of course, is the honest and honourable way to approach these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: The Democrats have been pretty consistent on this. While they have been consistently wrong, they have at least had the courage of their convictions and they have consistently opposed privatisation. I hold my breath, but I doubt very much that we will be seeing much of a change from them in the foreseeable future.

As far as the Labor Party is concerned, this crowd has prior convictions as long as your arm. If their form were that of a racehorse they would be up before the stewards and they would be swabbed and they would be rubbed out. Prior to the 1990 election they said that they would keep the Commonwealth Bank in full public ownership. Immediately after the election they said they would sell off 49 per cent of it. Before the 1993 election they promised to keep the Commonwealth Bank in majority public ownership. Then Ralph Willis solemnly and sincerely confirmed that in the Commonwealth Bank prospectus. Only two years later they again welched on that commitment. Less than 12 months ago Labor was vehemently opposing the government's one-third sale of Telstra, saying that Telstra should stay in full public ownership. Now we have this platform conference proposal that Labor supports Telstra's retention in majority public ownership and will maintain the power of the minister to direct Telstra in the national interest.

As Senator Schacht has made very clear on a previous occasion, that is simply code for saying, `We have a marginal seat strategy and if we think we need to tell Telstra to do something that is otherwise uneconomic but in our political interest we will have no hesitation in doing so.' One can understand where they come from politically, but I can assure you that the business community and potential investors will be horrified to hear that once again Senator Schacht is reaffirming that he has that approach. This is the whiteboard strategy all over again. If you see a milch cow and you think that you do not have the money to solve the problem you direct it to solve it for you.

What this is really about—and I think Senator Allison identified it—is that if Labor gets its hands on the honey pot, they will go a lot further than 49 per cent. Senator Schacht says publicly he has no plans to further sell down Telstra shareholding. Why would anyone ever believe that? The Left claims to be violently opposed. I do not know what the disgruntled unionist faction, the Bolkus Left— the one that Senator Schacht nominally belongs to—has to say about this. But once again, it seems extraordinary that they can expect anyone to believe their claim that they have no plans to sell down further. We know where former Senator Kernot stood. She was adamantly opposed, but she has been told to keep quiet, sit on her hands and say nothing on this issue. That is the sort of the policy leadership that we are now getting from the alternative leader of the Labor Party. So nothing much has changed about Labor, despite the fact that Simon Crean now wants to call them `Real Labor'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. My point of order is this, Madam President: Senator Alston was asked a question by Senator Tierney in relation to government election commitments and coalition election commitments. He was also asked whether those election commitments had been honoured in the 18 months that the coalition government has been in office. My point of order to you, Madam President, is this: do you consider the last 90 seconds of this answer, which relates—apparently—to certain Labor Party opposition front benchers in this chamber and to a range of other issues relating to Labor Party policy questions, is in order? I do not believe it is. Madam President, I think you need to be consistent with previous rulings that you have made in relation to this. If Senator Alston is not capable of answering the dorothy dix question that he has been asked by Senator Tierney, albeit as simple as it is, then you ought to sit him down.
—I would need to check the end of the question, but I thought there was another point to the question.
—Senator Faulkner must not have been listening to the question. The last part said: `Are there other approaches worthy of being taken into account?' Senator Alston is certainly answering that.

—On that point of order, that part of the question is clearly in order, and Senator Alston can go to that. But consistently, from about 1987 to 1996, on hundreds of occasions those sitting opposite took objection to questions and answers that went to opposition policy. Clearly for the last 90 seconds Senator Alston has gone to what he thinks purports to be Labor Party policy. Consistently Senators Sibraa and Beahan ruled out of order those parts of the answers that went to opposition policy. This has only been a factor that has been sneaking into government ministers' answers in the last three to six months and you should rule it out of order, consistent with the rulings of your predecessors.
—On the point of order: Standing orders do deal with this. There is case law on the subject, rulings from your predecessors—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment. What you will find—I just happened to take the opportunity to look at it the other day—is that it says that you are not entitled to ask questions directly about the other side's policies but you can certainly deal with them in terms of your own policies or the government's approach to policy. That is precisely what is being asked of here. If we were simply asked to give an opinion on the other side's policies—I know it would not take long—it might have difficulty in complying with that interpretation of the standing orders. But to the extent that you are being asked about how that affects the government's approach, whether these are policies worthy of being taken into account, that is precisely what it is all about. I simply draw your attention to those—
—You've been caught out!
—Caught out? You have been caught out by default getting a job that you should never have been promoted to. It is Parkinson's law at its worst.

—As to the point of order, it is not appropriate to ask a question to comment on opposition policy. That is absolutely correct. The way the question was worded was not in that form. Senator Alston needs to be careful that he deals with the matter that he wants to put in answer to the question in the correct form. But I shall be listening carefully to the way it is handled.

—I am indebted to you, Madam President. It is precisely in line with the ruling. I am also delighted to find that the Labor Party is now paying attention during these answers—at long last. They have obviously adjourned sine die the meetings of the sandpit clubs. They have realised that there is something to be learned, after all, from getting policy right. Ditching the name `New Labor' and going for `Real Labor' won't fool anyone because on privatisation when you come to the next election you will be told: get real.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Does the government intend to agree to the request by the chief architect of its nursing home policy, Mr Doug Moran, for access to more money from nursing home bonds? If so, how much more of a bond of, say, $250,000 should a nursing home proprietor such as Mr Moran have access to and how will the government guarantee the safety of the bond money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Campbell for his question. I will disabuse his mind. Mr Moran was not the architect of the—
—He said he was!

—He was not the architect. If the opposition will listen, I will tell them who the architects were. The architects were the many residents of nursing homes and the nursing home proprietors who approached the government because there was a desperate need, as the opposition spokesman herself said on the Today program, for money to be spent on nursing homes. I enumerated on previous occasions the desperate strait they were in as a result of the Labor Party's failure to spend money in the 13 years they had the opportunity to do so. The opposition spokesman even said that the Labor Party spent $1 billion. She forgot to mention that it was over 13 years, so they spent about $70 million a year. The nursing homes of this country have been run down over that period.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in terms of bonds, we have extended the Labor Party's policy on hostels to nursing homes. The Labor Party introduced that policy in 1988, whereby the amount providers can charge is not prescribed. That is an issue for agreement between the resident and the aged care facility. The policy has worked well in hostels, where bonds have remained modest, at an average of around $26,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Labor policy.

—That was Labor policy. We have followed that in relation to nursing homes. Two per cent are in fact uncapped because it was felt that there was no need for capping. The Labor Party felt there was no need for capping because there were too many inequities that occurred as a result of that. We have continued that. The government will, however, be monitoring the new arrangements closely and, as the Prime Minister announced, there will be finetuning. We will act firmly if there is any sign of providers abusing the system. Of those bonds, only two per cent of hostels have charged bonds over $80,000.
—You are talking about hostels—that is quite different.

—Yes, I am talking about hostels. I am drawing the analogy of the principle of what occurs in hostels and the fact that we are transferring that to nursing homes. There are no caps on them. Very few have in fact paid bonds to date, so we cannot give a representative sample to those who are wondering what has been occurring over that period. We are monitoring the situation and I am happy to tell Senator Campbell that we will continue to do that. It will be finetuned as necessary in the light of what comes through.

ANSWER.PARA: The system does allow self‐funded retirees and part‐pensioners to pay a proportion of their income. The bonds in Queensland, for instance, reach up to $60,000. The average is, as I said, $26,000 and they do reach up to more than twice that, but that is the upper end of the market. Senator Campbell may not be aware that there are certain people who want to go into a very high quality nursing home, and they can afford to do so. Entry to the nursing home is based on need rather than the ability to pay. But those that wish to pay more should be entitled to pay more and get a higher degree of accommodation if they so desire it. I see no difficulty with that. The then Labor government saw no difficulty with that in relation to hostels. I do not see why they should try to penalise anybody in relation to the principle. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Great Australian Bight: Proposed Marine Park

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer to the minister's announcement yesterday relating to the government's proposal to create a 2.3 million hectare marine park in the Great Australian Bight—a park which is bigger than the Kakadu National Park, at 1.9 million hectares; bigger than the Tasmanian wilderness world heritage area, at 1.3 million hectares; and bigger than the central eastern rainforest reserve in New South Wales, at 366,000 hectares. Minister, can you please explain to the Senate the environmental benefits of this newest Australian national park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am very pleased to. This government has a very strong position in relation to marine conservation, something that was somewhat neglected by the last Labor government. The government's position was demonstrated in the last couple of weeks, firstly, by the successful mission to the sub‐Antarctic to protect the environmental interests of Australia's environmental responsibilities in that area, in particular the total allowable catch of the Patagonian toothfish. That was a very successful mission about which I spoke last week.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, it was also demonstrated during the last week in the efforts that the Australian delegation was making at the International Whaling Commission. Australia is now leading the world in its efforts to apply a complete ban on commercial whaling, a position of which we are very proud. We trust that ultimately we will succeed in a truly global sanctuary for whales. That will be a very fine step for the international community to take.

Thirdly, this last weekend I announced, after about 12 months of negotiation, the next step in establishing a large marine conserva tion park in the Great Australian Bight. It might surprise you to know that this is the first declared marine protection area in southern temperate waters. In fact it has been suggested to me that it might be the first in the world. There is no doubt that nations have concentrated on the tropical waters and protected areas around reefs, perhaps areas that might be of higher tourist appeal or for some other reason. But, for whatever reasons, the temperate waters have been neglected. We know very little about the science of such areas.

What we are doing in the Great Australian Bight is looking towards a park that will serve a dual purpose. The first is a mammal protection area which will adjoin the state government's park and which will look to protect the Southern Right Whale during its breeding season and also to protect the Australian sea lion in the area and other rare seals and sea lions that exist within the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you announce this three weeks ago, before the South Australian election?
—If you have a question, Senator Schacht, you can ask it at the appropriate time.

—Senator Schacht may have no interest in this matter, but it is believed that area is possibly the most significant breeding ground in the world of the Southern Right Whale, the third rarest whale currently existing. I am very pleased that the Commonwealth has been prepared to take this action, which will mean for some months of the year activities inconsistent with protecting the whales in the breeding season will not be permitted.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition there will be a larger park area which is designed to protect the sea floor and obviously all that is accommodated on the sea floor. This is the first time, as I understand it, that a government has made an effort to protect the sea floor in this way, something that most Australians, if not the Australian Labor Party, can see great benefit in doing. It will be a 20 nautical mile strip that will go out to the end of Australia's EEZ. It will not interfere with uses that are compatible with the conservation values that we are seeking to protect.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing that most who have studied the matters that have been announced this weekend have applauded the initiative taken by the Howard government. I notice the South Australian Conservation Council, of which Senator Schacht is aware, applauded it and the Australian Marine Conservation Society applauded it. What did the South Australian Conservation Society say? They said that the Howard government was leading by example in encouraging state governments to act on developing a national representative system of marine protected areas, and they are quite right. There are some who have expressed some caution about it—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The tuna industry, as Senator Schacht is seeking to interject. What we can say to the tuna industry is that they will not be affected by this particular park. This is a multiple park that, as I said, allows compatible uses. (Time expired)
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, how does the principle of mutual obligation apply to nursing home care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to note that this year the government is spending $2.6 billion on the aged care industry, both hostels and nursing homes, and by the year 2000 that will rise to $3 billion; there are 2,500 new places each year; and there are 135,000 people in nursing homes and hostels.

ANSWER.PARA: The principle applies as it does, as asked about by Senator Faulkner, because of this desperate need for new nursing homes, as the opposition spokesman mentioned on a television program yesterday morning, and more money needs to be spent on them. The money could come from taxation but the problem with that—which is what the Labor Party is espousing—is that the number of taxpayers will be decreasing.

BREAK.PARA: The minister is finetuning the program and is announcing in the other chamber at the moment that there will be a package of changes to the implementation of the reforms. These changes will eliminate some anomalies that have become apparent and will protect existing nursing home and hostel residents. Under the changes announced today by the minister, income testing will be deferred until 1 March 1998 and will apply only to new residents entering care on or after that date—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the assets test in 1984—

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well done, Jenny Macklin!

—Madam President, you can hear the cheers from the other side, can't you, because these are changes that are necessary. Residents in care before 1 March 1998 will not pay higher income tested fees. For the purposes of income testing for nursing home and hostel benefits, assets gifted prior to 20 August 1996 shall not be taken into account. That was the date of the announcement, and that is why that date pertains.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, these changes are being announced in the other chamber. The government is finetuning the program. The principle—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I asked Senator Herron a very specific question in relation to how the principle of mutual obligation applies to nursing home care. It may very well be that Mr Smith or someone else is announcing changes to this abysmal policy in the House of Representatives, but what I am after is an answer to the question I have asked—a question which is clear and specific and I think important enough to deserve an answer from the minister. I ask you to direct him to answer it.
—I do draw your attention to the specific question that was asked, Senator.

—Madam President, with respect, it was not a very specific ques tion and I think I had the latitude to reply to that question in broad terms. The principle that is espoused is that those who can afford to pay should pay; those who wish a higher level of accommodation can have such if they so desire. The requirement is that this money be found for nursing homes because of the rapid ageing of the population, and the principle pertains then that the burden not be placed entirely on the taxpayer.

BREAK.PARA: We are taking a stand in relation to the taxpayers of this country that they should not be required to have an increased tax burden. The reality is that, as I tried to point out over a series of answers to questions, with the rapid ageing of the population, the number of taxpayers relative to those who need taxation support is decreasing. So something has to be done. In fact, Senator Ray mentioned earlier the change that occurred in 1984, and I agree with that interjection. The Labor Party way back then started to recognise it, but it then did not do anything further about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you might be aware that the Prime Minister has justified the government's user pays approach to nursing home care on the basis of mutual obligation. In the government's view, what obligations do people in nursing homes have to pay for their own nursing home care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just answered that in generality. It is a fact that 40 per cent of people in nursing homes do not pay anything. Senator Faulkner is probably not aware of that, but that is a fact. They do not pay because they are fully pensionable. There is a sliding scale of asset testing. The minister has announced changes today, which I have relayed here, in relation to that, so I have answered the question.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, has your government assessed the impact on taxation revenue of the Telstra float? I refer to the advertising campaign by Metway Bank offering loans for the full purchase cost of Telstra shares, allowing buyers to claim the interest as a tax deduction and receive dividends without spending any of their money. Are you concerned that this could reduce tax revenue by as much as $175 million if only one-third of the purchase price is borrowed? Are you aware that this will bring to $1.6 billion the annual budget cost of selling Telstra when added to the cost of losing franking dividends, credits and retained profits? Given that less than $650 million is saved by using Telstra sale proceeds to retire debt, how does the government plan to fill the billion dollar black hole that will be caused by the loss of Telstra profits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the question. It has become very clear that the Telstra float is extremely popular amongst Australians. It is so popular that it seems that the Labor Party, somewhat belatedly, is attempting to hop onto the bandwagon. As Senator Alston said, it seems unlikely that the Democrats will do so.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts of the Telstra float are extremely well known. The way the funds will be used is very well known indeed. These issues have been very extensively canvassed during the debate in this chamber on the one-third partial privatisation of Telstra. We believe that the sale of Telstra will be of major benefit to the economy and to the competitive nature of telecommunications. It will also provide, as you know, additional revenue for the government to retire debt and, importantly, to establish the Natural Heritage Trust, which will do so much for the environment of this country. I would have thought that that was one of the things that the Australian Democrats would have been extremely supportive of.

We think that there are very great benefits. We have explained those benefits in great detail. You raised some figures in your question. I will have those figures checked. We make no apology for the sale of Telstra; it was a central election promise. It was a promise that this government is delivering. It was a promise that the Australian Democrats attempted to make us break. There is no black hole. There are huge benefits for the nation and for the industry. The budgetary effects have been carefully explained to you time and again in the debate on the Telstra sale bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, I ask you again to answer the question about revenue loss related to negative gearing. That was the point of my question, and I do not believe it has been raised in any of the debates so far. Isn't the public entitled to know how much taxes will rise or which services will be cut in order to plug that hole?

—Senator, I do not think you understand this debate at all. This sale will have very positive budgetary effects. Among other things, it is enabling us to do a lot of very important, interesting and valuable things for the environment, which I would have thought you would have supported.
—Get your hand out of your pocket.

—Senator Ray is getting a bit excited. Even sections of the Labor Party think it is a pretty good idea, Senator Ray. Sections of the Labor Party think this is a great policy. In fact, they want to go further. Thank you, Senator Ray, for butting in. It is a very important point. After all the huffing and puffing that went on, you have done a backflip. Another Labor tradition has gone out the window. That is what it was. As I said, we make no apology for this very important policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Why is it that the government has deferred the new child‐care arrangements from 1 January to 27 April 1998? Is it because the Prime Minister ordered the pulping of the child‐care forms after Senator Newman and the former Family Services Minister, Judi Moylan, had an argument and the forms had to be redrafted? Is the national convenor of the Association of Community‐based Childcare Centres, Ms Lynne Wannan, correct in asserting, `It's just all chaos; all the fuss that's going on with aged care will be going on with child care very soon'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor Senator Neal. She dredges around in the highways and byways and gutters and listens to all the sludge that is around the place and the scuttlebutt of newspapers and the media and cobbles together a question which she thinks will bring down the government. I can understand why the Labor Party went to the leader of another party for talent.
—Senator, I draw your attention to the question.

—Sorry, Madam President, I digress. The answer to the question is the same as the answer in relation to hostels and nursing homes. We actually went to the people and asked them what they wanted. In relation to child care, we were concerned about what the parents told us and we acknowledge the concerns of both the parents and the child‐care service providers—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht probably has no interest in this but he should because it influences even electors in his constituency of the Senate. Regarding the 1 January start date for the new child‐care payment arrangements, this has been deferred. The first payments will now apply to child care provided in the fortnight beginning 27 April 1998.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not listen to the answer I gave. It was because we listened to the parents and to the child‐care providers. But they do not want to hear that because they have some scuttlebutt that they read somewhere in the newspapers and dredged up. The reason for the deferral was that it will enable more detailed consultation to be undertaken on the regulations and other disallowable instruments required for the new legislation. The new date also allows time for services to revise their operations in line with the new requirements. It means that when families first claim with Centrelink they will be able to better predict their child‐care usage, as patterns will have settled down during the first few months of the year. Even those on the other side would recognise that we listen to parents, we listen to child‐care providers and then we take back, and where necessary we adjust, so we can implement changes that are equitable to everybody.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Herron, can you tell us how much the government spent on printing the failed version of the child‐care forms prepared by Judi Moylan when she was the Minister for Family Services? How much did the government spend?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it would be infinitesimal compared with the amount of pulping, in relation to other material that was put out and changed as things went along, that occurred when the Labor Party was in government. But if she is so concerned about that I will get an answer as to whatever cost occurred to the taxpayer, because the taxpayer has a right to know.

—My question goes to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the government accept scientific opinion that global sea levels will rise between one metre and 3.5 metres in the next few centuries because of global warming? Was it this factor that led the Prime Minister to claim in Edinburgh, for better or for worse, that he had achieved a turning of the tide over global warming? Regardless of that, what was it that tripped the Prime Minister? Was it the impending 60th anniversary of Neville Chamberlain's extraordinary and ill‐fated statement of `peace in our time' that led the Prime Minister to make his extraordinary gaffe in claiming `differentiation in our time'? (Time expired)

—There is considerable scientific uncertainty as to the full consequences of global warming. In fact, Senator Brown might not be aware that the world is actually very slowly cooling. But there is a more immediate interim issue and that is that greenhouse gases and other human interference do seem to be causing an accumulation of gases in the atmosphere, resulting in some global warming. So it is really an extraordinary, complex scientific phenomenon that we are witnessing. We are witnessing short‐term temperature increases against a long‐term temperature fall. But the extent to which sea levels will rise is not known. There is various speculation.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Brown, who I presume takes an interest in these matters, would be aware that the most recent scientific information has suggested that temperature may not be rising to the extent that was previously anticipated. But the real point is that there is no doubt that in the short term there is a temperature rise. Although the full consequences are not known, it is sensible for the international community to be responding prudently in relation to that temperature rise. That is why we as an international community are joining together to look at ways in which we can reduce the rate of accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and, therefore, take precautions against any ill consequences that would flow from increasing atmospheric temperatures.

What is pleasing now, to that background where the international community is working together to achieve this better global outcome, is that there are more signs that within the current negotiation nation states are appreciating that we are going to get a meaningful and effective outcome at Kyoto—in other words, a meaningful and effective outcome within the annex 1 negotiations—only if it takes into account the different states of the various economies that are part of the negotiation.

The recent CHOGM meeting was a further demonstration that the international community is starting to appreciate that. It is a good point because it gives us a greater chance of getting something effective out of the Kyoto meeting. Those of us who are interested in this debate want something effective from the Kyoto meeting because we want to take the pressure off the increases in greenhouse gases and the at least temporary increases in atmospheric temperature that are resulting therefrom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, why did the Prime Minister choose Great Britain to use the extraordinary and eyeball-rolling term `differentiation in our time'? Was he not aware that it is approaching the 60th anniversary of Chamberlain's equally ill-fated statement on peace in our time?

—What I can say is that the Prime Minister ought to be congratulated for both seeking to protect Australian jobs—90,000 jobs would be put at risk if we were to aim for stabilisation of 1990 figures—and at the same time being committed to ensuring that Australia plays its part in a better global outcome. To the extent that he has received a positive response to that in Edinburgh, it pleases me and it pleases the government. It would also please all of those who are interested in Australia playing a constructive international role in this difficult negotiation as well as protecting Australian jobs.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer in his capacity as representing the Treasurer. Minister, can you explain why there is an economic recession in Japan? What does the Japanese Ministry of Finance say about it, and what will be the impact on Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that growth in Japan is not of the high levels that were enjoyed in previous decades and that a fiscal consolidation has taken place in Japan. Senator, I am not the Japanese Minister for Finance. If you want a detailed analysis of the Japanese economy, I would be happy to obtain one for you or supply you with a briefing.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the general issue of the world economy is concerned, I am aware that the IMF makes regular forecasts and that the forecasts of the IMF show strong growth. That takes into account all the major economies. Of course, Australia takes great comfort from the strong growth which is forecast for the world economy. Senator, if you want an analysis of the Japanese economy, I am happy to provide you with a detailed briefing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask as well what is the impact upon the Australian economy. You have not answered that question, Senator. You might actually answer it, if you do not mind. Is it true that Japan's powerful Ministry of Finance has told Australia that the recession is due to the increase in consumption tax from three per cent to five per cent in Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, what the Labor Party will not accept is that the prospects for the Australian economy are bright. That is what you do not like. We trade with many countries. The fact of the matter is that the prospects for the world economy are for comparatively strong growth. As I have said, certainly the prospects for the Australian economy are very bright.

ANSWER.PARA: You have raised the issue of tax reform. The world is waiting to see where the Australian Labor Party stands on tax reform. We are waiting. Everyone, apart from the Australian Labor Party, seems to recognise that the issue of tax reform fundamentally has to be addressed. The reality is that the Australian Labor Party has gone missing in action. You, now as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate—hardly a fresh face, I have to say—will hopefully encourage a more constructive attitude on that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, you would be aware that today is Australia Breast Cancer Day. Given that one in 14 women develop breast cancer in the course of their lives, what activities are taking place to raise the community awareness of breast cancer? Further, what is the government doing to protect women against a disease which kills one in 25 Australian women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Synon for that important question on a very important day. Today is really very important in raising the awareness among Australian men and women of the importance of breast cancer research, the need for surveillance by women, and the emphasis by those who love them on the need for them to take responsibility for their health and to insist that they get proper breast checks.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a need to increase the awareness of breast cancer so as to reduce the number of women who are affected. The enormity of the disease is that it kills one in 25 women and that each week the number of women killed equates to the number of deaths at Port Arthur. That is the horror of this disease.

BREAK.PARA: Today I had the pleasure of launching a new stamp by Australia Post as part of the campaign to raise awareness. That stamp was the idea of Dr Linda Reaby of the University of Canberra's School of Nursing. I took the idea up with Australia Post, and that led to today's launch of the stamp. It is going to be a vital tool in building community awareness.

Australia Post is contributing to that awareness, and it also understands the consequence of breast cancer in its own workplace, as the chairman, Mrs Nicholls, pointed out in the launch today. It is not of concern just to those who are directly affected but also to family, friends and workmates. Some senators here would have wives, friends or loved ones who have been battling the consequences of breast cancer. Linda Reaby said to me in her letter that it is not just a medical problem; it is a social concern. That is so true.

Some of the things that we know about breast cancer are that risk increases with age; over 70 per cent of breast cancers occur in women over 50; and nine out of 10 women who get breast cancer do not have a strong family history of breast cancer—it is important for people to realise that. Women who have a relative who has breast cancer face an increased risk of developing the disease. Remember this also: 100,000 women with breast cancer are still alive in Australia today, and we want to increase that number.

Today's stamp launch will help save more women's lives by raising awareness of the need for mammograms for women over 50 and for those over 40 who have had a family history of the disease and ensuring ongoing research funding. I congratulate Dr Reaby on her idea and Australia Post on making it a reality. I really urge all Australians—men and women—to ensure that they stop to think each time they lick a stamp, post a letter or receive a letter whether they are doing what they need to do to ensure that Australian women do not die of breast cancer.

The government is making a substantial contribution to medical research through the National Health and Medical Research Council, with $1.9 million allocated for research into issues regarding breast cancer in 1997. It is also providing specific funds for breast cancer research through the Kathleen Cunningham Foundation, of which I am the new patron. That is $4.2 million between 1994 and 1997 from the federal governments of both persuasions. In respect of funding for 1997‐98: amounts up to $500,000 will attract matching donations on a dollar for dollar basis. The Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, announced a few days ago more funds for research into women's health issues, including breast cancer. There is a $1.5 million grant to the Jean Hailes foundation in Melbourne. Among other things, they will be looking at clinical studies of new therapies to prevent breast cancer.

So it is a governmental role to be involved, it is a community and business role to be involved, because it is workplaces that are affected by the illness and the deaths of women workers. It is also a family and a community concern to be involved to make sure that we do our utmost to see that research continues into clinical treatment as well as prevention and also into saving lives. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, how may taxpayers fined by the Australian Taxation Office for making mistakes on their tax returns used the Taxpack? Is it not a fact that the tax commissioner pledged that no honest mistakes made using the Taxpack would be subjected to fines? Isn't it also a fact that tens of thousands of the taxpayers who have been fined were using the Taxpack, and that in many instances the ATO has no way of knowing whether or not they were entitled to the protection of the tax commissioner's pledge?

—In answer to the question, there are, I am advised, nearly three million taxpayers who self‐assess. I am also advised that fewer than 10,000 returns are adjusted, and of these around 3,000 are penalised. So the tax commissioner stands by his guarantee that taxpayers who follow the Taxpack will not be charged a penalty for honest mistakes. I have to say that, despite the newspaper headlines, my understanding is that there is no evidence that this guarantee is not being properly applied. For example, in many of these self‐prepared cases, a penalty was applied because people had not followed Taxpack and had missed important information. The special taxation adviser to the Ombudsman has also confirmed the commissioner's position, saying a check of his database has not revealed any case of complaints about Taxpack `96 which involve an allegation that penalties have been applied in contradiction to the commissioner's guarantee.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What is the government's estimate of its refund liability as a consequence of these errors? Will the forgone interest revenue also be repaid to taxpayers in keeping with the tax office's practice of charging interest when repayments are made to the tax office?

—I think that classically illustrates the problem of having a supplementary question prepared before you have actually heard the answer. I think that is the problem, Senator Conroy: if you had listened more carefully to the answer you would not have raised that supplementary question. The substance of the answer went to the guarantee that the commissioner made and the commissioner stands by the guarantee that taxpayers who follow Taxpack will not be charged a penalty for honest mistakes.
—What are you talking about?

—Look, Lurch, you have not listened to the answer either. I have explained in great detail; even someone like you, I would have thought, would have absorbed that. It is a problem. Senator Conroy, who did not listen carefully to the answer that was given, gets up and asks a supplementary question that does not follow. (Time expired)

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, concerns the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, organised by Mr Beazley and Mr Fahey, the last instalment of which is not payable until mid‐November. Is the minister aware that the Commonwealth Bank shares are currently trading at a price 50 per cent higher than the price the government will receive for them in two weeks? Is the minister is concerned about this miscalculation by the department: the fact that it has cost Australian taxpayers $2.5 billion—that is the windfall gain transferred from the public ownership of 18 million Australians to the private ownership of 400,000 Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question from Senator Stott Despoja. Senator, you are quite right: the initiation of the sale of the Commonwealth Bank was a Labor Party initiative. When campaigning in 1987 I was attacked verbally by some Labor Party people who suggested that the coalition in government would be the type of government which would sell the Commonwealth Bank. Of course, events and Australian history show that in fact it was initially a Labor Party initiative.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Bank sale, like the Telstra sale, was widely welcomed by the public. I make a habit of not making comments on particular stocks—I think you would understand the reason for that—but the fact of the matter is share prices depend on a variety of things. Again, we make no apology, and I am sure the Labor Party makes no apology, for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I am just wondering whether the minister thinks it is appropriate or moral that one of the first decisions of the bank at its post‐privatisation AGM will be to give the CEO a 52 per cent pay increase to $1.32 million when the bank has slashed 10,000 staff—that is a quarter of its staff—and closed 400 branches since privatisation began back in 1992. Does the minister think that is appropriate? Minister, do you agree that the winners out of privatisation are always the minority of Australians who can afford to buy shares, or the foreign investors and the managers of former public enterprises, and that the losers are always the rest of the population who do not have the money to buy shares?

—One of the main features of a privatisation efficiently carried out is that it encourages greater efficiencies in the Australian economy. In that way it benefits all Australians. There are certainly budgetary effects, which I have explained to Senator Allison, which are positive. That is another way that all Australians benefit. Matters such as those you have raised will be matters for the shareholders to comment on. Undoubtedly, if the bank performs poorly there will be some strong comments by the shareholders at annual meetings. This government believes in restraint in salaries and wages. That is a view that this government has held and it is a view that I am happy to put today. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—During debate on 22 October 1997 on an answer to a question relating to information technology outsourcing, suggestions were made that the debate was out of order because that subject would soon be reported on by a standing committee. The Deputy President pointed out that there is no rule of the Senate that matters which are before standing committees may not be canvassed in debate. Reference was made to standing orders 72 and 73, but those standing orders relate to questions and prevent only questions referring to proceedings in committee of the whole not reported to the Senate and questions to chairs of committees which anticipate committees' reports. Senator Watson then asked the Deputy President to check whether any matters raised in the debate disclosed material contained in the draft report of the committee. I am advised that the secretary of the committee has examined the Hansard of the debate and that there was nothing in the debate which disclosed the content of the draft report of the committee.
