TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time on 25 September, Senator Brown asked the then Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services a question concerning the Jetset parliamentarians' travel contract. I now have answers to Senator Brown's questions. A copy has been provided to Senator Brown's office and I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE OF SENATOR BROWN TO SENATOR KEMP REPRESENTING THE MINISTER FOR ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES ON 25 SEPTEMBER 1997
Minister, firstly, will the government make the contract with Jetset public so that we can see whether there are to be real earnings or whether it is a matter of shuffling figures?
What was the cost of the tender process?
What is the duration of the contract?
What was the cost of refurbishment of Senate office space for Jetset?
What is the cost of rental for the Senate office space?
Have there been any teething problems with the contract and have any Members of Parliament missed planes or been inconvenienced by the arrangements?
Will the government meet the same standards of public sector accountability as in New Zealand where such contracts are made available except for a schedule of costs?
Response of Senator Minchin, Special Minister of State:
No,the contract will not be made public as it contains information which if revealed could seriously compromise the commercial interests of Jetset.

A number of the former Department of Administrative Services staff were involved in negotiations with Jetset over a period of months but this was within the course of their normal work. Legal costs of $63,073.35 were also incurred in negotiating a final contract with the successful tenderer.
The contract runs for three years with options for two one‐year extensions.

I am advised that the only refurbishment charged to the Senate was for painting and carpet which cost $3,870. The room was due for routine refurbishment irrespective of any proposal to levy a charge for the space. Equipment and furniture has been provided by Jetset.

The Joint House Department is charging Jetset a general service charge at a commercial rate which is in line with the rental for other space in Parliament House being used by commercial organisations. The rental is similar to those assessed as appropriate for other parts of the building by the Australian Valuation Office.

There have been teething problems with some travellers inconvenienced by the fact that electronic ticketing is not yet available through travel agents such as Jetset. As the then Minister for Administration Services advised Senators and Members in a circular dated 22 September 1997, it is expected this facilities will become available to travel agents by March next year. There have been other issues raised and these has been addressed through the Customer Forum on which both Senators and Members of the House of Representatives are represented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to questions without notice asked today, relating to nursing homes.
Senators may well have noticed on Saturday in the Sydney Morning Herald there was a letter that said:

Most ministers seem to be incapable of providing direct answers to direct questions and many are unable to formulate answers that demonstrate a logical progression of ideas. When faced with a question for which they have no immediate answer, or which requires only a brief answer, members seem compelled, nonetheless, to waste the entire answer time on tiresome, juvenile point‐scoring. Some of them even seem to think that this is clever.

When this matter was drawn to the attention of Labor Party senators this morning, an attempt was made to organise a sweep to try to determine which minister this correspondence was referring to. The problem was, we could not get anyone who was prepared to back any other senator but Herron.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you please use the senator's proper title.

—Minister Herron is the minister who seems to be totally unable to answer even the most basic of questions and who is totally unable to draw up even the most simple responsibilities in terms of his role in this Senate. It was of some surprise to all of us that, when it came to the issue of ministerial arrangements after the last reshuffle, Senator Herron had no ministerial responsibilities other than what we have heard before. Of course, we know exactly why that is the case. It is extraordinary that, by comparison, he makes Senator Newman look very good in her job.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen today is a simple question from Senator McKiernan which could not be answered. Again we were told, `We must come back with the detail.' There was a simple question from Senator Faulkner: `What does this government mean by mutual obligation?' Again, no answer. Even when it came to slithering out of this chamber on the question of the miserable backdowns that they have announced today, this minister could not get it right. We have very simple propositions that have been announced in the other chamber, yet this minister is unable to communicate them effectively to this chamber.

The slithering that we are seeing on this issue reflects a government in complete disarray. It is a government incapable of facing up to some of the basic implications of the policy that they have announced. You have a right to expect that ministers be able to answer simple questions. After all, it was this government that took $500 million out of the aged care budget. It was this government that introduced legislation with an effective starting date of 1 October. It is this government whose policy has thrown the aged care and nursing home industry into complete disarray.

You would expect that the ministers would be able to answer simple questions. Instead, what have we heard? Last week, in response to a question from Senator Denman on prudential funds and the use of payments to those funds, the minister said:
. . . I would be happy to supply an answer to the points which Senator Denman brought forward.

In response to Senator West, on the question of the sale of the family home and involving children who are part‐time carers for aged parents, we were told once again, `We are happy to look at that,' and `We will get back to Senator West.' We have also been told, `We will get back to you,' with other figures requested and, `I will let you know the outcome in due course.' In response to Senator Gibbs, who asked a question with regard to the $100,000 up‐front entry fee bonds we were told:
. . . I will produce the detail of that answer for Senator Gibbs . . . I will come back with a definitive answer to all those questions that were asked in the supplementary.

In response to Senator McKiernan with regard to the tax rebate on accommodation bonds, again the Senate was told that the minister would get back to Senator McKiernan with factual answers to that question because, `I am not familiar with all the details of sections that he referred to in that act.'

That is at the heart of this question. This is a government and a minister that seem unfamiliar with the basic facts. They are unfamiliar with the distress that are being caused to many aged people in this country. This government seems unfamiliar with the consequences of its disastrous policy. The announcement it has made today will not stop the real outrage that is being experienced right throughout this community as a result of this government's actions in attacking aged persons in this community. We have a government that seems oblivious of the harm and the social damage that it is doing to people who have got a right to expect support from this government and a right to expect support from the community as they move into the final stages of their lives. This is a government that seems unfamiliar with the facts, and this is a minister who is unfamiliar with the facts, in regard to their responsibilities to this chamber. This is a government that ought to be condemned for the actions it has taken. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we stand again—aged care ad infinitum. Once again the Australian Labor Party has demonstrated that they are not prepared to hear the good news. What we have today is nothing more than political scaremongering and grandstanding. Some of the very issues that you have raised here today have been addressed by the Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith. But do you give any consideration to those? No, you don't. Nursing homes are in a state of disrepair and their funding is on an unsustainable economic footing. Today your shadow minister, Jenny Macklin, said herself that the nursing home sector was in a desperate state. Let us have a look at why that might be the case. The ALP when in government reduced capital funding to nursing homes by 75 per cent between 1992‐93 and 1995‐96. It cut funding by 75 per cent; yet you have the audacity to raise this issue again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government deliberately ran down the nursing home sector. Professor Bob Gregory told you in 1985 that $125 million was needed every year to upgrade nursing homes. The reality is that our nursing home sector is not a dignified place for many old people. We have heard many times about the fire standards that are not being met, about the health standards that are not being met and about the cramped living conditions in nursing homes. However, today the Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith, has said this:

Clearly there has been rising concern in the community about elements of the reforms. Much of this concern is totally unfounded and is the product of one of the most outrageous scare campaigns this country has ever seen. There has been an extraordinarily cynical and irresponsible manipulation of older people's fears by the Labor Party, without regard for the consequences.

I would like to demonstrate for the Senate some of the excellent changes that have been announced today. These changes will eliminate some anomalies that have become apparent and will protect existing nursing home residents and hostel residents. Under the changes announced by the minister, income testing will be deferred until 1 March 1998 and will only apply to new residents entering care on or after that date. Residents in care before 1 March 1998 will not pay higher income tested fees. For the purposes of income testing for nursing home and hostel benefits, assets gifted prior to 20 August 1996—an issue that the opposition has been raising—will not be taken into account.

The existing hardship provisions will be extended to protect carers who have been caring for two or more years—down from five years—and residents who were in hostels prior to 1 October 1997, when the new arrangements commenced, and who were affected by this change to the daily fee will have their fees reduced to the level they were paying before 1 October. Hostel providers will be compensated by a new supplement paid by the government to all residents in care prior to 1 October. You are looking very pleased, Senator Bishop, as well you might.

In relation to accommodation bonds, while they have worked well for hostels—they were introduced by the ALP, I have to remind everyone—people will have other choices if they are entering nursing homes. Our package of reforms has always included a number of alternatives to the lodgment of an up‐front bond, and these are particularly important to nursing home residents. It is just a shame the opposition has failed to highlight any of these and once again has been relying on scare tactics. These options allow people to pay periodically or pay their accommodation contribution from their estate if that is their preference. These options remain, and the government will listen to other suggestions about how this contribution can be made over the coming weeks. Have you heard that? The government will listen to other suggestions. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The unnecessary and unfair changes to aged care policy that have brought fear and confusion to our elderly over the last several weeks culminated this weekend with the withdrawal of two elderly people from a nursing home because they believed they could no longer afford to pay. These two elderly people left their place of care after receiving notification of the increase in fees and what the new daily charges would be. One can only assume that these two people are the tip of the iceberg when it comes to confusion and fear within the community regarding the recent changes announced by this government. This is a shameful indictment on this government and its representatives here in the Senate. Its handling illustrates either a callous disregard for the elderly or a high level of incompetence by the government—probably both.

BREAK.PARA: The changes by this government will mean that pensioners requiring nursing home care will be means tested and could see daily fees increase from $21 to around $60. The changes, however, do not stop there. Pensioners will be required to sell their homes to pay up‐front bonds and entry fees. this is an attack on one of Australia's oldest traditions—the tradition of home ownership and of security. No longer will Australians be able to pass their family home on to their children. It will now be sold to buy health care; health care that under previous governments was provided on a needs basis, not a cost basis.

Why have these changes been championed by the government? It is because they ripped $500 million from aged care in the last budget and will be using it for pork‐barrelling come election time. This government should forget that election pork‐barrelling, put the $500 million back into aged care and remove the fear and confusion that they have generated in our elderly community. It is indisputable that there has been a public outcry against these government changes. Yet what has been the government's response? The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said in Hobart several weeks ago that these changes were `fair, defensible and equitable.' Fair they most certainly are not. There is nothing fair about two elderly Australians leaving their nursing home because information from the government allowed them to believe that they could no longer afford proper care.

This policy has been anything but defensible, with the government and in particular the minister and his representatives in this chamber lurching from one embarrassing gaffe to another—one poor and confusing explanation of the changes to another. Is it any wonder that electorate offices like mine have been inundated with calls from elderly people asking for some explanation of what the changes mean and what type of care they will be able to afford in the future?

`Equitable' is also a word that I would not have used to describe these changes. What is equitable about care provided on ability to pay as opposed to need? Equitable is not a term that creates a two‐tiered system. Under one system those with little income and moderate house value will be placed in a nursing home with fewer resources and capital expenditure. Under a second system those fortunate enough to have the money will have access to top levels of care. I do not deny these people this high level of care; I simply believe that it should be accessible to all.
The Prime Minister did not stop with comments regarding the fairness and defensibility of these charges. The Sydney Morning Herald went on to quote the Prime Minister as saying in his party room:
. . . the policy would be a test of his political resolve, declaring in the joint party room the government could not afford to backdown because it would appear to be weak.

I anticipate that there will be an embarrassing backdown by the Prime Minister. That is his nature—he boldly strikes out with budget cuts, regresses policy changes and leaves his ministers to explain the policy and cop the flak and then he sacks them and amends the policy to save face. In the area of aged care he has done it again with the new minister. He has done it in other areas with Ms Moylan and Amanda Vanstone and he is doing it now with this minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone.

—Senator Vanstone. The Prime Minister and his government, egged on by a backbench that had no anticipation of the public outcry, have argued that there is no easy solution to this issue of aged care provision in an increasingly older society. The Labor Party believes that putting back the $500 million they ripped off would be a solid beginning. The government will reject this while it contemplates a range of options that may be pursued to placate the public—a range of minor options and a range of cosmetic changes. While this contemplation takes place the Prime Minister will continue to send a minister into this chamber and into the community to defend the indefensible. In the end, however, it will have the same conclusion—an embarrassing back down by the Prime Minister, who knows how to do it best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this issue again, as I did on Thursday. On Thursday I said that I wanted to try to put a bit of balance into this particular debate and to look at the real facts in nursing care and where the government was coming from. It is very important that we do that if we are going to be fair and square about this and do justice to aged people. We certainly have not heard that yet from those on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that I make following on from what I said on Thursday—and has been said by others—is that the financially disadvantaged will not be affected. There are a number of beds being kept for those people—in hostels it is 23 per cent and in nursing homes it is a minimum of 27 per cent.

The second point I made was that people entering nursing homes do not have to sell their homes. But you need to look at where the government had to come from. On Thursday I mentioned the $10 billion deficit and the actions that had to be taken by a responsible coalition government. Let us look specifically at nursing care homes and the situation that existed. In nursing homes some 40 per cent of residents share their bedroom with four or more people; 13 per cent of homes do not meet fire regulations; and 11 per cent of homes do not meet health regulations. That has all come from the mess that we were left by the previous government.

It is worth nothing that during that time Labor cut funding on capital expenditure—hence some of the problems that I have just outlined. In 1992‐93 it was $45 million. In 1995‐96 this had dropped to $10.7 million—a 75 per cent reduction from that $45 million. And this occurred while the current leader of the Labor Party, Mr Beazley, was finance minister. So those on the other side cannot just wipe their hands clean and suddenly pretend that this problem has arrived here today. It has not. It has been inherited and it has got to be fixed.

The final point I make before I get to some of the responses from our Minister for Family Services, Mr Warwick Smith, is that the government will deliver over $1.5 billion for upgrade to nursing homes and associated activities over the next 10 years. The important fact that comes into this is that we have seen from the minister, as I have said, and as has been highlighted by a previous speaker Senator Synon, there are some very significant changes being made to address some of the issues that have come out of this.

Equally important, the minister has announced in his statement that he will continue to consult and listen to the users and the wider community. There are a number of matters that I, myself, for example—and I am sure others—will want to raise with the minister nonetheless—accreditation just to give one example. Another issue that I will be raising with him will be the three‐year term for accreditation. It was pointed out to me over the weekend, for example, that this was an issue that was going to cause a number of concerns to a number of nursing homes. I have no doubt that the minister will deal with these issues as they are brought forward as we attempt to address the deterioration that has occurred in nursing homes.
I want to touch on a number of matters which are very important. On the introduction of income test subsidies the minister's statement says:

Income testing will be deferred until 1 March 1998 and it will apply only to new residents entering care on or after that date. Residents in care before 1 March 1998 will not pay higher income tested fees.
For the purpose of income testing for nursing home and hostel benefits, assets gifted prior to 20 August 1996, shall not be taken into account.

Who introduced that particular policy with regard to hostels? It was the previous government under the then Prime Minister Mr Keating. It is your policy, no‐one else's. You need to remember these things when you get up and carry on and scare the elderly in our community. The statement goes on:

Residents who were in hostels prior to 1 October 1997, when the new arrangements commenced, and who were affected by this change, will have their fees reduced to the level they were paying before 1 October. Hostel providers will be compensated . . .
So it will not effect them. But it will give those people, prior to 1 October, relief from that particular provision. It continues:
These measures will maintain the pre-existing rules for existing residents . . .
I must emphasise this: the pre-existing rules will be maintained for existing residents.

BREAK.PARA: In the remaining few seconds I have, I re-emphasise that the minister's statement highlights the fact that, as other issues come forward in connection with this particular matter, we will deal with them on their merits. But at the end of the day, we believe that we will end up with a much better and much stronger nursing home regime. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding further, I must say that the two government senators who so far this afternoon have dealt with this matter have done a reasonable job of defending, basically, the indefensible. In fact, the job they were given to do here this afternoon was to defend basically smelly policies that, really, no-one could stand on the stump and defend outside of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I will look with great interest to see how many government backbenchers will go and stand on the stump out there in front of the pensioners and tell them that this latest episode of pensioner bashing is all illusory—that they have not done anything to pensioners; that they have not done anything to people going into nursing homes; that, indeed, they have not done anything to their families; and that, at the end of the day, it is all the fault of the Labor Party. In fact, I reckon that one will go down pretty well at some of the pensioner meetings around town; I think they will find that particularly difficult.

The smart government backbenchers have already climbed onto the ropes, while the ship is tied up at the wharf, and are sliding down them at a rate of knots. There are a couple from South Australia in the other place who represent fairly aged communities—one, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus); and the other, who I imagine will be joining her shortly, the member for Makin (Mrs Draper), who is not quite as smart as the member for Hindmarsh. But at the end of the day, with their electorates having large numbers of aged people, they know damn well they are being hurt by this policy.

I was interested today to hear the way in which the Senate was told of significant changes. It was done by the minister, in response to an opposition question, with an absolute contempt for the whole set‐up, which is the way in which he has handled this debate over the last couple of weeks. While the minister told of these significant changes, I listened with a great deal of interest.

In essence, what the government have done with these particular proposals is three things. The first thing they did was to bring in the uncapped bond. We have not heard much about that this afternoon, and I will come back to it in a moment. Another thing they did in the last couple of budgets as to take $500 million out of this area. The third thing they are proposing to do, now that they have delayed it for an extra five or six months, is to whack up the charges associated with nursing home care.

Dealing with those three things in reverse order, what they told us here this afternoon was that they are going to put the fees off until next year, and it will not apply as universally as it did before—and for this, I guess they are to be congratulated; at least to that extent they have listened. Then they tell us that a few of the other provisions in there, some of the things which really do have a lot of aged persons very concerned, will also be delayed until next year.

But I was waiting for the Moran clause. I was waiting to hear something about the bond that is being charged for this. When I put the telly on yesterday morning and I saw the Sunday Program, I saw one of the pieces of humanity there who really did not do very much for me. I wanted to record that segment of film and send it out to every member of the Labor Party in South Australia and say, `This is why you are paying your fees: to protect the community from the likes of this person.'

I never heard anything today, not a word, announcing that the old bond is going to be changed, or delayed, or any of the rest of it. You see, they cannot do that because that is at the very heart of this matter. This is the payola to people who have paid them through the bad years, the 13 years. I have no doubt that the bloke who was on TV yesterday probably was one of the main architects of this particular system. If he was not, then I have to say this: he is doing pretty well out of what someone else thought up; he is doing extremely well.

We were told here last week by the minister that this particular man should be commended. He is a self-made man. He has made lots of money in his life. Well, he is making it over the bones of a lot of frail and elderly people. That is the sort of stuff we on this side will not be tolerating. Yes, there is a problem in the nursing homes. It will grow as the age of the population grows. But it has not been made any better by all of these supposed changes for the better. It will not be made any better if they persist with these changes. And I will make one further prediction: I bet before long there will be a few more changes around town too because, at the end of the day, when you come across a piece of dog dirt on the pavement, like this policy is, then you know it for what it is. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said the other day and, I am sure, will be said again: the real issue in this matter needing to be addressed is the state of nursing homes and the need to provide good care for the elderly people of Australia. The fact of the matter is that the greying of Australia is a reality. The number of people who are over 65 will grow by 48 per cent over the next 20 years—or so it has been estimated—and there is a real need to provide good nursing home care for these people.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said today, but I just repeat for emphasis: the nursing homes of Australia, on average, are of very poor quality. Forty per cent of nursing home residents share their bedroom with four or more people. Thirteen per cent of homes do not meet fire regulations; and 11 per cent of homes do not meet health regulations. There is a need—and there is no doubt or dispute about it—to improve the standards of nursing homes, and the government has set out to do that.

In dealing with this issue the ALP has engaged in an outrageous campaign of scare tactics which has put fear into the hearts of the very elderly people of Australia at a very vulnerable time in their lives when they face final illnesses, are unable to look after themselves and need to go into nursing homes.

I will pick up a couple of points that Senator Bishop and Senator Quirke have made. Senator Quirke talked about the government reducing funding to nursing homes. I point out that the Labor Party cut funding on capital expenditure for nursing homes by a figure representing 75 per cent. In the 1992-93 budget, $45 million was available to nursing homes for capital purposes. In the 1995-96 budget this had dropped to $10.7 million. That is a cut of 75 per cent. So, if anybody is cutting funding to nursing homes, the Senate should be quite clear who is doing it. It is not this government; it was the ALP.

This government—the Howard government—with its reforms will deliver over $1.5 billion over the next 10 years to upgrade nursing homes and that will mean improved comfort, safety, privacy and dignity to older Australians. If anybody can take credit for having sought to improve the standards of nursing homes, it is the Howard government. If anybody deserves criticism for consolidating the pitiful standard of nursing homes by cutting the funding available for capital works, it was the previous government. That just underlines the hypocrisy of the whole case that they have been making about this issue.

Another important thing to be understood is that less than 10 per cent of people in residential care are non‐pensioners. So the whole question of accommodation bonds only applies to that 10 per cent. Even given that 10 per cent may have to pay accommodation bonds, there are other alternatives available to these people. They can make instalment payments each month or fortnightly, they can pay a combination of up-front fees and instalments or they can defer payment to be taken out of their estate following death.

This whole question of bonds only applies to 10 per cent and the other 90 per cent of people are pensioners. In fact, the government subsidises pensioners to a very large extent in nursing homes. For example, the government pays a subsidy of $31,000 per annum for nursing home care for a full pensioner, it pays $29,700 per annum for a part‐pensioner and even in the case of non‐pensioners—these people who are being asked to pay accommodation bonds—the government pays a subsidy of some $24,700 towards their care.

The truth of the matter is very different from the way it has been presented by the opposition. The truth of the matter is that the government is addressing the problem of providing better standards of care for our aged in nursing homes. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time last Thursday I offered to seek further information in relation to questions from Senator McKiernan and Senator Ray in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. I now seek leave to have this information incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
SENATOR MCKIERNAN asked-Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Family Services, without notice, on 23 October 1997:

(1) Can the Minister confirm that, on the ruling IT 261, a medical expense rebate can be claimed for fees paid to nursing homes? Can the Minister also confirm that, under ruling TR 93/14, a medical expense rebate can be claimed for fees paid to hostels where a personal care subsidy is paid for the person?
(2) Will older Australians be able to claim the medical expenses rebate for the accommodation bonds and income tested daily fees they now have to pay to get the care they need?
(3) Do the savings estimates for the introduction of accommodation bonds and income tested daily fees take the increased taxation expenditure on the medical expenses rebate into account?
SENATOR HERRON—The answer to the Senator's question is as follows:

(1) It is correct to say that under taxation ruling IT 261 fees paid by residents to nursing homes approved under the National Health Act 1953 did qualify as rebatable medical expenses. It is also true that under taxation ruling TR 93/14 fees paid by a resident to a hostel approved under the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954 qualified as a rebatable medical expense if the hostel was paid a personal care subsidy for the resident.

(2) Residential Care services formerly approved under the National Health Act 1953 and Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954 are now approved under the Aged Care Act 1977. The Senator's question on the status of charges paid under that Act has been referred to the Australian Taxation Office for an opinion and I will provide the answer as soon as possible.
(3) The savings estimates for the introduction of accommodation bonds and income tested daily fees did not include an estimate of increased taxation expenditure on the medical expenses rebate.
Senator Ray on Thursday 23 October asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, Senator Herron:

Can you confirm that, in order to appease the coalition backbench, the government is contemplating allocating $4 million for an advertising campaign to sell its introduction of entry bonds and daily charges for nursing homes? Will the Department of Health and Family Services consult the Office of Government Information and Advertising in relation to that decision? Will you guarantee that that contract for the campaign will be decided through a competitive tendering process without any political interference—novel though this concept may be to some of your government colleagues?
RESPONSE
I am advised by the Minister for Family Services that the Government is not contemplating spending $4 million on an advertising campaign relating to aged care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned request the Australian Senate implements the following:
A Senate enquiry into the use of genetic engineering in the Australian Food Supply, including the ethics of its use.
That consultations be undertaken with the general public to ask us if we want this technology in our food supply and consent to its use.
That consumers be resourced to attend these consultations.
Any food that is genetically engineered or contains components that are genetically engineered are required to be labelled, including the origin of the genes.
That meaningful right to know legislation be enacted to guarantee public access to toxicology data.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation of Postgraduate Scholarships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government recognise that taxing scholarships will:
(a) jeopardise links between universities and industry;
(b) increase the costs of scholarships resulting in few scholarships or scholarships of less value; and
(c) represents another attack on the education sector; and
Calls on the Government to ensure that any changes to the regulations or legislation governing the taxation of postgraduate scholarships maintain the tax exempt status of these scholarships.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Stott Despoja(from seven citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide composting and soil remineralisation programs, and the planting of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promotes Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned residents of the State of Tasmania draws to the attention of the Senate the adverse impact on students of:
(1) Federal Government cuts to:

PARA.TAB: (a) Austudy;
(b) University Funding.

PETITION.PARA: (2) Federal Government increases in the Higher Education Contribution Scheme; and
(3) the Federal Government's mismanagement of the Austudy Actual Means Test.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to take action to address student and parent concerns.

PETITION.TITLE: Cassini Space Probe
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government take all measures possible to bring about the halt to the launch on 6 October 1997 of the Cassini Space Probe from Cape Canaveral containing 72.3 pounds of plutonium‐238 because:
(a) it is irresponsible to undertake experiments with significant dangers to the world's population; and
(b) there are no guarantees that an accident will not happen; and
(c) if there is an accident;

PARA.TAB: (i) millions of lives on earth will be endangered through exposure to plutonium; and
(ii) the nuclear material will impact on the entire planet for thousands of years.

I also table statements of reasons justifying the need for these bills to be considered during this sittings and seek leave to have the statements incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—
CHILD CARE PAYMENTS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
The passage of Child Care Payments (Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 is necessary to give effect to provisions in the Child Care Payments Bill.

The Child Care Payments Bill will allow for the introduction of new payment arrangements through the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency. It will also allow for the following budget measures to be implemented from January 1998:
reform of subsidies for school age care;
a limit on Childcare assistance of 20 hours for non work related care;
introduction of a new planning system for centre based long day care places; and
introduction of immunisation as a criterion for eligibility for fee subsidies.

The Child Care Payments Bill was tabled in the Winter sittings. As the two Bills are closely inter-related and the passage of one impacts on the other it is proposed that both Bills be debated cognately.

If the Transition Bill is not passed in the Spring sittings it will not be possible to introduce the changes from 1 January 1998, as has been announced. This would have a substantial financial impact, and would create considerable concern in the community.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Family Services, the Hon. Judi Moylan, MP)
NATIONAL ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION MEASURES (IMPLEMENTATION) BILL 1997

The proposed Bill is to provide for the implementation of national environment protection measures (NEPMs) in respect of certain activities carried on by or on behalf of the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities, and for related purposes.

The Commonwealth is obliged under the Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment to implement NEPMs. Such implementation is dependent on having the legislation in place. National environment protection measures are being developed for ambient air standards and for the National Pollutant Inventory (NPI). It is envisaged that the NPI NEPM will be finalised by the National Environment Protection Council (NEPC) by February 1998. If agreed, the NEPM is intended to have immediate effect and this Bill is intended to implement that on the Commonwealth's part.

If the Bill has not been passed and administrative arrangements for implementation have not been finalised by the time a NEPM comes into force, the States and Territories may perceive this as indicative of a lack of commitment by the Commonwealth to the NEPC/NEPM model of development of national environmental standards. Some States have indicated that agreement to finalise the NPI will not be given if the Commonwealth has not finalised its NEPM implementation mechanism. The Government attaches a high priority to the development of national environment protection measures and to the cooperative arrangements with the States and Territories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Effect of not being dealt with in the Spring sittings

SPEECH.PARA: If the Bill is not passed in the Spring sittings, the Commonwealth would not be able to commence implementation of the NEPM which is expected to be finalised by February 1998. This could be perceived by the States and Territories as a lack of commitment by the Commonwealth to the national environment protection measures process.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for the Environment)
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PARENTING AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill will give effect to a number of measures announced in the 1997 Budget, namely, to amend the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 to cover payments not currently included in the program to streamline the administration of the program, introduce a parenting payment to replace sole parent pension and parenting allowance, reform the child disability allowance, extend the period of the income test for the low income Health Care Card from four to eight weeks and apply consistent hardship rules to waiting periods.
The Bill needs to be introduced and passed in the 1997 Spring Sittings to ensure that there is sufficient time to:
finalise any necessary computer processing system and administrative arrangements to facilitate implementation of the measures contained in the Bill; and
prepare and disseminate to the community detailed information about the changes, particularly concerning people who may be affected by the changes.
(Circulated with the authority of Minister for Social Security)
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX (MEMBERS OF CONSTITUTIONALLY PROTECTED SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX (MEMBERS OF CONSTITUTIONALLY PROTECTED SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) IMPOSITION BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX IMPOSITION AMENDMENT BILL 1997
TERMINATION PAYMENTS TAX IMPOSITION AMENDMENT BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS AND TERMINATION PAYMENTS TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Purpose of the proposed Bills: To ensure that the surcharge can be applied to certain superannuation schemes operated by the States. The Bills also provide for amendments of a consequential and administrative nature to the package of superannuation contributions surcharge legislation.
Reasons for urgency: It is necessary to have the relevant legislation introduced and passed during the Spring sittings of Parliament as the first reporting date for the surcharge is 15 December 1997.

Result if the proposed Bills are not dealt with in the Spring Sittings: The exclusion of any significant group of taxpayers (members of constitutionally protected State superannuation schemes) would seriously undermine the equity credentials of the surcharge. The absence of the minor amendments would adversely impact on the efficient administration of this revenue measure.
(Circulated by authority of the Assistant Treasurer)
SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) AMENDMENT BILL 1997
Amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SIS Act) to:—

allow superannuation funds 60 days, or such further period as the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (the Commissioner) allows, from the date they came into existence to elect to become regulated under the SIS Act;
provide the Commissioner with a discretion to extend the time limit for superannuation funds established prior to the commencement of the SIS Act to elect to be regulated under the SIS Act;

allow superannuation funds 28 days, or such further period as the Commissioner allows, from the date of a notice from the Commissioner to rectify an invalid election to be regulated under the SIS Act; and
provide the Commissioner with a discretion to extend the time limit for superannuation funds to be wound up.
The amendments will take effect retrospectively from 1 July 1996.

Without the amendments, particular superannuation funds will not be complying superannuation funds for taxation purposes and members of these funds potentially face losses due to the loss of taxation concessions. This has led to substantial regulatory uncertainty for the industry. Over 3,000 superannuation funds are affected by this problem.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Effect if the Bill is not dealt with in one Sitting

SPEECH.PARA: The status of certain superannuation funds as complying superannuation funds under the Superan nuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 will be in doubt until these amendments are made.
(Circulated by authority of the Treasurer)
SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT 1997
(SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX) BILL 1997

Purpose of the proposed Bill: To amend the Superannuation Act 1976, Superannuation Act 1990, Defence Act 1903, Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991, Governor-General Act 1974, Judges Pensions Act 1968, Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, Law Officers Act 1964 and Superannuation Contributions Tax (Application to the Commonwealth Reductions of Benefits) Act 1997, to provide for the reduction of benefits payable to higher income earners who are members of superannuation schemes for Parliamentarians and Commonwealth employees where a surcharge debt has been assessed.

Reason for urgency: It is necessary to have the proposed Bill introduced and passed in the Spring Sittings of Parliament to provide trustees for some of the Commonwealth's schemes to enable the reporting of surchargeable contributions by 15 December 1997 in accordance with the requirements of the Surcharge Legislation.

Results if the proposed Bill is not dealt with in the Spring Sittings: The exclusion of any significant group of taxpayers (members of some of the Commonwealth's schemes including the Parliamentary Scheme) would seriously undermine the equity credentials of the surcharge.

Reasons why amendments were not foreseen: These amendments arise from Government amendments to the Surcharge Legislation and legal advice on the application of the surcharge in the Commonwealth's schemes.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Finance)

KERRY O'BRIEN
LABOR SENATOR FOR TASMANIA
23 October 1997
Senator the Hon Richard Alston
Minister Representing the Minister for
Transport and Regional Development
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Alston

You will be aware that my notice of motion No. 752, relating to the awarding of a consultancy contract to ACIL Economics, will again be listed for discovery of formal business the next day of sitting.
In your statement today you made a claim of public interest immunity for some of the documents referred to in my notice.
So that the claim can be considered before the notice comes up again, I would appreciate your clarification of the following aspects of your statement.

Before proceeding to those aspects, I indicate that I wish the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business to approach parties to the tendering process to seek their agreement to the release of documents involving a comparative assessment of bidders, as your statement indicated that he would, so that those documents can be presented on the next day of sitting.

In relation to the report referred to in paragraph (b) in the notice, what is the basis of the claim that the report is commercial‐in‐confidence? As you would be aware, such a claim must be based on a belief that disclosure of the document would cause damage to the commercial interests of the Commonwealth or others.

What is the nature of the damage to be apprehended? The fact that a document is a Cabinet document, of course, does not prevent the government disclosing the document if it so chooses. What is the nature of the damage to relations with the states to be apprehended from disclosure of the document? Why cannot the agreement of the states to the disclosure of the report be sought? What is the nature of the danger to the physical safety to a person or persons to be apprehended from disclosure of the report?

In relation to part (d) of the notice, what is the nature of the damage to commercial interests apprehended by disclosure of the list of organisations contacted by ACIL Economics? What is the nature of the danger to the physical safety to persons apprehended by disclosure of the list?
The same questions apply to the list referred to in part (e) of the notice.
Your response to these questions would be appreciated by close of business tomorrow.
Yours sincerely
Kerry O'Brien
Senator for Tasmania
SENATOR THE HON RICHARD ALSTON
Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts
Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate
24 October 1997
Senator Kerry O'Brien
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 23 October 1997 concerning your notice of motion No 752 and the tabling of documents relating to two consultancies awarded to ACIL Economics.

In response to your first request, I can advise you that the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has instructed his Department to seek, as a matter of priority, the agreement of the tenderers for the May 1996 consultancy to the tabling of the relevant documents. However, I should point out that while early consideration is being sought, given the privacy and confidentiality considerations, the material cannot be released until the parties agree. I am therefore unable to guarantee that any documents will be available for the Senate's next day of sitting. However, as soon as I am in a position to do so, I will inform you of the parties' responses.

The other matters raised in your letter would require me to divulge information contained within the ACIL report. As I have previously stated, that report is part of the deliberative process being undertaken by the Government in formulating its policies to achieve reform on the Australian waterfront.

As to relations with the States, again the discussions which took place were premised on strict confidentiality being observed. It would be damaging to prospects for reform if the States are not able to be confident in the confidential nature of their involvement in the reform process with the Commonwealth.

I also consider that the commercial interests of parties could be jeopardised if the contents of the report were to be released. Individuals and organisations who have a legitimate interest in the achievement of reform on the waterfront provided sensitive information to the consultant on the understanding that it would remain confidential. Their commercial interests could be adversely affected if they were identified. Future dealings between the Commonwealth and these parties would also be jeopardised if they did not have confidence that both the information they supplied and their identity would remain confidential. In some cases, individuals have expressed concern for their physical well being should they be identified.
For the reasons set out above, public interest immunity will continue to be claimed in relation to the information you have sought under parts (a), (b), (d) and (e) of motion No 752.
I will be forwarding a copy of this letter to Senator Harradine.
Yours sincerely
Richard Alston
Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts
