SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Madam President, this bill will amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the `SIS Act'). The SIS Act regulates the conduct of trustees of superannuation entities to ensure the prudent management of superannuation moneys.
The amendments to the SIS Act will improve the flexibility of legislative requirements relating to the nature and timing of elections by superannuation funds to be regulated under the SIS Act.

To be eligible to receive concessional taxation treatment a superannuation fund must elect to be regulated under the SIS Act. There are a number of steps involved in making an election including lodging a standard form with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and ensuring that the fund has a trustee that is a Constitutional corporation or that the sole or primary purpose of the fund is the provision of old‐age pensions.

There are strict time limits within which superannuation funds must elect to be regulated. A superannuation fund, established after the commencement of the SIS Act, must make an election to be regulated at the same time that it comes into existence or shortly after that day. A superannuation fund that was in existence prior to the commencement of the SIS Act must have elected to be regulated at the latest by the beginning of the fund's 1995‐96 year of income. A superannuation fund that was in the process of winding up after the commencement of its 1994‐95 year of income could continue to receive concessional taxation treatment without making an election to be regulated provided they were wound up by 1 July 1995.

Failure to elect within these strict time limits or to wind up by the prescribed date may result in the members of the fund suffering losses due to the removal of taxation concessions. In addition, given that there are a number of steps involved in making an election, a fund may inadvertently lodge a defective election. In this case, a fund is ineligible for taxation concessions until after they have made a valid election. This is despite the fact that the fund may have complied with the SIS Act and regulations in all respects apart from lodging a valid election.

The Commissioner previously dealt with the shortcomings in the election process by temporarily modifying the SIS Act under section 333. However, the Commissioner's temporary modification power expired on 1 July 1996. This bill amends the SIS Act to permanently reinstate the administrative flexibility which was previously achieved through the temporary modification declarations.

In particular, the amendments will confer a discretion on the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to extend the time within which the lodgment of an election must be made with the Commissioner and enable trustees to rectify inadvertently invalid elections. The amendments will also address restrictive timing requirements for funds established prior to the SIS regime or funds who were in the process of winding up. By overcoming these technical rigidities, the amendments will enable superannuation funds who would otherwise be deprived of concessional taxation treatment in certain years to obtain access to such treatment, without compromising the security of members' benefits or fund compliance with the retirement income standards.

It is intended that the amendments will take effect retrospectively from 1 July 1996 to ensure that the eligibility for taxation concessions for funds in the period prior to amendment is not jeopardised.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TRUST LOSS AND OTHER DEDUCTIONS) BILL 1997

The bill will insert rules in the income tax law to limit the circumstances in which trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses and debt deductions. The measures generally take effect from 9 May 1995.
The Government announced in the 1996‐97 Budget its intention to proceed with the previous Government's 1995‐96 Budget announcement on 9 May 1995 that trust loss rules would be introduced.
The Government has consulted widely with taxpayers and tax professionals in developing the trust loss legislation.

The Government announced in the 1996‐97 Budget that several significant changes would be made to the previous Government's draft legislation. Those changes were set out in a press release issued on Budget night.
Most of these changes were made in response to the concerns expressed by taxpayers and tax professionals about the previous Government's proposed legislation.

In announcing that it would go ahead with the measures, the Government committed itself to consulting widely with taxpayers and tax professionals before introducing legislation into the Parliament. To this end the Government's draft of the legislation was released for public comment on 10 February 1997.

A large number of submissions concerning the exposure draft were received. The Government has considered these submissions and has taken them into account in finalising the legislation. The Government has made many modifications to the measures in response to concerns raised in the submissions.

One of the main concerns raised was about the application of the income injection test to family trusts. In response to this concern the Government announced in the 1997‐98 Budget that it would relax the application of the income injection test for family trusts but the definition of family member would be narrowed from the 1997‐98 Budget time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Purpose of the trust loss measures

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the trust loss measures is to restrict the recoupment of losses and other deductions of trusts in order to prevent the transfer of the tax benefit of the losses. This occurs when a person who did not bear the economic effect of the loss when it was incurred by the trust obtains a benefit as a result of the trust's ability to deduct the loss.

The measures achieve this aim by examining whether there has been a change in underlying ownership or control of a trust or whether certain schemes have been entered into in order to take advantage of a trust's losses or other deductions.

The tax law already contains tests which limit the deductibility of losses incurred by companies. The proposed rules that are to apply to trusts will differ in some respects from those that apply to companies, reflecting the different characteristics of trusts.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Changes in ownership or control of a trust

SPEECH.PARA: The tests to be satisfied before losses are deductible will vary depending on the type of trust. Each type of trust has to satisfy certain tests relating to ownership or control of the trust in order to be able to deduct prior and current year losses and debt deductions.

For example, while fixed trusts will be subject to a continuity of ownership test, non‐family discretionary trusts will be subject to continuity of ownership, continuity of control and pattern of distributions tests. This reflects the fact that it is not possible to apply the same beneficial ownership test to discretionary trusts.

Special rules will also apply to widely held unit trusts so that ownership will be tested generally only where there are abnormal transactions. These rules will help to minimise compliance costs for these types of trust. Also, a listed widely held unit trust can apply the same business test if it fails the continuity of ownership test.

Special tracing rules are provided to overcome difficulties in monitoring ownership of trust interests where certain entities are interposed between the loss trust and the underlying beneficiaries. A special tracing rule applies for family trusts.

These tests do not apply to family trusts, some superannuation funds, deceased estates within a reasonable administration period and unit trusts with unit holders exempt from income tax. These trusts are called excepted trusts in the legislation.

If a trust is involved in an income injection scheme to take advantage of deductions, the income injection test may prevent the trust from making full use of the deductions. Under these schemes, income is injected into trusts with losses or other deductions so that no tax is payable on the income.
This test applies to all trusts other than excepted trusts. However, the test does apply to family trusts in some circumstances.

Family trusts (as defined) that distribute only to members of the family group will generally not be affected by the proposed measures. The income injection test will generally apply to family trusts only where income is injected from outside the family group.
A trust will become a family trust for the purposes of the measures if it makes a family trust election.

A consequence of making the election is that a special tax, called family trust distribution tax, is payable where a family trust gives income or capital to persons who are not members of the family group. This tax will be levied at the top marginal rate applying to individuals, plus Medicare levy.

The family trust distribution tax is an anti‐avoidance measure designed to ensure that the tax benefit of a family trust's losses cannot be transferred to non‐family members. The Government hopes the tax will never need to be paid.
The trust loss measures have been drafted so as to fit into the new income tax law being developed as part of the Tax Law Improvement Project.
The proposed rules are lengthy but necessarily so.

For example, there are many different categories of trusts. One way of dealing with trust losses would be to have a few standard rules that apply to all trusts. This would result in the rules themselves being unfair in their impact.

Instead, different rules have been applied to the different categories of trusts, depending on their nature. The result is that the size of the legislation increases, but this is matched by an increase in the fairness of treatment.

The length of the provisions has also been greatly affected by the changes made by the Government in response to representations from taxpayers and tax professionals. This has resulted in a trade off between simplicity and equity.

The estimated gain to revenue from the proposed changes is $90 million in 1995‐96, $185 million in 1996‐97, $160 million in 1997‐98, $75 million in 1998‐99, $20 million in 1999‐2000 and $20 million in 2000‐2001.
FAMILY TRUST DISTRIBUTION TAX (PRIMARY LIABILITY) BILL 1997
This bill is the second of four bills which implement the proposed trust loss measures.

This bill imposes the family trust distribution tax at a rate of 48.5 per cent of the amount or value of the relevant income or capital. In broad terms, the relevant income or capital is that given, by a family trust and some other entities in the family group, to persons who are not in the family group.
Family trust distribution tax was mentioned in my speech on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997.
FAMILY TRUST DISTRIBUTION TAX (SECONDARY LIABILITY) BILL 1997
This bill is the third of four bills which implement the proposed trust loss measures.
This bill imposes family trust distribution tax on amounts of unpaid family trust distribution tax of certain non‐resident entities. The tax is imposed at a rate of 100 per cent of the unpaid amount.
Family trust distribution tax was mentioned in my speech on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997.
MEDICARE LEVY CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENT (TRUST LOSS) BILL 1997
This bill is the last of the four bills which implement the proposed trust loss measures.

This bill makes a consequential amendment to the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to provide that the taxable income of a person for certain purposes includes an amount that is exempt from income tax because family trust distribution tax has been paid in relation to it.

This ensures the income tax exemption for amounts on which the tax has been paid cannot be used as a tax planning tool to avoid the increased Medicare levy on certain high income earners who do not have private health insurance.
Family trust distribution tax was mentioned in my speech on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997.

SNOWY HYDRO CORPORATISATION BILL 1997

Madam President, there are two bills in the legislation package which will corporatise the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority: the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997; and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997. The Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 gives effect to an agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments to establish a new company to operate and maintain the Snowy Mountains Scheme—Snowy Hydro Limited. The Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 repeals and amends various acts of parliament arising from the termination of the existing legislation.

This legislation complements corporatisation legislation introduced into the New South Wales parliament on 29 May 1997 and legislation expected to be introduced into the Victorian parliament in September 1997. The Snowy Mountains Authority cannot be corporatised until all three pieces of legislation have been proclaimed.

Madam President, most Australians would be aware that the snowy scheme is an integrated water and hydro‐electric power project situated in the Kosciuszko National Park. Through a unique and complex example of engineering technology water is diverted west to the Murray and Murrumbidgee river systems for irrigation, producing renewable electricity through a complex integrated infrastructure which includes sixteen major dams, seven power stations, 145 kilometres of interconnected tunnels and 80 kilometres of aqueducts. The snowy scheme is the largest supplier of renewable energy in mainland Australia. Hydro power is truly "green power", which does not produce the emissions associated with coal or gas, and there are strong indications that renewable power may attract a premium in the future.
There has been consistent support for corporatisation of the snowy scheme by successive Commonwealth and state governments, for a number of very good reasons.
The most significant is to ensure that the benefits of competition reform in Australia's electricity industry can be accessed by the snowy scheme.

The electricity industry is a very large and important sector, with assets of well over A$50 billion and some 45,000 employees. Its annual sales to 7.8 million customers raised A$12 billion in revenue.

Electricity is a key input for all Australian industries, accounting for between 5 and 30 per cent of input costs. Over the past two decades electricity use has increased by some 5 per cent a year. Structural and competition reforms in the electricity supply industry have the potential to reduce electricity prices to industrial users by over 25 per cent and thereby enhance Australia's international competitiveness.
Given the importance of improving efficiencies in this industry, governments have worked co‐operatively to introduce a competitive electricity market in southern and eastern Australia.

The snowy scheme is already important in the overall electricity market. Although the scheme provides only 5 per cent of New South Wales, Victorian, South Australian energy output, it has a number of unique strengths. It is a rapid response electricity generator, which can specialise in providing peak power to the market. It has an important reserve capacity role which provides insurance to the whole industry, because the snowy can respond instantly to cover the sudden loss of large coal and gas fired generating units. In particular, in the event of a complete or partial grid blackout, the snowy provides a "black start" service of restarting the electrical system.

The national market has recently commenced. Competitive trading arrangements will evolve progressively as the market develops, with the transition to a fully competitive national market expected to be completed by 2000. The commencement of the market has served to highlight that an important contribution to the development of the national market will be the creation of a competitive snowy generator, which will provide a greater depth of competition to other generators, and the separation of the snowy's current transmission business.

Under its current legislation, the snowy scheme is precluded from operating commercially in the national market. While New South Wales and Victoria have responded to the introduction of the competitive market by establishing a company to trade electricity entitlements from the snowy scheme, this does not allow the pricing arrangements enshrined in the current legislation to be varied.

Presently the operating costs of the authority are met by the electricity authorities of NSW, Victoria and the ACT, with no retained earnings. The current legislation requires that electricity is charged for at net cost of production, regardless of the prevailing market price. This does not allow the snowy to maximise its output of high priced peak power. Corporatisation will allow the scheme to change from cost based to profit based operations.
There are other important reasons to reform the scheme.

The dual management system which currently governs the operations of the snowy scheme has become outdated and inefficient. The Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority, a Commonwealth Statutory Authority, has responsibility for the day to day management of operations. The Snowy Mountains Council, which directs the operations of the snowy scheme's electricity generation, as well as water storage and release operations, comprises representatives from New South Wales and Victorian electricity and water bodies, and the Commonwealth.

This two tier decision making process does not provide the single management focus necessary to take snowy forward as a competitive and efficient trader of energy services in the national electricity market. When this legislation is proclaimed, governance of the scheme will transfer to a chairman and chief executive officer and a board of directors operating under corporations law and as set down in its memorandum and articles of the company.

As well, Corporatisation will enable the accelerated repayment to the Commonwealth of advances provided to fund the construction of the scheme. This debt to the Commonwealth has a face value of $820 million and a current value of around $740 million. Without reform the debt would not be fully repaid until the year 2027.

Madam President, some public concern has been expressed that corporatisation of the snowy scheme will establish a corporate entity which is then capable of being privatised. It is acknowledged that the Victorian government—which has largely privatised its electricity supply industry—has publicly indicated its intention to privatise its snowy entitlement as soon as possible. The NSW government has recently also stated its intention to privatise its electricity industry undertakings, including its 58 per cent share of the snowy scheme.

The Commonwealth government supports the corporatisation and privatisation of publicly owned electricity generators, distributors and transmission systems. We are investigating options to sell the Commonwealth's 13 per cent equity in the snowy to Victoria or NSW to simplify the governance arrangements when the scheme is corporatised.

Whether or not the Commonwealth sells its equity, the future ownership of the scheme will be finally determined by the major equity shareholders—NSW and Victoria. The Commonwealth has therefore placed a high priority on ensuring that the arrangements to corporatise the scheme recognise the community interests in the future of the snowy scheme. This interest is many faceted, reflecting the scheme's location in a national park; its significance as part of Australia's multicultural heritage; as well as its role as a significant source of the irrigation water on which our agricultural sector is so dependent. Regardless of the future ownership arrangements for the scheme these interests must be properly acknowledged.

A key element of the legislation package is the schedule to the explanatory memorandum, which contains the Corporatisation principles agreed between the commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments.

These principles, which provide the framework for Corporatisation, deal with the critical areas agreed between governments before legislation could be developed. These include: the formation, equity holdings, corporate governance and staffing arrangements for the company; water arrangements for the company; the establishment of a water inquiry to examine environmental flows in rivers in the scheme's catchments; the regulatory arrangements which will be imposed on the company by the nsw government; and the company's liability for taxation and state tax compensation arrangements. Under the corporatisation principles Snowy Hydro Limited will assume the authority's debt to the Commonwealth. The three governments are committed to the refinancing of the Commonwealth's debt in the snowy scheme shortly after Corporatisation.
The commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments have agreed that Snowy Hydro Limited will be incorporated in New South Wales, as this is where the snowy scheme is geographically situated.

The principle purposes of Snowy Hydro Limited will be to: generate electrical energy and market that energy and related services on a strictly commercial basis in the national electricity market; operate on a financially viable basis and in accordance with corporate plans approved by its members; and to undertake any future developments and operations that are commercially viable and that are agreed by the board.

Snowy Hydro Limited will be the sole employer for the scheme and all Snowy Mountains Authority staff will be offered the opportunity to transfer to the company. Those who do transfer to the company will carry over their Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes and various other accrued entitlements. Access to Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes will continue until such time as government ownership ceases. At that stage Commonwealth superannuation benefits may be preserved. Wages and conditions of service will also be carried over to the new corporation. Future changes to future wages and conditions can be subsequently negotiated under the government's new industrial relation arrangements.

Madam President, I have already alluded to the snowy scheme's importance as a water supplier to inland Australia. By diverting water west of the great dividing range, the snowy scheme plays an important role in agricultural production and river management, including flood mitigation, flow augmentation during drought and the control of salinity in the Murray and Murrumbidgee rivers. To achieve this, water has been diverted from other river systems, such as the snowy river. The community is now questioning whether the develop ment of the snowy scheme adequately acknowledged the impact of reduced flows in other rivers.

At the broader level, the Council of Australian Governments agreed to a process for water industry reform in Australia at its meeting on 11 April 1995. Of particular relevance to the corporatisation of the snowy scheme is the agreement by governments that the environment is a legitimate user of water.

governments have taken these concepts seriously. A water inquiry is to be held before the scheme is corporatised. The inquiry will examine issues arising from the current pattern of water flows in the rivers and streams within and flowing from the snowy mountains area, resulting from the operation of the scheme. The commonwealth has agreed that New South Wales and Victoria, as the two states which have principal responsibility for snowy scheme water management, will jointly sponsor the public inquiry.

The inquiry will be conducted by a single commissioner, appointed by NSW and Victoria and will report within six months, followed by a two month period to agree a final outcome. Corporatisation legislation will be finalised in all three parliaments following the states' agreement on the outcome.

Any outcome on environmental flows can only be determined in light of the finding of the water inquiry. The inquiry will allow the views of all interested parties to be considered—irrigators, environmental interests and other downstream users of water. Until then there is no valid basis on which governments can take any action to alter water allocations from the scheme.

governments have been unfairly accused of taking no notice of calls for increased environmental flows for the snowy river. To respond only to the views of one interested group in advance of a public water inquiry—particularly by legislating for environmental flows in the snowy river—would clearly disenfranchise other legitimate interests in the inquiry from the decision making process. governments have not been prepared to do this.

It is also important that the potential financial impacts of any changed water arrangements impacting on Snowy Hydro Limited be identified before the corporatisation legislation is proclaimed. This will ensure that the company is established on a sound commercial basis and can operate in the competitive national electricity market.
Madam President, there are other environmental aspects to the scheme's location in Kosciuszko National Park.

Following corporatisation, Snowy Hydro Limited will be subject to New South Wales environmental and planning law. To comply with the existing New South Wales regulatory regime, the company will be required to prepare a corporate environmental management plan, which establishes minimum environmental standards, remediation programs, performance targets, management controls and compliance checks and timetables.

Within the KNP, the sensitivity of the alpine environment and conservation status of the park means that it will not be sufficient for Snowy Hydro Limited to simply operate in accordance with the normal nsw environmental regulatory regime. After Corporatisation, snowy hydro limited's continued operation of the national park will be through a New South Wales lease and licence which will contain enforcement provisions in respect of a KNP environmental management plan. Snowy Hydro Limited also has significant incentive to ensure that its environmental performance is impeccable as it will be entering the market as a provider of "clean, green energy".

Mr Speaker, this package of measures is designed to formally take the snowy mountains scheme into the competitive national electricity market. It is essential that this step be taken to provide important and necessary competition and to reform the corporate governance of the scheme. In so doing the government is confident that the new arrangements safeguard the important environment and conservation status of the KNP and can address any potential impact that may have occurred regarding the snowy river.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
SNOWY HYDRO CORPORATISATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997

Madam President, this is the second of two bills in the legislation package which will corporatise the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority: the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997; and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997.

As outlined in the second reading speech for the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997, the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 repeals and amends various acts of parliament arising from the termination of the existing legislation.

The bill repeals the Blowering Water Storage Works Agreement Act 1963; the Loan (International Bank for Reconstruction and Development) act 1962; and the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority Act 1960 as part of consequential action arising from the repeal of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Power Act 1949 by the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997.

In addition the bill provides for consequential amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977; the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987; the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991; the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988; the Seat of Bovernment (Administration) Act 1910; and the Superannuation Act 1976.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.

Let me reiterate to Senator Parer that it is not just an environmental matter—because I know that is not going to get the minister interested—it is a very important economic and employment matter. Recycling of oil in this country creates jobs in this country to substitute for the import of oil from elsewhere around the planet. It has a massive beneficial incentive in terms of balance of payments. That appears to be flying right over the minister's head. He is being dismissive of it. It is important to bring forward that point in this debate. As I say again, I was tripped into action on this by the minister's brush-off statement that the burning of oil is dealing with it in an environmentally defensible manner. The burning and dumping of oil in the environment—and he says 70 per cent of oil used in this country goes that way—is environmentally indefensible and is economically plain bad management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that the minister made just then—that is, that this bill, in the government's mind, is not about the issues that Senator Brown and I have been canvassing—is probably a very true statement. Because this is an impact of the bill, the government does not want it on their agenda. The minister does not want it on his agenda; he would like not to have to deal with it. This is why, as I say, over three weeks we have tried to deal with the issue, tried to be reasonable and tried to get some sort of reasonable response from the government. We found out today, through their hairy‐chested behaviour, that they have decided they are going to do a crash or crash through without even the niceties of talking through the issues and without giving us the chance to talk to the industries. Isn't it funny that when there are industries that the government likes or supports everything stops to make sure that those industries are fully advised. But it seems to me that perhaps this industry is persona non grata with the government. Perhaps all the statements about fossil fuels that the government makes about wanting to do its best by the environment and small industry mean zilch.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to bring this home, I will quote a paragraph from a letter from Mr Fred Wren from Wren Oil to Senator Ellison as minister for customs:

As a law abiding member of society I would like to quote from my first letter to you. Obviously the large oil companies want government support to prevent the small recyclers such as Wren Oil from blending and marketing diesel and want the federal government to bring in legislation towards that end. We believe that we should have equal right to purchase tax paid new diesel from whomever can supply it to us. We should be able to blend it with our own recycled products for resale or on-sell the oil to whomever wants to buy and use it for whatever purpose they want. It should be the open market that determines the end user, not legislation.

Even should the government provide, say, Wren Oil in Western Australia with certain grandfathered exemptions—sunsetted exemptions—for sale to remote areas such as Broome, Derby, Exmouth or Esperance, that has not dealt with other companies in the rest of Australia. That does not deal with the medium- or long-term issue of whether this government is serious about encouraging the recycling of oil.

The fact that, in answer to Senator Brown's question, the minister is saying `Well, my answer to you as to whether we are assisting industry in recycling is that that industry already exists,' is a nonsense, a total nonsense. If what is happening damages the oil recycling industry then this government is doing the exact opposite of assisting that industry. Not only are they imposing a large cost on that industry they are also imposing a large cost on society. Even if all recycled oil was blended with fuel and sold without excise, the result would be small in relation to the total excise on oil. The percentage of waste oil used in the problematic blending is currently small, though it poses a potential problem. The percentage of waste oil collected and recycled is large. Anything that works against the industries involved creates a potentially large problem.

For instance, the fact that the soils in Perth where I live in Western Australia are mainly sandy makes disposal of waste oil difficult and contamination of ground water very likely. The fact that Perth and most Western Australian cities and towns are coastal and frequently sited on rivers and estuaries—and we have just had a debate about marine and coastal pollution—means that the disposal of waste water will pollute riverine, estuarine and marine coastal environments. So, if these are the government's actions in relation to these things, all the nice statements written in the marine and coastal pollution studies mean zilch.

There are issues about public utilities and the cost of remote and rural power generation relative to urban grid based power. But you say, `Leave that to the market'—except that we are going to stop the market from operating in this particular instance. We have already supported conversion to renewable resources of power for many of these stations. But we also recognise that this is a government decision. In the meantime, any move to make rural power more expensive, coupled with measures to eliminate cross-subsidies in the name of competitiveness, will penalise rural people, with no benefit to the environment.

The cost of collection of waste is substantial. It is currently borne by the private sector. If it is not borne by this sector, it will have to be borne by the public sector—probably state or local government, who will also have to figure out how to dispose of it. And how are you going to subsidise them? It will probably be put into pits and industrial waste dumps.

The cost of increased excise from recycled oil will be borne by users of state electric power—in Western Australia, the customers of Western Power. The cost in Western Australia will be borne by Western Australians in a multiple fashion: they will bear the cost of the increase in power due to the increased cost of fuel; they will bear the cost of the increased need to collect and deal with waste oil; and they will bear the cost of the increase in environmental degradation from inappropriate disposal of waste oil.

You have set your priorities. But perhaps you might like to give something to the industry to put their mind at rest. Can you guarantee, and can you state now, that regulations will be drafted to the satisfaction of the industry that I am talking about—that is, the recycling industry—at the very least, to exempt the sale of oil for blending with fuel from excise where that blended oil is sold to provide remote power to areas like Broome, Derby, Exmouth or Esperance power stations? And, of course, I am not wanting to restrict that to Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should make the opposition's position on this matter clear. I raised in my address in the second reading debate some of the questions that have been canvassed which now have taken the more personalised form of guarantees to Wren Oil. I might say that, in the first instance, I do think the Greens have a point about the tardy way in which the government has gone about actually giving those guarantees. Guarantees that could have been given earlier would have resolved the issue of the delay we are now experiencing because of debate on this matter, and it is unfortunate that there was that delay.

SPEECH.PARA: But, having that said, the guarantees I think have now been given in a manner which assuages the concerns that were raised by the opposition. Therefore, I am happy to vote for this bill in the committee stage and in the third reading.

What does bemuse me to some extent is the debate that we now are engaged in, which is a peripheral debate to the main issue that is before the chamber but one that is connected—and I can see the connection, and I am not arguing that it is not related. The confusion stems from my understanding of the Greens's position. My understanding of the Greens's position is that they favour a carbon tax. Here we have an amendment circulated in the name of Senator Margetts which actually provides a holiday of five years for people who might be blending oil for use in rural power stations which would have attracted the carbon tax. In policy terms, I cannot clearly understand what exactly the Greens are on about. It seems to me that you cannot call for a carbon tax, on one hand, and then provide a tax holiday for the burning of oil, which would produce carbon into the atmosphere, on the other.

Secondly, I think there is a tendency to talk in glowing terms about the oil recycling business. I too would like to talk in glowing terms about it because recycling of oil, I think, is a very worthwhile thing, and an oil dependent nation like Australia is one that ought to have refined that art to a high art form and then maybe more than 30 per cent of our consumption needs could be supplied. But I do not think we ought to run away with ourselves that there are not costs to the environment in recycling oil; there are.

There is cost to the environment in collecting it and bringing it to one central point for processing. Then there is the cost in gas emissions for the energy consumed in cleaning it and blending it. Also, since it is a replacement for oil that would have been burned anyway in a power station, you still get the same level of greenhouse gas emissions that you would have got whatever the source of the oil, whether recycled or original.

BREAK.PARA: So I do not see the argument in those clear terms; I know that these are peripheral to the main point. I just wanted to make those observations. But just to return to the central issue here: tardy though they be and, unfortunately, late though they are, nonetheless the undertakings seem to be satisfactory to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook seems to have missed the point altogether. Waste oil often gets burnt off or dumped. If waste oil is not recycled and cleaned up and used again, it is not going to help the greenhouse because perhaps more of it will be wasted into the environment in various ways, including simply burning it off and creating greenhouse gases. So the burning of it will probably happen anyway, and it probably will be burnt in a much more wasteful fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a issue of carbon tax. It is an issue of dealing with a particular type of recycling process in a way that makes it more and more difficult for companies to be involved with the recycling process.

The issue is about how you dispose of what is a non‐renewable resource in the most economic and environmentally smart way. The issue of a sunset clause still does not solve the problem in any reasonably thought‐out way. If there is a period of phasing out, it has not solved the problems or sorted out the situation for those industries. It just means they have a while to decide when they are going to close down, go out of business or whatever. It is about the long‐term issues.

What perhaps needs to be on the table now is a commitment to consider the Oil Recyclers Association of Australia's submission to exempt specific processed waste oil for uses of fuel, but to do this as a review of this bill to consider the long‐term impact on the waste oil recycling industry. If there is a sunset clause and if there is a commitment by the minister—I would like to hear those words from the minister—that these regulations will be drafted to the satisfaction of the recycling industry, which I do not think is unreasonable, there also needs to be a review to consider the long‐term impact of this bill on the waste oil recycling industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to your questions, Senator Margetts, let me take the first one that you raised in your earlier remarks. The regulations will be done in a constitutional way. To the best of our knowledge, the only areas that are affected are the four Western Australian power stations. They are, as you are aware, Broome, Derby, Exmouth and Esperance, operated by Western Power. When the regulation is drafted, it will be done in a constitutional way.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the second issue you raised, in the minister's response to Mr Fred Wren, he said:

The government is currently considering options in relation to the excise treatment of waste oils, including the submission from the Oil Recyclers Association of Australia to the Treasurer requesting a 100 per cent excise exemption for processed used oil for use as a diesel fuel‐blending agent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think `the government is currently considering' constitutes a review. What I am asking is: will there be an actual review—and will there be a published review—of this bill which will consider the long‐term impact of this bill on the waste oil recycling industry?

—In response, all I can quote to you is the response given by the minister for customs that the government will consider the options in relation to the excise treatment, including the submission of the Oil Recyclers Association.

—This is hardly satisfactory. The other issue was that the minister kept mentioning something about regulations done in a constitutional fashion. There are many examples where government sees fit to consult with industry when they are involved with legislation or, indeed, regulations. I was just wondering why the minister is finding it difficult to say that the government might actually make a commitment to sit down with the Oil Recyclers Association of Australia in order to make sure these regulations meet with their concerns?
—The customs department have consulted very extensively with industry and they intend to continue consulting with industry on those regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —After I made my contribution today, which was, in fact, angry, the minister came in and indicated it was a tantrum. The reason I was angry was the way he is treating this industry. I know, and they are telling me, how you have responded and how you have not responded. You are saying, `We will do what we have been doing up to now.'

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well to look around and laugh, but they do not actually think that their livelihood and their future is a laughing matter, and they do not expect your government to treat it as a laughing matter. What I am asking specifically is not, `Do you at some stage consult?' Will you make a commitment to sit down with the Oil Recyclers Association of Australia to make sure these amendments meet their concerns? That is a fairly simple question. It is not good enough to say, `We will make our amendments, we will consult and we always do consult.' I am asking you: will you make a commitment to make sure these amendments meet the concerns of this industry?

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say to you is that we will consult with the industry on the regulation in respect of the commitments we have made.

—The figure of 30 per cent of oil recycled in Australia: does that include oil that is burnt or does it include purely oil that has been re‐refined back to its refined state so it can be recycled and re‐used for the purposes to which oil is usually put?

—May I take that question on notice? I presume it is what you call `recycled'. I think we have all been through the experience of going to a landfill, as they call it these days—not a dump. If you take a can of oil, they put it aside and it goes off to recycling. I know that the garages I go to separate out the oil when they change the oil in the car and that goes off to a recycler somewhere. But let me take that on notice and I will give you a more detailed answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That underlines my concern because in Tasmania there is no recycling facility. I have been trying to assist Evergreen Oil, which is a local group of business people who put their life savings into world's best practice. I have approached government at state and federal levels to see what assistance could be given and have drawn a blank.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern I have is that, in Tasmania, oil in small quantities is burnt, which is not a good end use for it, and it is not being recycled. When you go to the landfill, as Senator Parer said, and you put your recycled oil somewhere, it is not in fact being recycled in terms of being re‐refined. Without delaying the committee, I will point out again that that is the best end use of oil. Ninety‐five per cent of oil can be re‐refined, using Evergreen technology.

That is a multibillion dollar advantage to Australia in terms of the balance of payments. But Evergreen sits there with this fantastic potential, with world's best practice, unable to make the final step from the refinery those people have built through their own sweat and commitment—and their own dollars, because they cannot get the final piece of bridging finance that would put them into action, this time with some assistance from one of the oil companies.

In the past recycled oil technologies have been squeezed out of the markets by the big oil companies. The big oil companies do not want recyclers in there. They do not want part of their market given across to an environmentally beneficial re‐use of oil. But, on this occasion, it seems like there is a breakthrough. One of the big companies has at least indicated that it will collect the oil and sell it at its outlets. That is a very important breakthrough. If it can be done in Tasmania it can extend elsewhere.

So I am bringing this up to explain to the minister that I am not just talking here about some green fancy; I am talking about a very real industry that has extraordinarily fine technology but that is being stifled at the point at which it should be flowering to great benefit right across the board to Australia's environmental, employment and economic prospects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I think you would agree that it would seem unfair if only parts of Australia that had developed this system by which they were providing oil to remote rural power stations were exempted. Will you give the commitment that if other companies throughout Australia wish to do something similar you will be willing to provide specific exemptions to allow that to take place?

—The response I gave before is that it would be done in a constitutionally correct way. The reason I said that is that the only power stations that we are aware of that use this technique are the four in Western Australia, and that is where the proposals have come from. But it will be done in the constitutionally correct way. In other words, if New South Wales or Queensland or someone else were doing it, it would apply as well.

—The Australian Democrats support the intent and purpose and value of the contribution made by the two Green senators in this debate and look forward to the government responding with sensitivity to the matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, you have an amendment that you need to move. Are you going to move that amendment?

INTERJECT.PARA: Request (by Senator Margetts) not agreed to:
(1) Page 2 (after line 5), after clause 3, insert:

PARA.TAB: This Act ceases to be in force at the end of 2 weeks after the day on which it commences unless the Minister establishes an inquiry into the impact of government regulation on the creation of markets for processed, used oil.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask that the vote of the Australian Democrats be recorded as in favour of the request?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —You certainly may. I am sure Hansard will note that.
