TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 and amendment No. 4 moved by Senator Cook for the Australian Labor Party. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam Chairman, I ask the minister at the table whether he is the minister who is going to carry this bill or is the minister who is going to carry this bill absent from the chamber.
—By the look on his face, I would say that he is not the minister who is going to take this bill through. Would you like someone to relieve you, Senator Parer?
—He is on the way.
—What a farce. The government are not even ready for their own bill.

—Madam Chairman, it is very difficult to debate with a minister who will not be handling the reply. This is a quite serious piece of legislation. It is one that the government has trumpeted as being a keystone to its approach to raising the standards of parliamentary debate and of public scrutiny of the processes of government. I am drawn to the interjection that I heard a moment ago from Senator Margetts. If the government cannot manage its own legislative program, how can it be expected to manage this piece of legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: What is before the chamber is an amendment that I have moved. When I moved this amendment, I said with as much emphasis as I could muster that it is a very important amendment. The amendment reads:
(4) Page 11 (after line 25), after paragraph (da), insert:

(db) a report prepared by the Commissioner of Taxation and the Secretary to the Treasury of any material threats to the integrity of the tax system including the fiscal impact of these threats, and their best professional judgment of the specific means necessary to counter these threats;

In view of the minister's last remarks on the Hansard , I want to further ask why the government does not support an eminently reasonable amendment such as that. But, with the minister not being here, I feel at cross‐purposes. I wonder whether there is any indication from the government benches how much longer the Senate chamber will have to wait. (Quorum formed)

I once more say to the minister that this is a very serious amendment. This bill is entitled the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill. As I have had cause to say during this debate thus far, it could easily be argued that it is mistitled; the proper title should be the `charter of budget dishonesty'. The government has proposed to the Australian people that it will provide a basis in which the policies of the major parties contesting the next election are transparent and that we can see and easily identify whether or not a party is making promises that will blow the budget through the roof. We can then remove, so the rhetoric surrounding this legislation asserts, the argument of who is right or who is wrong about the financial impacts of promises.

What is fundamental, absolutely foundational, to any party rationally and sensibly being able to develop policies which will be costed and presented to the people so the effects can be seen is to know what the situation is with regard to revenue; that is, what the tax base is. We have to know whether there are substantial threats to the tax system in Australia as conceived of by the Commissioner of Taxation. He can tell the Treasurer (Mr Costello). Whether the Treasurer tells the people of Australia is another matter.

Whether the Treasurer is prepared to act if there are threats to the tax system is a matter that the electors of Australia should know about. They should know when they are casting their vote whether the tax system has integrity, whether it is fair. They should know that. The person who can tell them is the Commissioner of Taxation. He is statutorily independent of government, and he has the responsibility for minding the integrity of the tax system.

There are two things in taxation which get electors in this country upset. One is eternally—irrespective of what the level of taxation is—the level of taxation. But I suspect what more seriously gets them upset is whether people are rorting the system and getting away unfairly with not shouldering their responsibilities in terms of the tax burden; whether someone over the other side is minimising their tax so that they or other electors have to pay more tax to compensate for that.

The Commissioner of Taxation maintains a monitoring of the integrity of the tax system. He knows what goes on. If we are having a charter of budget honesty in which voters at an election can see the economic impact of policies being presented by parties contending an election for the treasury bench, then electors have to be able to see whether the taxation system maintains its integrity, what the Commissioner of Taxation thinks about the integrity of the taxation system and whether the government is prepared to act to staunch a haemorrhage of the tax system, if there is one.

I think that is reasonable. I think any person you stopped in the street and asked whether or not they would want to know whether the taxation system was fair would say `yes'. So I do not know why it is that the government wants to oppose an amendment which would ensure that the people of Australia would find out that issue. The minister at the table has made a couple of forays in this debate but none of them, with the greatest of respect, has explained why it is that the government does not want to let the Australian people know the answer to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a chance. Just sit down and I'll tell you.

—I have a couple of other points. I thought I would make them all, rather than our going backwards and forwards like a ping pong debate, and then you can respond to the lot of them. In your responses to my previous propositions in this debate, which to some extent we are going through by way of synopsis now, you have got up and blackguarded the Labor Party when it was in power and said this, that and the other happened. All of that is interesting, much of it is quaint, a lot of it is political spin but none of it, with respect, has anything to do with what you do when you are in office and how you answer the proposition: why won't you let the Australian people know whether or not there is a material threat to the tax base?

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I wish to make in this debate and one that you might wish to reply to as well, Minister, is this proposition we have that parties are to submit the costings of their programs to Treasury so that the people of Australia will know what the real cost of the promises might be. Quite clearly, if the cost of a program is high and it imposes costs on the system which mean that a budget would go into a deficit rather than into surplus, that not only has to do with the measure being promoted but also has a bit to do with the level of revenue side of the budget, the level of income to the government. It may well be that the only way you can judge whether or not the impact of a given set of proposals pushes the fiscal barriers is whether or not the revenue side, the tax base, is properly handled.

There is a particular reason why this question ought to be put to you, Minister, and that is this: the last time we had a coalition government on the treasury bench in Australia the tax system in Australia became optional for the wealthy. They paid tax if they chose; they did not pay tax if they chose. I recall Malcolm Fraser, then Prime Minister, had an inquiry into the ship painters and dockers union which found the bottom of the harbour scam and many tax authorities in Australia argued with great force and considerable justification that taxation had become voluntary for the wealthy, which meant that ordinary Australians paid more because the wealthy got away with it for free or for negligible cost.

That was the last time, with the greatest of respect, your government presided over the tax system. Given your track record, on this occasion there is a particular reason why we do not want you to run away from this point and to answer it directly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down and I will.
—Order!

—The third point that I make in this debate—and I will conclude on this point, Minister—is that in elections it is not unusual for parties to make promises about tax. In fact I can remember the famous fistful of dollars election, in which the Fraser government made promises about tax cuts which it then backflipped on and repudiated after the election. I can remember that.
—Was that the l‐a‐w, Senator.

—I would counsel you not to get into a debate about l‐a‐w because you say a lot of things about l‐a‐w tax, all of which are wrong. You have repeated those things constantly and it has now become a mantra that you chant which assumes its own truth because of repetition. I counsel you not to get into that debate because, if you do, we will be here all day and I will take the opportunity to painstakingly walk you step by step through the error of your ways.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I make is that it is not unusual at election time for parties contending for high office to make promises about tax. Electors deciding how they cast their vote and what is believable about those promises need to know what the integrity of the existing system is and whether or not avoiders are getting away with it or whether avoiders are caught and pay their fair share. They do need to know that. That is why this amendment moved by the Labor Party is an important amendment. It is in the spirit of what the government has said is the purpose of this legislation. I know that the spirit is often departed from in practice but here is a chance to keep the spirit and the practice on the same wavelength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook is very anxious to get some responses, and fair enough; that is why I am here. Seeing that the senator made quite a number of points, I will respond to them. Firstly, he is a bit worried that when I get up, I blaggard the Labor Party. I would say, Senator Cook, that in 60 per cent of your speech you were blaggarding your opponents. You were worried that we went back to history, and then you went back to the Fraser period. You set up a principle and then three sentences later, you completely ignored the principle you set up. You decided to trap us through history—which you are entitled to—but if you are going to trap us through history, don't complain if other people do. That is the point that I am making.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I can list a whole host of answers to the really highly political points that Senator Cook made. I will not take the time of the committee because I think this is an important bill. All I say is that if the Labor Party wants to dish it out, it has to be able to take it. A lot of us feel that the Labor Party does have a bunch of glass jaws. This debate will show that when I get up and attack the Labor Party, it is in response to attacks that you have felt free to get up and make about the coalition. That is fair enough; that is political debate. Don't set up a principle and then completely ignore it the way you have done.

I think it is important in this debate to say that the charter already requires that material threats to the fiscal outlook be outlined in the statement of risks. I suggest that if you want to see how this is developed and applied, you should look at budget paper No. (1)—Budget strategy and outlook 1997-98. In that paper we look at the revenue side and the generous risks to the revenue. That starts on page 240. I will not take the committee through it, but it is a very long and detailed explanation of the material threats to the fiscal outlook. I think that some of those deal with tax minimisation and avoidance. Senator Cook, you asked me to respond to you. I am trying to respond to you. You might do me the courtesy of listening to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am listening to you.
—It does not appear to be the case from where I stand.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you can do that, but can you listen while you are also talking? In that statement of general risks, which I refer non-government senators to, there is a section on tax minimisation and avoidance. That is actually covered in the clause. Despite all those fine words, Senator Cook, we are looking at the risk to the revenue in quite substantive detail. I think I am correct in saying that it has never been done before. I am looking to my advisers and they are nodding. We have outlined the risks to the revenue. It would have been a help before you made that speech if you had looked at that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook, your amendment goes one step further, the way I read it. Your amendment would draw to the attention of tax planners the weaknesses and anomalies in the tax law before the government has time to rectify them. In other words, what we are saying is that the substantive point you are making is covered in the legislation as it stands. You want to go further. You want the tax commissioner to outline every little scheme, like R&D syndicates, for example, which you are a great booster for. That is what you want. The reality is that before any government came in to fix this up, the way your legislation stood, I am advised, it would provide a guidepost to tax planners. So it would actually produce a perverse result—it would actually produce the reverse of the result that you are seeking.

Senators will note that I have not risen to the debate and attacked the Labor Party's record on this, albeit it is an easy target. I draw the attention of senators to the way the statement of risks is outlined already. It is a very comprehensive statement of risks to the revenue.

The problem with Senator Cook's amendment is that it seems to me that it will just provide a guidepost for tax avoiders. I urge the committee to recognise that the substantive point is covered but the Senator Cook element goes far further. It would be like telling a burglar, for example, where the house is unlocked. The reality is that in tax law there is an industry out there which is seeking to constantly develop new schemes. It is an enormous effort of any government worth its salt to constantly attempt to close these schemes, like R&D syndicates, and protect the revenue.

I would urge the Senate to recognise that the substantive point that Senator Cook has made is covered. But Senator Cook wants to go further. He wants the tax commissioner to outline in detail the particular areas which we think would act as a guidepost to tax planners. This would lead to a reverse result, the contrary to what Senator Cook is claiming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start my response in relation to the ALP's amendment No. 4 to the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 , I want to respond to the example of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) that `it would be like telling a burglar where the house is unlocked'. I would have thought the government has some obligation to the parliament and the people of Australia. Is there a reason why you would not want to tell them whether the house is unlocked so that something could be done about it? It seems bizarre that the tax office would keep those things secret and not want to pass them on so that political change and action could take place. And that is exactly the point I will be making.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an interesting amendment in that it allows the officers of a departmental bureau to take what might be seen as political stands independent of government. Let us not make any mistakes: political choices are made, even in tax accounting and revenue estimates. As I said earlier, there is no such thing as an apolitical tax policy. Tax policy is not straight maths or entirely logical. It is about who should pay for social projects. Implicit in this is a debate about who benefits and how we want the distribution of economic resources to look.

Tax policy is often explicitly about the redistribution of wealth. I say that this is implicit in the tax debate, but it used to be explicit. It used to be the substance of such debate. It has now become either a naive assumption about goals and direction in society or a hidden, unspoken agenda. Tax policy is also clearly political in the sense that decisions about how much tax to collect, and whether to tax or to lower taxes, reflect political value decisions about the role of the public sector and, of course, about the role of government. Is it a burden on society? Is the only purpose of government a minimalist regulatory one—there are very few regulations at that—or is government the collective social body for attaining a common good? Is the role to provide public control of areas of life which affect all people—such as the provision of water and power, communications and a monetary system—in ways that reflect the purpose and values of the community? Is the goal to eliminate the profit margin on necessities, a margin which goes into private pockets?

These are highly political areas. We are asking the Australian Taxation Office to determine its own agenda to a certain extent, to identify what it sees as threats, needs and solutions and to present them to the public without regard for the views or policies of government or opposition. We are asking the ATO to become a political player in its own right.

On the issue of taxation, I think it would be fine to allow the tax office to highlight their issues. I think every department should be allowed to highlight their issues. I do not see it as the right of the education department to highlight threats or proposed remedies although, clearly, budgetary policies have been the primary threat to education and the department is often told to be quiet—but wouldn't it be nice.

The primary argument for singling out the Australian Taxation Office to directly enter public politics is that the tax base itself is the basis for allowing all other departments to fulfil both regulatory duties and social goals in terms of program provision. A secondary feature is that independent and public political information on tax may throw into high relief areas that the government may not have the backbone to address. As to the point about telling the burglar where the house is unlocked, areas like negative gearing, transfer pricing and the various rorts of corporations and the rich might be areas the government wants to stay unlocked—you never know. This is attractive, given the prevalence of these amongst the rich.

The primary argument against this amendment is that the Australian Taxation Office cannot be trusted to run a socially progressive political agenda. Why do I say that? My experience colours my view. We have seen the Australian Taxation Office argue the threat to revenue in terms of Commonwealth scholarships. They came up with `remedies' in the form of draft rulings on service that would effectively exclude the majority of Commonwealth postgraduate scholarship holders. We have seen them argue that broad shotgun approaches to taxation of trusts, which would negatively affect huge numbers of small business people—to whom it was recommended they set up as trusts—were necessary to catch big business rorters.

I have no doubt that big business rort trusts, and I have concerns for small business that are not rorting. Somewhere there needs to be more consideration than we need to get the baddies no matter what the cost to others. I do not see that in the ATO advice. I worry that the Australian Taxation Office will focus on a simple revenue preservation agenda without looking at the social impacts of taxation or how tax can be constructed to maximise social benefit through the targeting of tax and tax incentives.

I worry that the Australian Taxation Office will be seen as giving independent and objective advice when, in fact, they are giving political advice without making their social and political objectives clear. I guess they will not state in advance which factional party they might support. I think Hansard will show that I have supported governments acting where the tax office has identified a legitimate rort. I have been happy to see action taken on things like negative gearing. But negative gearing is not news and the failure to act has been because of a lack of political will, not because people do not know about it.

I will support this amendment because it will make it more difficult to ignore tax rorts at the big end of town. I want to make sure it is noted that I support it with some reservations. My reservations are really along the line of why I dislike this bill. I think it is a bad sign to support the pretence that budgets are purely economic and that economics is somehow just about money or is somehow or other scientific. This particular amendment may be all right since it is liable to show up deficiencies in terms of what those with considerable capital can get away with.

Our problem is that the tax office often have other targets. Their recommendations, like eliminating tax exemptions for scholarship holders, have implications that are certainly socially negative. The damage to our pool of educated people and to research will have economic implications, too. I do not have the faith that they will be picked up by any measure in the government's bill or by any amendments to this bill other than, potentially, Senator Murray's amendments Nos 3 and 6. Therefore, I tentatively support the ALP's amendment No. 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to Senator Cook's exposition of the virtues of his amendment and to the response of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). What went through my mind when listening to it—apart from the competitiveness that exists between the two sides—is the fact that in tax systems and in questions of tax integrity there is very little that is new under the sun.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the latest count of countries in this world of ours is 202. Tax systems, how they operate and the changes and threats to them are very widely discussed. I wondered what possible threat there could be from embarking upon a transparent approach to our tax system where nothing is hidden—there are no secret taxes, secret revenues or secret systems—everything goes through the parliament and everything is published and reported normally.

Everyone is well aware of the very material shifts that have occurred in our economy. For instance, it is why the Australian Democrats focus very heavily on financial transactions and the shift to foreign ownership and what that means. It is why the previous government, this government and we focus very much on transfer pricing. It is why we all are concerned with negative gearing, why we are concerned with trusts and why the government quite rightly has put tax reform on the agenda. We are aware of the way in which the whole tax system has changed and the fact that we need to re-evaluate where we place our emphasis and how we deal with it. On the basis of the natural attractions of an open and mature debate about these things, I would have thought that transparency was in our interests.

Minister, I had a look at the risk statement that you spelt out and it occurred to me, with the kind of view I have in mind, that this amendment actually adds to your intention. We have given you praise for embarking upon this course. I think the only thing we are most offended by is the lack of enforceability. This amendment will add a balanced and more holistic overview of the fiscal implications from your reports. I would have thought it adds to your bill and does not take away anything.

If indeed you have fears and those fears are realised, the very first report will expose those fears. I must say that, without particularity from you, I am unable to conceive of a situation where there is any real danger from the acceptance of this amendment.

I think the case made is a good one. I thought your example of the burglar and so on was possibly a little extravagant, given the lack of particularity about the possibility of any real threat resulting from an open debate in a world where that goes on a great deal anyway in analytical and academic terms. So my inclination is to support the amendment unless you can find some astonishing reason as to why Senator Cook's case is not persuasive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The only reason I rise is that I sought the call earlier to reply to the substantive point that the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, made when he replied earlier. Short of all of the rhetoric in this debate, what I understood you, Senator Kemp, to say was that, if my amendment is carried, then the tax office will expose what it understands to be schemes that rort the system—tipping off people who may wish to rort the system. That was your substantive argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with that. With the greatest respect, that argument is wrong. What happens now? There is a whole industry out there devoted to working out how to rort the tax system—how to get around it, how to minimise it. It discovers what it believes to be a loophole, it informs its clients, and off they go and minimise their tax—or rort the system; whichever way you want to describe that. The tax office picks it up after the event, after rorters have had a free reign for a time. The real threat to the integrity of the tax system becomes apparent to the tax office. Those with the privilege of the exclusive knowledge about the loophole are able to exploit it to their own advantage before the tax office operates.

Firstly, I think that that is the way it operates. Secondly, I think the tax office is counterpunching here. It is not exposing something in advance. It is exposing a practice that is current. Thirdly, and most importantly, our governments, if they are so moved, then issue a press release saying, `This is a problem with the tax base and we will legislate from this point to close off this loophole.'

If we all knew what the particular schemes were—in an election context, bear in mind, that is where this debate is occurring—there would be a greater responsibility of the contending political parties to make sure that they announce that the integrity of the tax system would be protected. I do not want to make this as a cynical, snide point, but let me make it frankly and straight to you: I cannot understand why a Treasurer would not want the backing of public opinion to strengthen his arm in closing loopholes, particularly when the public of Australia is paying attention in an election campaign, unless it is that he is derelict, slow to act or has something else to hide.

I think in terms of the public's need to know what the avoiders are up to—I was going to say what the bastards are up to—that it is a basic question of how well you police the system, and that is something that electors are entitled to make up their minds about. So I say, first of all, that the sequence of events is that the avoidance occurs and the response from the Taxation Office follows. Whether the government acts then is at its discretion, but the electors do need to know what the schemes are, and there is a capacity to legislate back to the time of the press release or, in extraordinary circumstances, even further back to cut out the ill‐gotten gains of this avoidance and deter people from going down that route.

The other thing I wish to raise is that you, Senator Kemp, said that it is dealt with in the budget papers in any case so we do not need to go any further. I have the budget papers before me, in particular Budget Paper No. 1, and I am looking at page 2‐40, which is head ed `Revenue' and `General risks'. It lists a number of general risks to the revenue: `Tax Minimisation and avoidance'—and it says a bit about that; `Financial innovation'; `internationalisation'; `communications technology'; `PAYE arrangements and personal services income'; `The tax treatment of trusts'; `community expenditure patterns', `Court decisions'; and `Tax expenditures'. It then goes to some specific risks, but it does not go to the sorts of schemes that ought to be stamped out. It just goes in a general way to the concerns. I think that, if this Charter of Budget Honesty is going to be able to present to the people of Australia a transparent way of understanding what the detail is, the amendment that I propose ought to be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly respond to Senator Cook's remarks. Tax law and tax avoidance are perhaps more complex than Senator Cook gives credence to, as indeed is the solution to it. Let us say a R&D syndicate type scheme emerges and comes to the attention of the tax office during an election period. This is brought to the attention of the contending parties. How many weeks go by? Three or four? It is a close election and the government is not formed until perhaps a month after the election. So perhaps two months have elapsed and a scheme that may well have proposed very substantial risk to the revenue is available for the tax planners and those who perhaps have not cottoned on.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook is quite right. Some of these schemes are often put to particular clients. Suddenly the press might reveal an area where tax avoidance can occur with very large sums of money involved. But the sequence of events then arises that one person's tax avoidance is not another person's. The debate on R&D syndicates was a classic case of that. We cracked down and you opposed it. Of course, in the end the government was successful in stopping what we regarded as a rort of the system over the heads of the Labor Party, I suspect due to the assistance of a variety of non‐government senators. So the situation is not quite as straightforward as Senator Cook might claim it to be.

It is possible that some schemes may have been known before but they are difficult to close; some may emerge to the knowledge of the tax office during a particular period. We are saying that the general risks that we put down are miles ahead of anything any government has ever proposed before. I know Senator Cook is very cynical of this bill, and those who know a bit about political history would understand why he is. We welcome the support of the Democrats for this bill and the recognition that this is a very big step forward. Of course, this was stimulated by the performance of the previous government and its cover‐ups before the election.

I put it to Senator Cook that this is a complex argument. There will be cases where this will certainly lead to signposts, and it may not be possible or practical to close them off before these schemes are really rorted in a huge way. The one thing on which Senator Cook is correct is that there is a big industry out there and people are working very hard because there is a lot of money at stake. This government is proud of its record of cracking down on tax avoidance, and it has often had to make these crackdowns over the head of the Labor Party.

I ask Senator Murray to note what I have said. When you see how these things develop, you see that the picture that is being painted in this chamber is too simple; it does not recognise the complexity of how these things develop, how they spread into the public arena and the possible risk. We think the substantive point is well covered and that it should be given a chance. We think there are some risks in what has been proposed. I would urge non‐government parties to reject this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Kemp, I cannot recall all the figures, but let me try to give some particularity to your examples. Let me use syndication as an example: you will recall that your government did make the decision; you will recall that the Senate reviewed the matter and that, as a consequence of that review, it was debated and the government bill was passed.

SPEECH.PARA: You may also recall that at no time was syndication ever regarded as illegal. Syndication was always legal and the allegation of rorting in the illegal sense of it was never proven; it was very difficult to substantiate. You were given, as they would say in law, the benefit of the doubt. That is why your bill passed, because we thought you had made a good enough case that the potential was there to threaten the integrity of the system and we were not getting the benefits out of it. I do not want to recap that, but let us assume that this reporting process had been in place prior to that. Let us assume that the report had said, `Look, parliament and people, we have here a situation where $600 million of taxable income is at risk. We believe that the way in which the system is running is not producing benefits that warrant the cost to the tax system and, accordingly, the government intends to consider closing down the system.' So what? What would have happened?

When you are dealing with gigantic sums of money which involve careful integration of very complex schemes, regardless of how clever and capable the industry is that deals with these things, they cannot rush off and, in a few weeks or months, turn the entire system upside down. The syndication example would be very true of that. Those were complex, long‐term and very difficult financial systems to structure and put together. They could not be put together very simply and very quickly because they had to relate to practical business events.

Using your own example, whilst I think I understand where you are coming from I cannot see, in the particularity of the example you give, that we arrive in a situation where the government would have been disadvantaged or have been put at any great risk if, at election time, you said, `We do not like the syndicate system and we are going to close it down.' I really cannot see that the result would have been major damage to the exchequer or anything else. In fact, it would have made for a very enjoyable debate during the election period. So whilst I understand the points you are making, Minister, I am not persuaded by them and I will support Labor's amendment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 1, clause 12, page 12 (line 4), at the end of subclause (1), add:
; and (f) a fiscal statement of election promises which have been kept or broken since the last election and their fiscal impact.

Democrats' amendment No. 4 on sheet 664 revised is in the same kind of arena that the whole debate is in, and that is expressing yourself in an election campaign and thereafter being held to account in terms of what you said. Amendment No. 4 to schedule 1, clause 12, adds a paragraph on a fiscal statement of election promises. A former leader of ours, one of the last of the six we have had, said that the government had made $18 billion worth of promises and kept $6 billion; or maybe she said they kept $12 billion of them. I cannot recall.

The fact is that it is a tradition in Australian political history—maybe in all political systems—to make promises that are not kept, and this clause will provide the electorate with an easy guide on what the government of the day has done or has failed to do in keeping their election promises. Parliamentary secretaries and sometimes governments feel with good cause that they cannot keep an election promise, and I think the electorate is fairly forgiving of that sort of thing; otherwise they would not return governments to office a second time around. But there are many times when they are not too forgiving.

The attraction of such a reporting requirement is plain. It is about information, transparency and accountability. It will mean that the electorate will be provided with the opportunity to have their memory jogged, to be able to see what was said and what its result has been, and governments will not be able to rely on the fact that after three years in office the electorate will not remember what it was they were promised at the last electorate and what the promises were that the government did not keep. Also, to the advantage of the government, they will not have an opposition of the day running round making claims that the government did not do things which in fact you might have done or could not do. It will turn claim and counter‐claim into a question of fact and how it is reviewed.

This amendment will, we think, be a particularly useful tool for the parliament and non‐government parties in scrutinising the government and keeping the government accountable to the public. We think that is the essential task of parliament, and of the Senate in particular, and of the non‐government parties in any democracy. The adoption of this amendment will only enhance these roles. I therefore commend the amendment to the committee and hope that it will be another addition to what we have already said is a good bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, there is some element of attraction in this amendment, but it goes to the issue of mandate, and I have never actually gone along with that concept. It has never been my belief that people voted for, for instance, the Greens (WA) on the assumption that they would vote with whatever government it was that got elected based on what that particular party promised prior to an election. So on balance I find it difficult to actually wave in front of any government a statement saying, `These are the promises you have kept and these are the promises you have not kept,' on the basis that some promises are worthy and some are not, and I reserve the right to indicate that there are promises which should never have been made and therefore should never be kept in relation to what governments or parties say that they want to do affecting the electorate. Therefore I do not know whether it would be serving overall the interests of the electorate to support this amendment No. 4, though I do see the rationale for moving it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment. I have two things to say about it. This is a way of keeping tabs on what promises are carried through once a government is elected. It would seem that the implication of this amendment is that each year, I imagine, the budget papers would contain a tally of what promises have been kept and what have not been kept. It may well be, as Senator Margetts says, that there are some promises that should not have been made, but they were and people may well have voted for the government on the basis of those promises. Whether they should have been made or not is a subjective judgment at the end of the day, but if they were made and people voted, then they are entitled to know what the outcome was. Whether or not they have a different view later on, they are still entitled to know what the outcome was.

SPEECH.PARA: I have it in my memory that after the 1993 election the Labor Party produced a statement saying what election promises we had kept. Certainly the current government published a document, `Meeting our commitments', after the last election saying what promises they had kept, and arguing in their own party documentation that promises had been kept. Some of them were a bit political in terms of how they were argued—for example, it was argued that they had kept their promises to the ABC despite making a cut. But the point about this is that the Labor Party and the coalition have produced this sort of audit on themselves and because they are self-nominated audits there is, for the cynic, some element of question as to how accurate they are. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition believes that this amendment is ultra vires the intent of this piece of legislation. If you use Senator Murray's argument, which is that we should be judging a government's performance against its own election promises, this amendment would force us to break an election commitment because our election commitment was very much, as Senator Margetts alluded to, to have a charter of budget honesty that was quite specifically to look at our performance against a budget and a fiscal strategy. Political commitments in election campaigns and prior to them and in policies and manifestos cover a range of issues, some of which have fiscal impacts and some of which do not. I guess you would argue that for the ones that do not have fiscal impact you would just have `no fiscal impact' on the line.

SPEECH.PARA: You are tending to make the charter of budget honesty legislation so broad as to lose what we regard as its important central focus, and that is the government's performance against its fiscal strategy, and how that is achieved, and also to assess those other matters—risks and so forth—that we debated earlier. There are a range of interest groups and media specialists who analyse whether a government is performing against certain goals.

I know that in the policies I wrote in the areas of administrative services—Senator Kemp and I wrote that policy—property rationalisation, youth, and sport and recreation prior to the last election there are detailed points against which any of the people interested in those policies can go back and judge our performance. You will be able to see which specific policy commitments have been delivered, which are in the process of being delivered and others which have not been delivered at all. Senator Cook makes the point that there are areas where governments do not deliver the promises they make in opposition or prior to the election, sometimes for good reasons, sometimes for bad reasons. Sometimes you realise there are better ways to achieve the same sort of outcome.

The point I make is that in political debate, and with the assistance of an ever watchful electronic and printed media, there are very good ways of assessing whether or not a government is keeping its promises in a range of portfolio areas. We believe that to burden this piece of legislation with a requirement to report on a range of matters that do not necessarily have any sort of relationship to the fiscal or economic performance of the government, which is the focus of this legislation, would destroy the important focus of this legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel obliged to remind the Senate that in the lead‐up to this last federal election there was a very well orchestrated campaign by the now government, who were then in opposition wanting to form government, to make sure that when they put policies out—there was a very clever process— they gave them in rapid fire, very much under control, so that the fine details of what was being presented were not even available. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, clause 20, page 16 (lines 5 to 11), omit "5" (wherever occurring), substitute "3".

This amendment refers to the matter of intergenerational reports. TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting this amendment.
—On behalf of the opposition, I inform the committee that we see no reason why this amendment should not be supported. We will be voting accordingly.
