SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the point that has been made by Senator Murray and particularly the point that if it is a five‐year period the first report will not necessarily be provided until five years after the date on which this legislation comes into effect.

I think that is probably too long. I think it would be desirable for the government, the opposition and other political players, such as the Australian Democrats, the Greens and whoever else, to have that first report brought forward in a period of less than five years.

I know that the minister has stated that five years is to be the minimum time—it is his decision, his idea, his legislation—but I wonder whether some sort of guarantee can be given that the first such report will be brought forward to within a period of three years from the date of operation of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one of these advisers is prepared to risk their neck and make a promise. I think it is a very important question, and it is one that I am happy to raise with the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know that I can get you an answer before we have a vote on this particular amendment, but the main issue I was canvassing before we were so rudely halted by the Temporary Chairman at 6.30—and I think Senator Harradine understands this very well—was that these are reports that look at the long‐term fiscal position and the impacts on those over a 40‐year horizon. You often get changes in the costs of delivering services and the productive capacity of the economy—long‐term issues.

The question you have asked is whether we would leave it five years from proclamation to do the first such report. I could only guess at it, and I will not hazard a guess. But what I can do is seek to get some sort of indication in the short term for you. Apart from that, I cannot give you any further assistance because I cannot make those sorts of decisions standing in the Senate, as much as I want your support for the legislation as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to make a point for the timing and that is that I think the first report you produce will be a pacesetter, if you like. It will be very important to set the pace and the tone for the future, and the dates could run roughly like this: if the act was proclaimed next year, by the end of next year you might have an election. You would perhaps be returned and run a further three‐year term, and there still would not be a report until you faced the possibility of a third term. That would be a worry, given your commitment to the bill and to the objectives you face.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the support give by Senator Harradine, the Greens and Labor but, on those grounds, I recommend that you reconsider your position.

TALK.START.PARA: —The argument put forward by the government on this is that they ought to stick with five years, not three, because of the long‐term forecasting involved here.

BREAK.PARA: I have a copy of a public sector superannuation scheme and Commonwealth superannuation scheme report which is subheaded: `A report on long‐term costs carried out by the Australian Government Actuary.' On page 4, talking about projection of actual employer costs, it says: `Actual employer costs have been projected for the next 45 years and expressed as a percentage' and so on.

Is it not true that this is done every three years? It used to be done every five years and it is now down to every three years. If it is done every three years, why don't you put it in the fiscal report, as requested in the amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the point of Senator Cook. I entirely trust you on these matters. If you say that is what it is, I am sure that is the case. However, that particular issue is but one of a number, and it is probably the most simple one to seek to forecast. You can make estimates as to the number of people being funded and the contributions that are being made, and you could use relatively simple formulae to estimate the impact in out years, going out for some time. There are other costs, of course, and other influences that might be harder to determine.

SPEECH.PARA: I think all senators would agree that this would be a major undertaking, a major exercise. Senator Murray is quite right—the first report will be a very important one. To steal Senator Margett's language in relation to environmental matters, it will be a baseline report. It will be important to get the matters in that report as accurate as possible and ensure that you will not have to keep changing them every five years, or whenever you produce a further report.

We think it is important to have an assurance that at least twice a decade you have this long-term report. People will anticipate this report. It will become a very important focus of national economic attention. It will focus national debate on long-term economic trends. It will ensure that people do focus on trends within the economy—the ageing of the population, the cost of providing services, the cost of a range of other longer term items—so you are not continually putting off hard decisions year after year until they get so hard that they have the potential to cripple the economy as a whole, or deferring expenses to future generations unfairly. So it is an important matter. It is important to get it right, and to retain the flexibility to do it at least once every five years but also in the near term.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, clause 22, page 17 (lines 5 to 8), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 22 Public release of pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report

PARA.TAB: The responsible Secretaries are, jointly, to publicly release a pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report:
(a) two years and nine months after the first day of sitting of the House of Representatives following the previous general election; or
(b) should writs for a general election be issued prior to the report required under paragraph (a), within five days of the issue of those writs.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment has the effect of replacing the existing provision for a pre-election financial economic and fiscal outlook report being published within 10 days of the issue of the writs with a new provision that a report should be published two years and nine months after the first day of sitting of a new parliament or within five days, and not 10, if an early election is called.

The opposition has moved this amendment for the very simple reason that if a pre-election economic and fiscal report is to be published, then for it to be useful and contribute towards public debate in the context of an election campaign, it needs to be timely, and available as soon as the election is called. It should not just be used as a political tactic by the government of the day to advance its own political agenda.

Obviously, the later such a report is released, the more beneficial this is to the government than it is to the opposition because it denies the opposition reasonable time in which to respond to the issues that the report has raised. In the context of budget honesty, such an approach is decidedly dishonest, as it denies the opposition and the public adequate time for scrutiny and adequate time for a response. It is, therefore, eminently sensible for such a report to be made public at the end of a normal parliamentary session or within five days of an election being called early.

If the government is serious about presenting timely and relevant data to allow the parties to prepare detailed and effective policy costings, then the opposition amendment should be supported. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook's amendment reduces the delay between the issue of the writ for a general election and the public release of the pre-election economic and fiscal outlook reports from 10 to five days. The Democrats welcome the shortening of this time‐line in the interests of informing the electorate and providing them with sufficient time to assess the pre-election reports. Therefore, we support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —The government regards the period after the election announcement or issuing of the writs—virtually within a few hours of each other, probably within 24 or 48 hours of each other—as entirely impractical. I am quite sure that the Australian Labor Party, who have been in government, would understand that it takes a significantly longer period than five days to prepare these documents. I am sure Senator Cook would have had at least some passing involvement in the preparation of economic reviews.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would tend to make one believe that the Australian Labor Party are not dealing with this bill seriously, if they seriously stand by it. It is practically impossible. There is no way the government could live with that. It would make a farce of the situation. It ignores the fact that in relation to the two years and nine months after the first day of sitting of the House of Representatives following the previous general election there is another range of practicalities, particularly the fact that this legislation will already commit the government to the release of a detailed mid-year economic review, the like of which this nation has not seen before—certainly not in the last 13 years. We will be voting against the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Senate's attention to some participants in the Australian Masters Games who have joined us today, the Heidelberg Volleyball Club. I welcome you all on behalf of the Senate—and good luck in the grand final tomorrow!
—They are members of the party!

—No. They are not members of the party, you would be happy to know, Senator Heffernan. If the government is genuine about budget honesty, it has to be genuine about getting the report out within five days—
—Did you say honest—this crowd! You are kidding.
—It is hard to imagine that in relation to a government that has broken so many promises you could use the word `honesty', but this is the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill.
—Don't put on an act just because you have an audience.

—That is the whole point. Ten days is too long for an opposition to be able to use the information and draw on it to educate the public on its policies. But the government wants to try to hold the information for 10 days during an election campaign. The government is privy to that information because it has received all the confidential briefings of Treasury and it is aware of where the economy is going, yet the opposition has to wait 10 days before it is able to obtain this information. If you are genuine, if this is more than just the stunt that we on this side of the chamber believe it to be, then you will accept this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Treasury has been under your regime now for 18 months. We are sure that you would agree there have been lots of improved efficiencies in Treasury through all your new workplace relations legislation, individual contracts and workplace bargaining. So surely Treasury, under your regime, is able to respond quicker than in the old days and is able to get a report together. It is not as if it will be unaware of the possibility of an election, especially if you are in a situation where you have had to already present a report at two years and nine months. All you will have is finetuning. You suggest, Senator Campbell, that because you will have provided your midterm report—

TALK.START.PARA: —Midyear economic review—that's what it is called.

—midyear economic review, thank you—there is no further need for an earlier reporting time of two years and nine months. I simply draw your attention to what your own reviews over the last 12 months have done—that is, to continually downgrade your forecasts on employment growth, downgrade your forecasts on GDP growth and avoid therefore having to admit that unemployment was going to rise. You have had three changes of your forecast in 12 months and you still will not come clean about this year's.
—If they were in the weather bureau they would have been sacked!

—That is right. You still will not come clean on whether or not unemployment is going to be down as low as 8.2 per cent or 8.3 per cent, as you forecast in this year's budget. You know it will not be. All the private forecasters have already revised down, before the Asian crisis hit, their forecasts for GDP growth, and that has to mean that unemployment is going up again this year. I will wind‐up there as Senator Cook is ready to make a contribution, it seems.

—It seems that the government has a problem with paragraph (b). I did not hear any arguments advanced in opposition to paragraph (a), that is if I am reading the right amendment. The amendment we are dealing with, as I understand it, substitutes the current clause 22 for a new clause 22, such that the responsible secretaries are jointly to publicly release a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report made two years and nine months after the date of the first day of sitting of the House of Representatives following the previous general election or, should writs for a general election be issued prior to the report required under paragraph (a), within five days of the issue of those writs. I would imagine any prudent government would have this material ready to publish in any event. The strong, quite definitive and lucid intervention by Senator Conroy into this debate indicated that would be the case. I must say that I am very much inclined to vote for Senator Cook's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting Senator Cook's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Schedule 1, clause 27, page 20 (after line 25), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) Apart from providing information to the responsible Secretaries under subclause (1), Minister must not participate in the preparation of a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is to proposed section 27, `Responsible Minister to provide information to help prepare report'. This amendment is designed to ensure that there is no ministerial influence, direction or bias that can in any way influence that pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report. The Australian Democrats would like to be assured of absolute independence and freedom of interference in the drafting of these reports by the secretaries to the treasury and finance departments. It does not, of course, prevent the minister providing information.

The assurance that we want is essential for a number of reasons. It will serve to protect the independence of the Public Service and the ability of the secretaries to give advice without fear or favour and without being pressured or potentially pressured by anxious or aggressive ministers as they face the prospect of a difficult election—and all elections are difficult. It will protect the government, we think, from the allegation and perhaps temptation of interference in the drafting of those reports. Finally, it would ensure the electorate is receiving the most accurate and independent report on the economic fiscal outlook that it could hope for. Those are the principles and reasons which I urge senators to consider. I urge them to support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasury and finance secretaries, which I presume Senator Murray will know, already must sign off on these reports stating quite clearly that they reflect the best of their professional judgment. I do not know whether Senator Murray thinks that people like the Secretary to the Treasury or the finance department secretary would sign off on those matters if they did not agree with them. There are already provisions in place to ensure that that cannot happen. I would think from a quick reading of Senator Murray's amendment that this provision is entirely unenforceable anyway. The best protection that we have is that the secretaries of those two departments are required to sign off in their own names on these reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I just think we already have a sensible provision within the legislation that deals with this problem. You want to add the words `the Minister must not participate in the preparation of a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report'. I will just quote from part (b) of clause 25:
a statement signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury to the effect that, to the fullest extent possible, the information in the report for which the Secretary is responsible:
(i) reflects the best professional judgment of officers of that Department; and
(ii) takes into account all economic and fiscal information available; and
(iii) incorporates the fiscal implications of Government decisions and circumstances disclosed by the responsible ministers;

In a way at part (iii) ministers and in fact the Treasurer will have to be involved in the process because they will have to provide information on which the secretaries will have to make decisions. I guess you would say `not participate in the preparation of a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report'. I guess if you are minister and you are asked to provide information you would have to read this legislation and say, `I should not be participating in the preparation of the report by providing information.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The first line says that, Minister. It says `apart from providing information'.

—I guess in some ways they are in conflict. It is a matter of providing information, giving further information or maybe the secretary coming back to you challenging the information. You would imagine that in the sort of process gone through regularly in estimates and additional estimates there is a continual process between both the minister's office and the policy departments responsible and between both the finance department and the Treasury to ascertain these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought your best protections really are in existing paragraphs (i), (ii) and (iii) of subclause 25(b) and, as it relates to the finance department, under subclause 25(c). I do not think this adds to those protections. As I said, they would be almost impossible to enforce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are lots of ways of participating. It is a bit like saying that the Treasury should participate in an audit. In a way it is a bit like an audit. This is the state of the accounts. I do not think it is an unreasonable suggestion to say that, if this is a bit like a quick audit in order to present it to the community, it is reasonable that apart from providing information and being cooperative in that sense the Treasury should not be directing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to Australian Democrat amendment No. 8 on sheet 664 revised. This relates to the costing of election commitments. We have been obliged in putting this amendment to omit the clause and to put a substitution. I do want to indicate to the Senate a minor change, if I may, to subclause 29(2). That is on page 2 of the schedule. At subclause (2) insert at the beginning of the subclause `subject to clause 31, subclause (4)'.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this minor amendment is to clearly link the costing of election commitments in clause 29 with the provision for supplementary policy costings in subclause 31(4) after the policy costings have been completed under section 29 as long as those supplementary policy costings are provided seven days prior to the election date. The reason for this specification that policies be provided to the department 21 days before and supplementary ones not less than seven days before is to ensure that Treasury and finance departments have sufficient time to cost supplementary policies. It is also designed to ensure that the electorate is informed as far as is possible of policies days before the election.

These amendments apply during only the caretaker period following the issuing of a writ for an election. The intention of this amendment is to provide for the costing of election commitments of both major parties. I wish it was minor parties as well.

The costing of election commitments will clearly assist the electorates in their assessment of the parties' fiscal policies and their election promises. It will encourage parties to ensure that the election commitments are economically responsible and not unnecessarily burdensome on the public purse. The amendment will make available to the government, the opposition and all those concerned within those parties the resources of the departments of Treasury and Finance during the caretaker period to cost election commitments so that the public may be made fully aware of the fiscal impacts of such commitments.

We think this amendment serves again to enhance the intention of the bill by improving the information which the electorate have at their disposal in the election of the government to come. It will make all parties accountable to the electorate and open to public scrutiny. That is the intention of the system. This amendment which I foreshadow is straightforward. I look forward to your response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite follow where we are up to here. I have taken on board the oral amendment made by Senator Murray to subclause (2) of clause 29, which would read:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to clause 31, subclause (4), the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and any minor party leaders are to provide . . .
When I turn to my bill and look up clause 31, clause 31 does not have a subclause (4), so I do not know quite what it is subject to. That is my first difficulty.
The second difficulty is with subclause (1) of the new amendment. It reads:
The responsible Secretaries are to prepare costings of policies announced by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and any minor party leaders . . .

That is a marked improvement on what the bill says, where it confers on the Prime Minister the option of referring opposition policies to the departments for costing. Under this construction it seems to me that the opposition policies and any minor leaders' policies are to go for costing. That is an improvement but the difficulty I also have is with `policies announced'. I have some amendments to come a little later which would enable, if carried, parties to actually get an indicative costing so they know what the outcomes might be when framing their policies. I think that is a very useful amendment. I draw those things to the attention of the mover, Senator Murray. Perhaps if there is an explanation, it might help me sort out my problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the committee. I should have indicated to you that I was foreshadowing moving my amendments. Possibly I should have moved them cognately. I am referring to amendment 12, which provides subclause (4), which we are looking for. Do you see it there, Senator Cook?
—Yes, I do.
—I seek leave to move the two together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (8) Schedule 1, clause 29, page 22 (lines 4 to 30), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) The responsible Secretaries are to prepare costings of policies announced by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and any minor party leaders during the caretaker period for a general election, but not including any policies announced later than 7 days before the date of a general election.

(2) Subject to subclause 31(4), the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and any minor party leaders are to provide to the responsible Secretaries in writing sufficient details of their election policies not less than 21 days before the date of a general election to allow the policies to be costed in accordance with this Act.

(3) The responsible Secretary may agree that the policies are to be provided to a third person agreed to between the Secretary and either the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition or the minor party leader, as the case may be, for independent costing.
(4) For the purposes of subclause (3), the Secretary must not agree to provide the policies to a third person unless the Secretary is satisfied that the person is:

TAB.TAB: (a) not associated with any political party or interest group; and
(b) capable of costing the policies in accordance with this Act.

PARA.TAB: (5) The Secretary, or a person selected under subclause (3), must not disclose the contents of a policy document to another person without the permission of the office holder providing the policy document until the policy document is publicly released.

(6) The Secretary must consult the Prime Minister or Leader of the Opposition or minor party leader providing the policy document before costings are released to ensure that the policy has been costed in accordance with the assumptions underlying its intended implementation.
(7) The Prime Minister or Leader of the Opposition or minor party leader may withdraw a policy from the costing pro cess by notice in writing to the responsible Secretary.

BREAK.PARA: (12) Schedule 1, clause 31, page 23 (after line 32), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) Subject to subsection 29(1), if any policies are released by the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition or a minor party leader after policy costings have been completed under clause 29 and the new policies would change the total policy costings published under this section, the Secretaries must release a supplementary policy costing of the new policies, prepared in accordance with clauses 29 and 30, before the date of the general election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on the record one of a number of concerns that many Australians—certainly those who would like to see a full range of policy commitments released—would have. I heard Senator Margetts speaking before the suspension of the sitting for dinner about the trick that the coalition played in terms of our policy announcements—releasing them in quick fire succession.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy of the coalition was to release all of our policies before the election. Our strategy included releasing, on average, one policy a day for the period of the election. I know from my own experience in the portfolio that I had responsibility for prior to the election that I worked very hard to ensure that as many people as possible knew what was in the policy. The problem was not so much trying to hide the policy from people. We went to enormous lengths to ensure that people were very well aware of the policies. It is very hard, as all politicians would know, to get more than the core details of the core parts of policy across.

You certainly do get more attention paid to policies in an election environment. If I were to release my sports policy three months out from an election and try to get someone to focus on it, it would be almost impossible. At least in an election climate, people are interested in what the parties are saying.

Senator Kemp, for example, who is with us in the chamber tonight, released, as you will recall, Senator Margetts, an environment policy. That was one of the most detailed environment policies ever prepared by a major party in Australia's history; at least that is what Senator Kemp told me. It is fair to say that that policy received a lot more attention in the context of the election campaign—the detail of it as well—because it was released in that campaign.

The concern I am leading to is that, with the get out of some sorts of exemptions, you effectively would have to have the policies finalised and released within 12 days of the firing of the starter's gun and the issue of the writs. I think we had something like 38 policies during the last election. It was a fairly neat fit to try to do about one a day.

What you are saying is that you have to get all of your policies out in the first 10 days. You probably argue that we should put the policies out well before the election. My own long experience in this area shows that you do not get the coverage. You do want people's minds to be focused. When you release a sports policy or a policy on the environment or whatever, not only do you get the information out through the electronic media, the newspapers and so forth and you send it to all the interest groups in the mail, but you always get telephone calls into the office, the Liberal Party campaign offices or electorate offices and you can send out detailed material.

Senator Margetts, when Senator Kemp released that environment policy I was meeting with Senator Chamarette, your former colleague. She was very interested and requested a copy which I duly delivered to her that afternoon. I know that Senator Chamarette would have gone through that policy in some detail. That is a normal sort of process.

This amendment, on my reading of it and on the advice I have taken on it, with one or two exemptions effectively means you cannot release any detailed policies for the final 21 days of the campaign—and I would have thought that is quite counter to democratic principles. I would have thought that political parties should be releasing policies throughout that 33‐day campaign period and allowing the voters, at a time when they are most focused on political matters, to assess those policies and to do so in comparison with the alternatives in the political battle.

The imposition that this would place on the Treasury and Finance officials is almost too hard to imagine. I would be interested to see, when Senator Cook has had a chance to top and tail the amendments with the proposed amendment, the addition of 31(4), what the opposition's views are. They have had the benefit of being in government and knowing what would be required, practically speaking, to achieve the implementation of this amendment. I put it to the Senate that it will be a very important test of the opposition's sincerity in dealing with this legislation because on my reading of it it would probably be quite counterproductive to the very essence and aim of this bill, which is to place the fiscal footing of the government and any policy proposals before the people in an objective and democratic way. But I wait with bated breath to hear what Senator Cook has to say about this proposal. It will be a test of their sincerity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —How could I refuse such a generous invitation to test my sincerity? But let me start where I would like to start, if I may. As I said before, there are some things in this amendment that I approve of and agree with. One is the question of minor parties being able to have their policies costed. I voted for such an amendment earlier. That amendment has been put and defeated in this chamber and is back here in this proposal—and I would be happy to vote for it again. I am also pleased that in the first part, subclause (1), the option of the Prime Minister to refer or not refer opposition policies for costing is removed because the wording of this paragraph means that the Leader of the Opposition's policies are referred. So the intervention of the Prime Minister in deciding what goes for costing and what does not in opposition policy is removed; and that is a very positive thing. When we moved that amendment before we lost it. It is back here now and we have a chance to restore it. I would like to be able to succeed in doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to balance those positive things against, in the first clause, the seven‐day rule. We have not had the chance to consider this properly but it may be just a touch too rigid for us. Looking down the list further, to subclause (5), there is a penalty of 20 penalty units imposed for a breach of subclause (5). The subclause states:

The Secretary, or a person selected . . . must not disclose the contents of a policy document to another person without the permission of the office holder providing the policy document until the policy document is publicly released.

If they do, there is a penalty. I understand why that is there. I again make the observation that we sought that this bill, if it were to become an act, be enforceable. That was defeated. It is not enforceable so I do not know how we can have in a bill a penalty which, if the bill were to become an act, would not be enforceable.

When I look at this amendment, I am driven to the conclusion, reluctantly and to some extent against my will, that I am proposing to vote against it in favour of pursuing the amendments that are circulated in my name and which deal with some of these things on an individual basis rather than within a block amendment of this nature. That is not, as I have said, that I do not have strong sympathy with the question of the Prime Minister not interfering and being able to decide what is referred and what is not. I am happy to have minor parties have their programs costed. But there are other elements to this fuller clause that create in me a bit of anxiety and cause me to want to act cautiously and pursue my amendments individually.

I have not directed my attention in a great deal of detail to subclause (4) of clause 31 in amendment No. 12, the one that has been moved concurrently with the amendment before the chair and on which I am asked to test my bona fides in this chamber. I will do so but for the moment all I can say is that I am disposed at this stage and for the reasons I have enunciated not to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, I am not one of those who would ever question your bona fides in this chamber. I have always found you to be very straightforward. Having said that, there are two points I want to pick up on. The minister goes to a question of emphasis and philosophy. The one view we have is that the government, the opposition and anyone who is serious about the election process will have developed their policies well in advance of any election. Not to do so would frankly be delinquency of the highest order.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue is when those policies are released, not whether they are prepared or ready to go, and whether the electorate have sufficient time in which to consider those policies. Our view has always been that the earlier policies of detail and depth are released the more serious and the more considered a view the electorate can take at large. It is extremely difficult for the media, other political parties and especially the electorate to view in a few short days a welter of policies which descend on them.

Senator Cook, you referred to the question of penalty. You are right that, as the bill as a whole is unenforceable, it makes it difficult to enforce that particular clause. But I would suggest that one of the most important things to any political party is that it controls the timing and the contents of the release of its policy.

Given that the administration in recent years has taken to leaking like a sieve, you need to be able to control this sort of area. It will be a problem that faces the government and the opposition more than it faces those on the crossbenches. With those few remarks, I will leave my amendments to your views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I am looking at page 22, part 8, subclause 29(1)(a) of the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Prime Minister may request the responsible Secretaries to prepare costings of publicly announced Government policies . . .
I will be moving an amendment later which deals with the term `publicly announced'.

I do not propose to explain it in any detail now, but essentially we think there is considerable virtue—in fact, it would improve this bill considerably—in giving some indication of policy costings prior to announcement and how the Treasury would go about costing particular policy initiatives. So my amendment to be moved later would enable an opposition or a government to approach Treasury with costings of their policies. Once they have those costings, they may wish to change the policies to reduce the cost or to add to the cost accordingly.

Senator Murray, for subclause 29(1)(b), you may wish to move the following words, which would overcome my anxiety. Next to `the Leader of the Opposition', you might insert `and any minor party leaders' and chop out `subject to subclause (4)'. After `request the responsible secretaries to prepare costings of', chop out `publicly announced opposition policies'. That should be `opposition and minor party policies'. That would overcome my problem with this block amendment that you have moved and would enable me to deal with this question, which is now being brought into this discussion, of `publicly announced'.

With `publicly announced' we are embarking on something quite new. There will not be any appeals after this process. You are in an election context; you submit your policies; they are costed and, bang, that is it. You live or die by those costings once they are published. To us in the opposition, the process of government is about looking at alternative costings for various policy options, selecting the appropriate policy option and going with that. That is what cabinets do. They have documents before them often setting out three or four proposals and they know what the variations of costs are. Governments have that advantage. So they can balance the policy objective against the cost and make a considered decision.

Oppositions will only be able to lodge their papers and have them costed and they will be stuck with that cost. If they knew what the cost was, the structure of the policy might have been a little different. It seems to us that that biases the fairness of this in favour of he or she who commands the greatest resources in the election context. That is why we are a bit leery about the publicly announced policies. Quite clearly, with policies that you might want to put, you do not want to be shot down once the costings are revealed; you want to be sensitive to those questions. That is why I have those amendments up my sleeve for a little later on down the Notice Paper.

What I am trying to do is get a signal from Senator Murray as to how that sits with him and whether the changes in the words in (b) to include `and any minor party leaders' along with `the Leader of the Opposition' would go to meeting his principle points. If it did, it would meet my anxieties as well. I apologise to the other minor party and the Independent here. If we settle this dialogue, then at least something can be sorted out in the chamber.

—I have some problems with the level of prescription and how this amendment might actually work in practice. SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 1, clause 29, page 22 (line 7), omit "publicly announced".
(9) Schedule 1, clause 29, page 22 (line 11), omit "publicly announced".

These amendments involve minor rewriting of the proposed costings regime in the current bill, but in the opposition's view involve some very key and fundamental aspects of the costing regime proposal. Part 8 contains the proposed costing regime; clause 29 is the major clause in part 8, which sets the ground rules for the costing of election commitments after an election has been called. As I will explain, the government has been very cunning in framing these provisions. They are pretending that they are improving access to the costing resource of the bureaucracy—namely, the economic departments—when in fact they are proposing to create a nightmare for the opposition.

As the bill currently stands, only publicly announced policies can be costed; that is, an opposition has to formally announce a policy before it is entitled to get a cost estimate from the bureaucracy. It may well be that the official costing indicates that the financial impact of the policy is significantly different from that assumed by the opposition. As such, it is not reasonable to force an opposition to publicly announce a policy about which it is unsure of the precise fiscal implications. So opposition amendments Nos 6 and 9 propose to delete the publicly announced test, which is completely unjustifiable and political in nature.

The fact is that this legislation massively favours the government, as they have access to these economic bureaucratic resources continuously by virtue of being the government. This means the government may refine their policies or proposed policies with the assistance of costing advice from these departments without either the policies or the costs of those proposed policies having to be made public. The effect of this is to force the opposition to release publicly its policies if they want them to be costed. This is fraught with danger for the opposition, as they could be forced to announce policy decisions on the basis of incomplete information, which could expose them to political debate and ridicule. This is of no advantage to the opposition but of tremendous benefit to the government. These amendments attempt to inject some equity and fairness when it comes to policy costings. We believe that both the government and the opposition should have access to advice on costings regardless of whether the policies have been publicly announced or not. They are my remarks in support of the amendments.

that is the Secretary to the Treasury or Finance in this case—
may decline to prepare costings under any request pursuant to this clause where they consider the request requires policy advice rather than merely the preparation of costings.

The debate that goes on at the ERC is about the policy objective and the price of it. Ministers in the ERC context vary the policy formations according to the price in order to get the best outcome—the best policy focus at the cheapest price. Why wouldn't they? That is their task.

The effect of what you say confirms my view that you are seeking a process which will assist oppositions to develop policies—fine, in itself—but seeking to involve Treasury in that process. Look at the battle which may well break out. The amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretaries may decline to prepare costings under any request pursuant to this clause where they consider the request requires policy advice rather than merely the preparation of costings.
The final policies which you wish to put to the electorate will presumably be a package which adds up, and the development of that is part of the policy process.

Senator, you seem to say that this gives government massive advantages. This bill is a major restriction on government. It is a charter of budget honesty to deal with the problems that emerged at the end of the last election when the Keating government hid the full facts of the fiscal position from the Australian public. This bill is a restriction, in that sense, on the powers of government. It is not conferring massive advantages on government. The last thing that you wanted was a full exposure of the fiscal position of the government of Australia before the election. On the Monday after the election it was available to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, but you were not prepared to share that information with the public.

This bill acts to restrict governments. This bill seeks to make governments, among other things, up‐front with the key information. You talk about conferring great advantages on government. That is not the case at all. If it was the case, your government would have grabbed it with both hands but your government could not have been further away from it.

So, Senator, we oppose these amendments. They will lead to the politicisation of the Public Service and they will lead to the involvement of the Treasury in the preparation of policies for the opposition. Let us think of the process that would be entailed. The reality of this is that governments and oppositions develop their publicly announced policies. If the Leader of the Opposition wishes, he can put his policy up for costing. It is not compulsory, not like the previous amendment. If he wishes, if he feels that it is to his advantage in the context of the election debate, he can put his policies up for costing. Of course, not all policies will be put up.
