I understand that and accept it, but you say, Minister, that the opposition can get its announced policies referred to the responsible secretaries to prepare costings now. That is what you are saying. Under this legislation, I thought you had indicated that the opposition would be able, during the election period, to get its publicly announced policies costed. A number of those policies are already publicly announced. Are you saying that the provisions of this bill would enable the opposition to get those policies costed?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—No? Under those circumstances, I do believe it would be of benefit to the public for the alternative government to have its policies which have not been announced costed. I have come to that conclusion from having listened to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —This has nothing to do with the time period. The bill allows policies to be costed during the election period.
—Publicly announced.

—Yes, publicly announced policies during the election period. That is what this bill is designed to do, on the option of the party, but this amendment does not seek to do that. This amendment seeks to have a range of policies, which are not publicly available, costed. Senator Cook nods his head. This would involve the Treasury in a policy process. We believe this would put great pressure on the Treasury and raise the spectre of the difficulties of maintaining a non-partisan Public Service—the politicisation which you referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: So this bill does not confer an advantage on government as distinct from the current practice. It gives an advantage to an opposition, if it so wishes, that it does not have under current practice and convention. But it does not allow the Public Service to be used by the opposition as a vehicle to develop its policies. Because of the very reason you raised in regard to an earlier item, this could lead to a politicisation process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Later in the bill clause 31 says that as soon as practicable after a policy costing request has been made, and before polling day, the costing has to be publicly released. I was concerned about the open-endedness, if you like, of Senator Cook's amendment. But the practical situation will be that there will be a cap. The opposition surely is not going to be requesting the responsible secretaries to prepare a costing on policies which they know will be publicly released. You are saying that they would be able to get a particular policy proposal costed and then another one that was slightly different. That would reveal to the public a very uncertain opposition, to say the least. I suppose that would be the practical cap that would limit the open-endedness of the proposal. We may have spent too much time on this. At this stage I am proposing to vote for the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —What people have to appreciate here is that the election is on, the clock is running, the people of Australia are thinking about who they are going to vote for and they have contending political parties making assertions about what they stand for and how much it will cost each other. That makes the Public Service, which is going to cost these proposals, a sort of arbiter. Who do you believe in this context when rival claims are being made? The Public Service neutrally comes forward and says, `These are the costs. These are the rules that will be in place.' The government says that this is not going to advantage government; that it will disadvantage government. All I can say is that your bill, Minister, which you have put here as government, does this. If you do not want it, do not put it here. But you have put it here, and all we are trying to do is make it work effectively and fairly. If you are going to impose on the Public Service the role of saying what people are most likely to believe—they are not most likely to believe politicians; they are most likely to believe a bureaucrat in those circumstances—then you have to have access to this, in the context of the election, fairly and equally.

SPEECH.PARA: We will have costed our programs, of course. But put yourself in this position. We have costed our programs and we submit them, believing that our figures are right, and Treasury comes out with a different figure. In an election context how can a political party argue with Treasury who is right and who is wrong about those figures and be believed? There has to be some way in which you can say, `This is the policy we are going to announce, and this is what we think the costings are—let us see what you say', so that the matter can be settled. Once you do it, once the figures are out, it is game, set and match. That is the figure as far as the public is concerned. The only fair way you can do this in an election context, you having put the Public Service in this position, is to confer on us the right of testing our costings before we announce. That is all we are saying. That is reasonable, that is fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard a more specious argument. You would think it was compulsory for you to put your policies to Treasury. It is not.
—If you don't put them to Treasury you are history anyway.

—You are not. You may well say that you are that confident because you have employed special research groups and you are happy to rely on the credibility of those groups. To be quite frank, our costings stood up and we did not use Treasury in the last election. So to put this in that context is profoundly wrong.
—If you don't put them to Treasury, forget it. No-one will believe you.

—It is entirely up to you whether you wish to put them to Treasury or not, but your other amendment allows policies not publicly released to be put to Treasury at any time. Senator Harradine may not be aware, but I am advised that in your future amendment you would be directly involving Treasury with a vast range of papers in the run-up to the election—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my understanding.
—It's not before the chamber in this debate now.

—Yes, but this is what this leads to. This is what you are seeking and this is what your agenda is. That is exactly what your agenda is and my understanding is that that is shown by your further amendments. So you are seeking to involve Treasury in the development of opposition policies, putting up non-publicly released policy from any time, from this point of time right through to the election. Senator Harradine raised the problem of the politicisation of the Public Service. He was dead right on that argument. This illustrates exactly what you are trying to do, and we are utterly opposed to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That puts another aspect to it. I thought that we were dealing with an amendment relating to during the election period. As I understand it, we are dealing with that on this particular matter. We will just have to look at the matters when they come up.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Alston did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Kernot.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Schedule 1, clause 29, page 22 (line 9), omit ", subject to subclause (4),".
(10) Schedule 1, clause 29, page 22 (lines 19 to 23), omit subclause (4).

The opposition also seeks to amend the bill to remove from the Prime Minister the discretion granted in clause 29 of the bill to decline a request from the opposition for a costing to be made by the relevant departmental secretary. It is indeed extraordinary that subclause 29(4) of the bill proposes that the Prime Minister must receive a copy of the request for the costings from the Leader of the Opposition which must include the relevant policy prior to any transmission to the bureaucrats.

In addition, the Prime Minister will have the power to receive a copy of the opposition's policies and then refuse a request for them to be costed—a very powerful weapon for a Prime Minister to have during an election campaign. Let us not forget also that such a denial would be made when the government is in caretaker mode.

For these reasons we feel that it is entirely inappropriate for the government, through the Prime Minister, to have such a discretion on opposition policy costings. If costings are to be done, they must be done free of government influence and free of the perception of influence in the interests of a proper and open public debate and not one controlled by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree. I think it is extraordinary. Considering the minister indicated that he did not want this to be a party political process, I find this inclusion in the bill extraordinary and I will not be supporting the government's approach here. I will be supporting the opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party I know in the 13 years that it was in power would never have contemplated throwing out what is part of the Westminster system and an important convention in relation to contact between departmental officials and the opposition, particularly during a caretaker phase. I am flabbergasted that the Australian Labor Party would move this, but it is in line with a series of amendments they have moved to this bill which help draw me to the conclusion that they are not serious about this. They are so flippant about these matters after having deceived Australian electors for so long that, given the opportunity to bring a sensible charter of budget honesty regime into Australia, they are happy to play cheap politics and to chop it up.

SPEECH.PARA: To go back to the five-day rule, a fiscal policy document having to be prepared in five days is just absolutely impractical. I know very well that Senator Cook and senior Labor Party figures who have been either finance ministers, as Mr Beazley was, or Treasurer, as Mr Willis was, know very well in their own hearts and from their own experience that there is no way this could be done.

Similarly, with this amendment they are prepared to throw out what has always been an important convention. If the Prime Minister of the day were to refuse a request by the Leader of the Opposition to have costings prepared, the Prime Minister would of course wear enormous political odium. That would be the issue of the day in the campaign. I am sure Senator Cook would not deny that.

This is a practicality. It is important, in the coalition view at least in this chamber, to maintain that convention, to maintain the caretaker conventions, to maintain the convention that in caretaker mode contact with departmental officials is maintained through the Prime Minister. I repeat: for a Prime Minister to refuse the Leader of the Opposition's request would become a matter of great political moment and debate which would probably dominate that period of the campaign. As all of us know, winning the campaign day by day, week by week is critical in these election periods and a Prime Minister deciding not to agree to refer a matter would of course be viewed very poorly by the electorate.

In conclusion, the coalition treats this seriously. In contrast to the opposition, we treat this Charter of Budget Honesty Bill very seriously. We think it is an important improvement in transparency in government in Australia. It is something that Labor failed to bring in in 13 years. In fact, quite to the contrary, when they had the opportunity to say to the Australian people what the fiscal outlook was just prior to the last election they blatantly lied to them to the tune of $10.3 billion—a massive percentage of the national economy and particularly Commonwealth spending.

Quite frankly, watching the Labor Party chop this bill to pieces with silly and impractical amendments is really analogous to seeing Christopher Skase try to rewrite the bankruptcy laws and/or the extradition laws. That is analogous to seeing the Labor Party play with this bit of legislation. They cannot come to this place with credibility on the question of budget honesty. To propose to tear up this convention again is just a reaffirmation of what they bring to this whole bill: they are not serious, not fair dinkum, but prepared to tear up centuries‐old conventions that have served the people very well and are very important conventions. The coalition will vigorously oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe I am missing something here. We are dealing with opposition amendments 7 and 10. Subclause 29(2) said—I will add a couple of words if I may—that a request relating to a publicly announced policy is to be in writing and to outline fully the policy to be costed, giving relevant details, and state the purpose or intention of the policy. To some extent, that is not a huge problem because it would have been publicly announced. However, the Senate, in its wisdom, has agreed that it should not be publicly announced.

SPEECH.PARA: Imagine the opposition last time round saying, `Dear Mr Keating, we've got this lovely idea about Telstra. We want to sell one-third of it and give one-eighth of the third we sell to create a new national heritage fund. Please would you ask the Treasury to cost the policy for us. Here's the full details of it. This is the purpose or intention of it. PS, don't use this before the election to plan your counter campaign.' It is so ludicrous as to be extraordinary.

I can see your difficulty, Parliamentary Secretary, in that you devised this bill with the intention of dealing with publicly announced policies. But the Senate does not want it to be publicly announced. I say to you that, as a result, it would be very damaging to any opposition leader and would negate the whole purpose of election campaigning and would encourage them not to give you their policies to be costed if we proceeded on this basis. Unless you have astonishingly good reasons to counter my views on this, we too will support the opposition amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding what Senator Murray said, I felt that the contribution made by the parliamentary secretary was apt. The Labor Party has to get over this. There are conventions in respect of this matter and in respect of contacts with public servants that have been about for a couple of centuries. I would suggest that that is a matter which we should not transgress. I agree with what Senator Campbell has said about the unlikelihood of the Prime Minister of the day refusing to have that request passed on to the appropriate secretaries. I am not supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with things that have never been associated with conventions because they are new. The charter of budget honesty is new and the proposal for non-government parties to be able to access that is new. In that sense, this particular amendment goes to the point of whether or not something new which has been added in a new bill does have to go through the Prime Minister. That is my understanding of what has been asked here.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Senate has said that the policies that can be costed do not have to be announced seems to be an impossible situation. How could you have a requirement that you have to go through the Prime Minister to get a costing approval and at the same time say that we allow you to get a non-announced policy? It seems to me that this is one where there is not necessarily a convention. There obviously has to be a mode of operation for the Treasury to allow something new, which this is, to operate.

I can hear what Senator Harradine is saying but I do not think this is necessarily a problem because we are dealing with things that have never happened before within the Australian Treasury and there has to be some means by which we can facilitate them happening. To require that the Prime Minister signs off for the opposition's costing of an unannounced policy is a ridiculous situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a couple of words. I acknowledge what Senator Harradine has said. I want to comment on his remarks and the remarks of the parliamentary secretary. There is a parliamentary convention here. The parliamentary convention is that the Prime Minister and the ministers sworn in are the ones who direct the Public Service. What this bill does though during the caretaker period when the Prime Minister and his ministers are unable to direct the Public Service is impose an obligation on the Public Service to do certain things. The method of transmitting that obligation is the Prime Minister for the sake of the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: But the convention is struck down in most of its effect other than its appearance by virtue of the caretaker period. When we are in an election period, the government disengages itself from the Public Service during that period. The Public Service goes off and writes up its wish lists of things for the incoming government.

The direction of the Public Service during this period by the minister or the Prime Minister is not competent. They cannot direct them to do this, that or the other. If this bill is carried, then they have the power to direct them to do things in this bill. That is new. That changes the quality and nature of the convention. The quality and nature of the convention is changed because the government wants it to be changed—this government wants it to be changed; it has introduced this bill. When we talk about the convention, we cannot talk about it in pure form because this very bill changes the nature and quality of it. That is my first point, and I think that is a very relevant point.

The second point is that the parliamentary secretary says that, of course, the Prime Minister will pass on the request of the Leader of the Opposition. To do so would be to create a major element of political abuse. Let me come back to that in a minute. What the parliamentary secretary is saying is that the Prime Minister will obey an unspoken intent here that he should pass on honestly to the Public Service the full content of the Leader of the Opposition's policies. There is recognition of the fact that, of course, he will but maybe there will be an argument that maybe he will not.

This amendment would put the Prime Minister above that. If the parliamentary secretary is right, and I hope he is, for all prime ministers henceforth, whoever they might be, justice would be done. But with my amendment justice would also be seen to be done. This distracting debate in public during an election campaign, about whether or not all the policies have been passed on in the manner that they have been submitted or whether something has been lost in the translation, would not occur with this amendment.

By carrying this amendment we remove from the election campaign that type of public debate which could potentially clog up the ability of the electorate to come to a very clear and focused understanding of what is involved. The `be seen to be done' part is as important as being done. If the parliamentary secretary is right, it will be so for this Prime Minister and all the prime ministers yet to be elected for as long as this bill, if it becomes an act, remains an act.

BREAK.PARA: The third point I make is that we are not having a discussion here. This subclause requires it to be written so there is not contact between the opposition and the Public Service. There is a written document that is transmitted. That, I think, may assuage some of the concerns.

I return to the point that, yes, there is a convention. This bill changes the nature of that convention by imposing new obligations on the Public Service during the period of caretakership, when the convention is the Prime Minister and the ministers cannot direct the Public Service. The very quality of the convention being defended at the parliamentary table by the secretary is changed. Let's get the debate simple and keep it focused. Let's remove the argument as to whether or not the Prime Minister has done the right thing or whether the Prime Minister has somehow, in the transmission of the request, mangled the policy details.
Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be proceeding with opposition amendment No. 8.

—I have a proposal to make. I have listened to what has been said by Senator Cook. What I am concerned about simply is the well‐known tradition of government in Australia and elsewhere in respect of the Public Service. What I would like to see is an amendment made—and I might be able to draw one up overnight—so as to ensure that clause 29(4) requires the Prime Minister immediately to refer the request to the responsible secretaries. It may well be that there is a need to so redefine the request for the purposes of that referral in a manner that differs slightly from that contained in clause 29(2). I am just throwing that up that we might be able to have a look at an amendment overnight that would be able to satisfy the point that was made by the parliamentary secretary and deal with it tomorrow, hopefully with more rapidity than it has been dealt with today.

—I must say I am always attracted to finding a way through these mazes, if there is a way which can be found. I take on board what Senator Harradine has said. I would certainly like to hear an in principle, if you like, commitment to that course from the government before I go any further. I wonder whether I can now put that question to the parliamentary secretary. In view of the suggestion made by Senator Harradine, what is the government's response? In asking that question the minor parties clearly would want to give a response as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that someone with the long parliamentary experience that Senator Harradine has had would put a matter like this to the government—in fact, an invitation—and we would refuse it. We certainly will have a look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: I must reiterate that we believe that the balance of the words in subclause (4), which says that the Prime Minister may then agree to refer it to the responsible secretaries, leaves it in the hands of the Prime Minister. It is a discretion.

As I have said, it would be a brave Prime Minister—in the words of Yes, Minister—who would not refer on such a request expeditiously. I do not share Senator Cook's concern that these matters being matters for debate is a bad thing. I do not think they would become matters for debate. Senator Harradine, we will have a look at it. But I do not give you any false hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a request to Senator Harradine that when he is working overnight on this issue—
—I think the opposition will be; I will not be.

—Whoever works overnight on this issue should have regard to the fairness of subclause 29(2), in its completeness, where a policy announcement has not been publicly announced and would therefore be early ammunition in the hands of the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I caught Senator Harradine's side comment when Senator Murray was speaking, but I think it was to the tune that he will not be working on it overnight. I am certainly happy to work on it overnight. I have a recollection of the 1983 federal election. In the course of that federal election, a major bushfire broke out in the Adelaide Hills
—And in Victoria.
—And in Victoria. I think the election campaign was adjourned for a short time in the national interest because the nation was concerned about this calamity.

SPEECH.PARA: It could be—I am not wanting to construct fanciful scenarios—that the opposition's request gets delayed on the in‐tray while we go and deal with a national calamity. Or it could be not that the full request is not passed on but it is passed on more slowly or for whatever other reasons. The thing that attracts me to this outcome, in view of the loss of my earlier amendment, is that there is a possibility that there is no discretion on behalf of the Prime Minister. So the argument about whether or not the full policy details of the opposition were passed on does not arise.

The purpose of the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill strikes me as being to try to simplify the issues and provide greater transparency for the public to discriminate with their vote over the economic implications of policy. As it stands, there is a possibility of a red herring being drawn across the path. They happen in election campaigns all the time. If this is about simplicity and transparency, then I think there is a real case to look at the automatic transmission that has been referred to by Senator Harradine.

If one wants to be exhaustive about it, there is not just the question of the conduct of the Prime Minister; documents can get lost, be misplaced or there can be other problems within the office. At the end of the day the Prime Minister has to take responsibility for that because it is his office. Therefore it is an extension of him. Just to get this issue out of the debate I think would be a very good thing. Therefore, I am prepared to constructively apply myself to finding what particular words might be consistent with Senator Harradine's remarks. I hope that tomorrow we can proceed expeditiously and get this bill through.
Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In commencing my remarks, I thank Senator Marise Payne for making way for me in this adjournment debate this evening, which allows me to raise a matter of genuine concern. Earlier today in the other place the Chair of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund tabled the committee's 10th report. I understand that it will be tabled in the Senate tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments tonight relate to the behaviour of the Labor Party over this particular report. In my brief time in the Senate I have understood there to be a convention that one is not to divulge any aspects of committee's private workings or of its report until, in the case of a report, the report is tabled. This rule has been breached by the Labor Party.

Indeed, those of us who read the Canberra Times and the Australian Financial Review this morning have found that there were apparently well sourced stories as to the minority report. I am also reliably informed that the media got copies of the minority report at 10 a.m. today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it seems to me from what you have said already that this may well be a matter of privilege which, under standing order 81, ought to be brought before the Senate in a particular way. It says:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator intending to raise a matter of privilege shall notify the President, in writing, of the matter . . .
And there are some other aspects of standing order 81.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, all I am seeking to do is place on the public record certain activities that I have become aware of in the course of today.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I was going to rise to my feet just as you intervened. I was listening carefully to what Senator Abetz was saying. He had actually got to the point where he had reflected upon members in the other place and particularly members of the Australian Labor Party. As yet he has not named them, but he certainly referred to ALP members and, if my recollection is correct, ALP members of the committee. On that basis, I would put to you that, firstly, he is not entitled to reflect in that way because he is clearly going to go on and make certain allegations—if he has not in fact already implied them—regarding the leaking of a report. It is difficult for me to comment further on the point of order without getting into a debate about the issue anyway, but I would suggest that the point you have just made is more appropriate and that Senator Abetz should be ruled out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult, Senator Abetz, in that standing order 81 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . a matter of privilege, unless suddenly arising—
and I understood you to suggest that this was something that had happened this morning in the other place. It then says:
. . . shall not be brought before the Senate except in accordance with the following procedures:
Just from what I have heard so far, it would sound to me that it may well be a matter of privilege and therefore ought to be brought before the Senate in accordance with standing order 81.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on that point the question then arises as to whether one is to draw that conclusion as to whether there has already been a breach of privilege by these matters that I am simply raising in my speech this evening. I was intending to canvass the behaviour of Labor Party members in relation to the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. If I cannot deal with issues that may pertain to a breach of privilege, I will not refer to them. But there are certain matters that I wish to raise that, although I might have certain suspicions as to whether or not they are a breach of privilege, are, with respect, Madam President, matters that I simply want to place on the public record as having occurred. I will do so without necessarily drawing any conclusions that in fact that behaviour constitutes a breach of privilege. I thought that, if I were to conduct my speech in that fashion, I would not fall foul of the standing orders as indicated in the comments that you and Senator Forshaw have quite rightly raised. If I am wrong as to that and I cannot canvass those matters at all, that is fine. I will simply refer to the other concerning behaviour of members of the Labor Party in the conduct of this inquiry.

—I think that on that basis you perhaps could proceed, but I shall listen carefully. You must be very mindful of the provisions of standing order 81, which specifically indicate that, if it is related to privilege, it must be dealt with in a certain manner.
—Some of the matters that I may raise, Madam President, may lead honourable senators to draw a particular conclusion.
—I think you should not put them in that fashion, Senator, because that would be, I believe, raising a matter of privilege.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I am just trying to find the relevant standing order—
—Eighty‐one, Senator.
—As I understand it, a senator is not entitled to impute improper motives to either a member of this Senate or of the other place. It is difficult to know without hearing what Senator Abetz says.
—That is a different standing order—193.

—I know. That is the one that I was referring to. The problem here is that, by the time Senator Abetz gets through his speech, it is clear that that is what he will have in fact done. He has already headed down that path.
—I cannot conclude that at this point. Senator Abetz could proceed, being especially mindful of both standing order 81 and standing order 193.
—Madam President.
—Do you have a point of order, Senator Crowley?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CROWLEY

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure it is a point of order. I seek your clarification. In the light of what you have said, I think one could almost conclude that Senator Abetz has now got no other option but to proceed in the light of your advice. The reason you made that interjection, as I understand it, was that Senator Abetz's opening comments left no other conclusion than the suggestion that this was a matter of breach of privilege. My concern, Madam President, is that you have made your comments in the light of Senator Abetz's opening remarks—he did not draw attention to this matter; nobody else did but you. You in fact mentioned the caution in the light of what Senator Abetz has already said.

INTERJECT.PARA: I do not understand now how Senator Abetz can proceed, having opened the batting with the kind of comment that caused you to draw attention to your concern. That is now a given. How can he proceed, having made those opening comments, without actually making further reference to the point that you have already drawn our attention to?

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Madam President. I can understand the sensitivity of the Labor Party on this matter because, quite frankly, if I were on the back bench and had seen the conduct of the shadow Attorney‐General and shadow spokesman for Aboriginal affairs today, I would share the sorts of concerns that Senator Crowley is undoubtedly raising.

BREAK.PARA: But the situation is, Madam President, that the matters I indicated I wanted to raise were matters of a genuine importance. I indicated that earlier today the parliamentary joint committee on native title's report—the 10th report—had been tabled in the other place. I then wanted to relate my comments to the behaviour of the Labor Party over this report. That has created, with respect, Madam President, the opening for me to comment about their behaviour during the committee inquiry itself, their behaviour at public hearings and their behaviour over a whole range of other issues.

I know that Senator Crowley wants me to sit down because it will hurt the Australian Labor Party undoubtedly when it all comes out, as it will in due course. I would have thought that my opening remarks should not prohibit me from being allowed to make further comments about the Labor Party's conduct throughout the whole conduct of the 10th report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I draw your attention again to standing order 193(3) in terms of reflecting on the motives or behaviour of senators or members of either house.

—Madam President, as I read that it tells me that senators shall not use offensive words against either house of parliament `and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections' et cetera. I would have thought that was a given and, at this stage, I do not think I have even come close to it, although I may well have been justified if I had done so.

—The other issue that I must raise, Senator, is that I am advised that a letter has been sent to me on this matter, in which case it is a matter on which I should report to the Senate when I have had an opportunity to read the letter. I would not think it appropriate to be canvassing the issue between the writing of the letter and the response.

—Thank you, Madam President. The 10th report of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund was a matter that caused the committee a lot of concern and a lot of work. The secretary of the committee, Mr Peter Grundy, and his secretariat staff ought to be commended for the wonderful work that they did in arranging this.

BREAK.PARA: It may not be known to the public that the Labor Party set out, from the beginning, indicating that they would put in a dissenting report before the first word of evidence had been heard. As a result, it was agreed that the Labor Party would have made available to them funding for separate staff members to write the dissenting report for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Yes, so a specific funding allocation of $10,000 was made by way of salary plus travel allowance expenses. In very rough terms, I calculate that that would be about $20,000 worth, which comes to about $120 per page of the dissenting report.

BREAK.PARA: Throughout the hearing we had behaviour which, I have to say, was a matter of great concern to me; the way that the Labor Party behaved itself during the conduct of these inquiries, with quite inflammatory interjections—
