BREAK.PARA: The conduct of this committee was a most difficult one because it was clearly done in a highly charged political atmosphere in which the Labor Party, as I have indicated earlier, had indicated where they were coming from before the first word of evidence had been given to the committee. As a result, resources were made available for them to be able to write a separate and dissenting report. It is interesting to note, having spoken at a number of functions along with the honourable member for Banks, Mr Melham, the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the sort of quite inflammatory language that was employed on those occasions in relation to the government's 10‐point plan and its proposed legislation to deal with those 10 points.

It is interesting, for example, that during some of the hearings the suggestion of allowing pastoralists to engage in farm tourism was seen as being quite outrageous. In their report, guess what they suggest: that we adopt the definition as contained in the Northern Territory legislation for pastoral leases and what they are able to do. Do you know what that includes? Farm tourism. So, having inflamed the public's mind in relation to a number of issues, when actually confronted with what would have to be done they then realised that some of their alleged concerns had to be put aside and that they would have to agree with us.

They also engaged in what could only be described as a dramatic rewrite of history; revisionism at its best. We are told, for example, in their executive summary that the government of the day and the Australian Democrats drafted the legislation—this is referring to the Native Title Act 1993—in open and direct consultation with all the stakeholders. That clearly was not the case. Indeed, Senator Barney Cooney chaired the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee which dealt with the question of the Native Title Act back in 1993, and do you know what it found? It found that a number of Aborigines themselves, groups and individuals, complained to the committee that a deal was done with the then Prime Minister and that they were not part of it; it was a secret deal.

If you talk to pastoralists like Mr Rick Farley from the National Farmers Federation, I do not think that he would believe, nor would the National Farmers Federation these days, that they were in fact taken in and consulted to the extent that the Labor Party would now have us believe. The question then is, what about the mining industry? Were they part of those consultations? Were the state governments part of those consultations? Were local government part of those consultations? Indeed, was the opposition, the alterna tive government, part of those consultations? Of course, the answer is no.
Despite all this time discussing this issue of the 10‐point plan, the Labor Party in their minority recommendations tell us this:
The recommendations set out below are not exhaustive.

The Labor Party still have not got their house in order on this important social issue. They still have not been able to get it together. How long do they need to be able to get their house in order in relation to this important policy issue? They did have the benefit of some extra advice, which I must say is really an acknowledgment by the Labor Party that they were not sufficiently skilled to write their own dissenting report, that they needed that extra professional help paid for by the taxpayers. I must say that all the dissenting reports I have been part of have been penned either by me or fellow senators from this side; they have not been courtesy of an extra bucket load of money from the taxpayers to assist in that regard. But you would have thought, with that extra help just to push them along a bit, they might have been able to come down with a firm policy position. But, no, they have not been able to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you write the 10‐point plan yourself?

—Senator Forshaw makes another one of those inane interjections, which really does give rise to wonder about his current state. I look forward to making further contributions on this report, and I especially look forward to the outcome of the privileges matters that will undoubtedly be raised in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I want tonight to draw the attention of the Senate to a speech I was able to give in India recently. I was asked if I would care to give a keynote speech at a women and governance conference in Delhi to celebrate 50 years of Indian independence. I must say I was very honoured to have the privilege of being able to do that. I had visited Delhi late last year and met with a number of the women's organisations in India, particularly in and around Delhi. One such group was the Women's Political Watch, headed by a wonderful woman called Veena Nayyar. I was delighted when she wrote and asked me if I would care to come to Delhi in September to contribute to this conference. There were representatives at this conference from all around the world. Some 250 or 300 delegates were there. I must say it was a most successful conference indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: It comes at a very good time in India, because they have before their parliament a bill to reserve 33⅓ per cent of their federal parliamentary places for women. In the lead‐up to the last election all different parties agreed to this proposal as part of their platform, but they had not reckoned with the political ability of many of the women in India, who have seen this piece of legislation actually brought into the parliament, from where it was referred off to a committee—a fairly standard deferral procedure. Subsequently it has come back into the Indian parliament. I might stand corrected on some of these actual procedures through the parliament because their ways of dealing with matters are somewhat different from our parliaments.

What has happened now is that the gentlemen in the parliament in India are of the view that of course we all agree in principle with this point, but let us talk about the actual figure: `What support is there for 20 per cent? Do we hear any votes for 15 per cent?' So in fact what they are doing is bargaining down the 33⅓ per cent. My comment on that is that they should know that this is a parliament and not a bazaar when it comes to voting for the 33⅓ per cent reservation.

I will continue to watch closely the outcome of this piece of legislation in the Indian parliament. I might say that at the more regional and local government level they have had reservations in place for 50 years for different groups of people, in particular untouchables and what are known as OBCs, other backward castes, and indeed women. Some 800,000 women at the local level have been able to take public office because of a reservations bill for local government, and some 75,000 Indian women have taken the role of chair in a number of those local organisations.

So it is certainly true that, given the opportunity to participate, to be represented and to represent a different voice, women have been more than able to rise to that occasion in India. When I visited Delhi last year I met with Madam Heptulla and a number of women from the different parties in the Indian parliament. All the women from all the different parties in the Indian parliament are united absolutely in their support for increased representation of women in the parliament. So it will be very interesting to see how that bill goes.

It was also very interesting to point out that in the Australian parliament such a process would never, ever occur. No incumbent Liberal government would make a bill to reserve places that would set requirements for the opposition Labor Party and no Labor Party in government would likewise make a bill that would reserve and make requirements on an opposition party. I pointed out that our way of doing it in Australia is different—it is through our parties. In my own party, the Labor Party, it is done through a rule change that now requires that by the year 2002 at least 35 per cent of safe seats shall be occupied by women.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not doing too well, though.

—Thank you for that timely interjection, Senator. Following the very recent election in South Australia, my own state, 10 out of 21 of the Legislative Assembly Labor Party members are women. That is the highest percentage of women in any parliament anywhere at any time. So it is quite clearly a process that is well under way within the Labor Party and, as I said in my speech, Senator, well under way within the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party was very successful at the last election. Senator Newman insists that it was all done without affirmative action. I like the way Senator Newman, for example, says, `Well, we had no affirmative action. It is just that the Liberal Party advertised widely to invite women to come forward as possible candidates.' They were also assisted with meetings to teach them how to dress and speak publicly, how the process operates and so on—by any definition an affirmative action program. I say congratulations to the Liberal Party. You were slow to catch up with us and you passed us with flying colours at the last election.

I also pointed out to the women in India that, while I have acknowledged on the public record many times my congratulations to the Liberal Party for its success in achieving an increased number of women at the last election, every day across this chamber I argue and fight with those women as they all vote for the systematic dismantling of all the programs and processes that we put in place to assist women. I also pointed out that that is exactly the case for Pauline Hanson. Here is another woman elected into our parliament. Even though I support the election of women, every day I will totally oppose the ridiculous, malicious and ignorant comments of Pauline Hanson about the nature of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, in the way you have just expressed yourself you are reflecting on a member of the other place.

—Thank you, Madam President. It is difficult to know how to say that I utterly disagree with the things Ms Hanson says while at the same time acknowledging the increased representation of women in our parliament. I made these points and many others in the course of my speech and I have to say it was a delight to be able to acknowledge—
—It was a pretty good speech, even though you say so yourself.

—You can read it and decide for yourself, Senator. I do not know that I would rank it that way but, if you want me to, I could show you the cables from India that would give you an objective assessment. They were certainly full of praise in their acknowledgment of this contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I drew some references from Marilyn Waring's book, Three Masquerades. In her first chapter about the difficulties she experienced being a woman in the New Zealand parliament she said that it was very tough and that there were lots of very lonely and difficult times for those women who were breaking new ground in parliament. In some ways I think that she describes a piece of history that is largely gone. Certainly the point that I wanted to make in India was that the women coming into Australian parliamentarians now are not the first. Madam President, you and I and others have broken the first ground, as have some before us. Our generation in particular has made it perfectly clear that women can come into this parliament and cope very well—excellently, in fact. Indeed the electorate have made it very clear that they are very happy to support women across the political spectrum. They are a very attractive addition in the electorate. People like what women represent and how women are able to listen to what the electorate has to say and bring different things into the political agenda in this place—different emphases and points are debated.

When I was at a conference in New York on governance all of the countries present at that conference argued very strongly the importance of democracy and the move by many nations towards democracy. One critical part of that is the representation element of it. If you are serious about representation in democracy then you have to move to 50 per cent of women in our parliaments. Indeed, that ought be the goal, and indeed that will happen. All it will take, as I said in my speech, is `time and our daughters'. Indeed, our daughters will come into the parliaments knowing that they will be welcomed by us. They will certainly be welcomed by me, but I think that most of us in this parliament would welcome the younger generation of women, along with men—standing side by side, 50 per cent of each, I hope, in the not too distant future.

Those are some of the points I made. I have not gone through all of them. I was able to tell some stories about our parliament, particularly one about Hansard—it is a record I remember very well. When I came into parliament I had learnt from Gough Whitlam the habit of reading the daily Hansard and I noted that no matter how many of us used non‐sexist language Hansard used to edit it to the male third person. It was not until we stood in this place and asked Mr President to look at that that Hansard changed and finally became a record of what was actually said in our parliament.
I seek leave to have my speech incorporated in Hansard. I did ask Senator Ian Campbell if that was okay and he gave me approval.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
WOMEN IN GOVERNANCE: CRITICAL ISSUES CHALLENGES AND STRATEGIES
INTRODUCTION

Thank you—what a great honour it is to be here and to be taking part in this conference. I visited Delhi late in 1996 and met many women's groups and parliamentarians. One such group was "Women's Political Watch"—imagine my surprise and delight when Veena Nayyar invited me to both attend and give this speech.

Not only am I honoured to be a speaker at this International Women's Conference, I am also honoured to be here in the year which celebrates 50 years of Indian Independence—a half-century full of achievements and an inspiration to us all. Congratulations.

I congratulate you too on holding this conference as part of your 50th year celebrations and I congratulate and thank those of you, especially Veena Nayyar, who have organised this important event. Indian women were a vital part of the struggle for independence. It is very appropriate that a women's conference in this year reflect on the participation of women both then and now, to acknowledge their contribution and to outline what still remains to be done for and by women.

There is much to say about women and their role in India. Let me limit it to two comments. India has provided one of the first women Prime Ministers, Indira Gandhi. Many Indian women are known world wide as strong and brave and clever and able. On the other side of the coin, thousands of Indian women live in poverty, they are not literate and they work very hard all their short lives to provide subsistence, food, clothing and housing for their families.

The picture is different for women in Australia and I will return to that shortly. What is the same however, is the divide between some women who are well off and who contribute to our parliament and the many who struggle daily to make ends meet.
Increased Status of Women-Greatest achievement of the 20th Century

I want to begin by telling you about an Indian Gentleman I met here in December last year. He asked me, "what I thought was the greatest achievement of the 20th Century." I thought for a while and answered that perhaps the technological advancements of international communications. He replied that he thought it was the improved Status of Women. Initially I was surprised, albeit pleased at his answer, but the more I have thought about it, the more I have come to utterly agree.

The United Nations declared 1975-1985 the Women's decade. "International Women's Year" marked the beginning of the worldwide awareness of the social, political, economic and cultural concerns of women.

We have come a long way in the heightened awareness of the wide range of problems that women encounter in their daily lives. There is not a country in the world that has gone untouched by the emergence of `women's issues'. Laws, political systems, and economic and cultural institutions have been changed everywhere.

100 years ago very few women in the world had the right to vote, the right to property and the right to an education; to learn to read or write, to go to university, the right to protection and safety from violence at home or in society, the right to have a say, the right to health care or reasonable housing. While most women worked, it was in unpaid work and low paid work in poor conditions. A century on, things have certainly changed. Women around the world now have the right to vote, to have property and money of their own, to attend university, to go to school, to read and write, to have reasonable health care and housing. Laws protect them against violence in the home and in the street and some of them are paid equally to men for their work.
Women have gone from being 2nd class citizens or not citizens at all, to participating and recognised members of our societies.

Despite these achievements and indeed, perhaps because of them, we are clearer than ever of the many, many women who still have little access to those gains. 500,000 women around the world still die each year from child birth and related causes. We recognise the challenges for women—to achieve fair representation and a fair voice and fair participation in our society, so that they can read and write and provide for their children and live longer, healthier and productive lives.
In Australia, under the Labor Government in the 80's we produced a Women's Agenda called:- A Choice, a Say and a Fair Go. It still describes the challenge very well and very succinctly.
Women in Governance
What is the role and responsibility of governments and why should women be part of it?

Our national parliaments represent and are the pinnacles of power in society. They make the laws, they determine economic outcomes, they defend the country. More and more nations around the world are moving to become democracies—governments of the people, by the people, for the people. They are representative of the people—their voice, their protector their advocate.

I recently attended a conference in New York, sponsored by UNDP, looking at governance and women's participation. It looked at other things but I will confine myself to these dimensions only. I was given the role of rapporteur in one forum and this honour meant that 1, by and large, had to listen and not speak—a blessing, some would say.

I took notes as country after country approved democracy as the way forward. I believe this world wide move to democracy is another vital feature of the 20th Century. The session on Gender Representation women's participation—was somewhat less fulsome in its approval of this principle. While no delegate was fool enough—or brave enough—to oppose the idea, there were reservations. These were best summarised by one country proposing that we should proceed with caution because "women were their own worst enemy". Fortunately and admirably, indeed succinctly an Australian colleague, Barry Jones MP said in response: "Not while men are alive!"

It is beyond debate, to my mind, that if we promote democracy, particularly its representative dimension, then we must accept 50% of women in our parliaments and nothing less. This must be the goal for the next century into the next millennium. Until women stand equal alongside men, we will not have achieved!
At 50% we women are giving away 1-2%, but most of us will settle for that.

Joan Kirner, Premier of Victoria in Australia, in a speech The Politics of Learning in Australia 1994—An Open Moment, to mark a century of women's vote in South Australia, spells out why this fair representation of women is right and necessary—
"- women matter as much as men do;
- women have the right to determine their own lives
- women's experiences matter;
- women should be able to freely describe and share these experiences;
- women's experiences should be part of decision making;
- women should have equality and equity in terms of education and training, employment, safety, health, resources and in representation"
That says it all. I believe the time of debating the representation of women is past. We must take it as a given and now take steps to achieve it.

I also acknowledge the 1,000's of women who have carried that debate over the last century, who have spent hours and buckets of spit proving that women are not second class citizens, that they do have brains, that they can think logically, that they are creative, that intuition is a gift not a liability and that emotions are rational. I include myself in that group and I say that I will never again be distracted into debating it—clever male tactic though it has been. Now I say "That is not the question. The question is how we achieve fair 50% representation."
I want to turn now to our experience in Australia, by way of illustrating some very important points about critical issues, challenges and strategies.

When the Labor Government was elected in 1983, it came into office with a platform that included a document Towards Equality. That document spelled out 42 proposals to advance the position of Women in Australian society. It included sex discrimination legislation, affirmative action proposals, child care, women's health programs, equal employment opportunity programs, anti domestic violence campaigns, educational programs for girls into non-traditional areas like maths and science, mature aged entry into university, equal pay provisions, and women and sport programs, to name a few. It also listed a women's perspective in non-specific to women areas like superannuation and medicare—our national health program, industry policy and family friendly work place reforms. The policy document also stressed the importance of establishing government mechanisms to defend and extend women's participation and protection. The Office of the Status of Women was brought in/elevated to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. Women's desks were established in a number of departments. There was to be a Women's Budget Paper released each year with the government budget. That document was an account of how every department's spending was directed to needs of women. A Women's Agenda was formulated and published and an expanded National Women's Advisory Body was established. National Women's Peak Organisations received government funding and elected women representatives to advise government on further improvements for women.
I have outlined just some of the proposals and achievements of the Labor government for women.

I do that to share with you some of the achievements—all those things listed were implemented—and to highlight the road we took in Australia. Our road was in and through the government in the main. We used government legislation, programs, and funding to improve things for women. We also used government to require things of the private sector—Affirmative Action for example. Our Sex Discrimination Act prohibited discrimination on grounds of sex, marriage and sexual preference in housing, finance and employment. We also promoted community participation and representation to keep government focused, but our priority emphasis was through Government and we had women in government to argue for these things on the political agenda.

I remember our surprise of hearing an American Congressional visitor commenting wistfully on her envy of our achievement and her noting how different it was from the path women in the U.S. were taking.
I was surprised because I had thought all women were going along this path. I realised no, and that is one reason why I outline it here to-day.

It is one path—but not the only path. It is also important to note the achievements of the Labor Government, because, with the change to the Liberal Coalition Government in the 1996 election, many of the achievements and gains have now been undone or removed.
Things we thought were set in stone, things women have worked and struggled for over very many years, have in 18 months of the new government, disappeared.

Many child care centres have closed and child care fees have increased by $20 or more per week, per child; equity funding for education has largely been removed; the women's health program is being rolled into one public health program and its funding cut by 10%; the affirmative action agency no longer requires businesses and universities to report annually of their advancements for women; legal aid money, so important for women, has been dramatically reduced, the cost of court appearances has been significantly increased; up-front fees for post graduate study have been introduced, significantly impacting on women. The commitment to equal pay has been removed from the Industrial Relations Legislation; the Office of the Status of Women has had its funding savagely cut by 40%, we have retained the Sex Discrimination Commissioner in our Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission only after a public brawl and profound lobbying;. . . and the Women's Budget no longer is produced.
Just when other countries, e.g. South Africa, are proposing to copy Australia and introduce their own Women's Budget our Women's Budget is removed.

When the Australian government presented its report on its Gender Equity Policy to the UN Committee on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women in July this year, the UN Committee made the following comments:

"The Committee was alarmed by policy changes that apparently slowed or reversed, Australia's progress in achieving equality between women and men, such as in housing and child-care programmes and in employment assistance". The Age PA6;29.7.97

The reason I have spent some time spelling out Australia's changes for you is because at the last election, the successful liberal coalition Government saw elected a record number of women in the ranks. 19 liberal coalition women have come into the House of Representatives in Parliament and have voted for the systematic winding back of gains for women.

Back to my earlier points on fair representation. What Australia teaches us is that support for more women into parliament means just that and no more: That is, it is a step in the right direction for fair representation but it is no guarantee of improvement of conditions for women.
That struggle is a political one, determined in Australia's case, by party politics and programs, not merely by more women in parliament.

One of the women elected in 1996, Pauline Hanson, has led a virulent and misinformed campaign against Aboriginal Australians and Asian migrants. She has challenged Australia's multi cultural and tolerant attitude. Again I find it ironic that I support women in parliament but I totally oppose what this woman says. However, men of every persuasion have long since been elected to our parliaments, the same must be true for women.
Let me make it clear—I support the increased number of liberal women and I congratulate them. Now, every day, I argue, debate and criticise them and their policies across the Chamber.

On very few things are the women in our parliament united. Sometimes there is support below the counter, so to speak, but the public face is partly political differences, rather than unity of purpose.

While the Labor party has argued for women to have more choice, more opportunities, to participate in the work force with government funded child care and support, the Liberal Coalition has encouraged more women to leave the work force to return to the home as their principal occupation, and to provide care for children and the aged, with only modest government support. It is much more an emphasis on individuals doing for themselves than counting on partnership with government to assist them in their choices.

However, I take some support from a woman who when interviewed in 1995 about changes by the Labor government said: "Things are still tough for me and my family but they are much better for me than they were for my mother and my grandmother. I don't want to go back to their ways—to their world."

Where does all this lead? Firstly, it illustrates the importance of government for women—their advancement and the importance of electing to our Parliament, women who are committed to the improvement of conditions for women. That is why the Labor women have campaigned for and succeeded in changing our party rules about the selection of women as candidates for election.

Our rule change requires that at least 35% of safe seats must be provided for women and for men—to be achieved by 2002. I can assure you that it has been a hard fought battle and it is grudging in it's implementation.
Women will continue to be elected and pre-selected, because what each party now knows is that women are an electoral asset. The community welcomes us.

But, as a Liberal women said to me recently: "the Labor Party's successful rule change has been of great benefit to Liberal women". To which I replied: And your success at the last election has been of great benefit for Labor women!"

In Australia, it is very hard to be elected to Parliament as an Independent. Most success comes through the two major parties—Labor and the Liberal-National Coalition. Democrats have been successful in the Senate only—our upper house, elected on proportional representation.

I have talked about Australia because I know it first hand. I know we have problems and there are real challenges for our government. But we do not face challenges of the magnitude of India or many other countries. Those challenges include a population growth that "adds the population of Australia every year", as one person put it to me. And I know that many women cannot read and write, indeed may not even get schooling, that girl babies are not loved and valued as boy babies, that young girls are sold into the sex trade and that many mothers have no access to, or option for, contraception.

One thing this conference illustrates is how women can come together to support each other and to learn from each other, and it provides an opportunity for me to say, and I'm sure I speak for you all, that we are united as women around the world, to see justice for women and girls in every country.

I want to turn now to a different perspective. The role of government has never been more important, I believe, than at this time of international businesses, international finance and world wide information technology. When multi-national companies can pick up their businesses and accompanying jobs and move them to another country where labour costs are much less, how can government operate to protect employment and the wealth of the nation from the loss of those jobs and investment?
How can government cope with foreign investment if much of the financial returns are repatriated to the country of the head offices?
How can governments collect adequate taxes if more and more money and retail transactions are effected through the Internet where no taxes are paid and it is not possible to trace such transactions?

How can, governments cope with new information technology when as President Clinton said in an address to the Australian House of Reps on his recent visit:- let us not forget that over 60% of the people in the world are two days walk from the nearest telephone?

I said earlier that government, especially democratic government was the voice, the protector and the advocate of the people. Given the questions, I've just posed, it becomes clear that not only do we need representative government, we need cooperation and collaboration between governments to tackle international challenges. If we didn't have a UN, we'd have to invent one.

But, here again, the UN needs to shift and shape to present circumstances. Its international peace keeping role is a step in the right direction, but we need the same international commitment and involvement in the social and trade functions of the world's governments.
If we judge that women's perspective is vital at government level, and I do, equally we need women's participation and perspective at the International—the UN—level.

And further, we need women's presence, participation and perspective in international finance—the IMF, the World Bank; in national banking houses, in boards of multinational corporations, and in information technology.

All that may lead to a sense of overwhelming demand with little likelihood of success. However, we the world's women, have achieved great gains at the local and national level. We will proceed at the international too. All we need is time—and our daughters.
And knowledge of things like the International Court of Justice where we can appeal the case for women's representation.
Let me back up a little.

A conference such as this is of great importance in allowing the exchange of information and different ways to achieve improvements for women and greater participation in our Parliaments. I am delighted to know about India's bill to reserve 33 1/3% of places in her national parliament for women. I have no doubt that in time you will succeed. What I like about it is that it is different from which we are doing in Australia.

It is different from what Scandinavian countries have done and it is different from what the UK Labor party has done—to reserve a percentage of seats for women candidates. That process has been ruled unfair by the courts; but the pre-selections were not recontested and so Prime Minister Tony Blair has over 100 women in his 400 plus caucus. It is still only 25% but it is a significant critical mass.

It is the variety of ways that women are employing to achieve their increased representation in Parliament that fascinates me, as much as the successes. We must ensure that this information is widely known by women around the world. One way is via conferences and the like. Another is via the Internet and the World Wide Web. Not long ago, I visited Seoul and met there a woman who had just returned from establishing a femminet in Mongolia. She has also established the same in Korea and Malaysia. The Wcmen's Net world wide grows by the day. More and more parliaments and their women representatives are there for all to see. Other networks explain the different mechanisms by which this is being achieved. Hopefully, soon the Inter-Parliamentary Union's excellent publications about women and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Associations will be equally available.

Such data is invaluable and increasingly accessible. I am delighted that so many women, of so many ages, but particularly young women are as at home on the web as they are at the stove and the sink. Our challenge is to ensure that all our young women can read and write and have access to computers and the Internet. Here clearly, is a role for government. And here clearly is the importance of women in parliament—to ensure that girls, as well as boys, have that schooling. I have just finished a report, as Chair of one of our Senate Committees, into Adult and Community Education. It highlights the importance of older women having access to education and computers too.

While access to the Internet is very important, so too is local access to information—within country and between country information about women. My Labor women colleagues and I have been campaigning for all Foreign Affairs briefing material about other countries to provide data about women in those countries—as well as broad acreage, exports and imports, major trade commodities and the like. Often, I still have to specifically request information about women and often still I am told "we don't have that available—it is not known".

I am pleased to say that the Australian Post in New Delhi has very good information on the status of women in India—many of you have provided both the data and the contacts to develop and maintain it.

Further to information about women on country publications, I recommend we ask our Foreign Ministers and Shadow Foreign Ministers to raise questions about women on all their country visits and to follow up on their return for reports of those discussions.

I am no longer content to accept comments like: "we had serious discussions about trade and finance, about exports and imports, about food production and regional development, about migration levels and defence—and none of these concern women". All of it is about women—they do most of the work in the food production and most of the domestic purchasing of goods and services. They have a say, mostly, in each country's population—or they should. It's time for the word women to be part of inter-country discussions.

I also think it is time for inter-country bilateral meetings of women in Parliament and government. We need lots of smaller and regional meetings in between our major UN meetings. We need the immediacy of regular and regional meetings. In such a way, the network of women in parliaments around the world can be strengthened—and we need such meetings funded and resourced.
That is one important reason I am happy to return to New Delhi. Australia and India have much in common and much to offer each other.
We play netball, hockey and cricket—women do—and we acquit ourselves well. Australia is doing nicely at the moment.

I mention sport again because it is still a matter of fact that women's sports gets much less money and recognition than men's sport. This is grossly unfair and also poor judgement in Australia's case, because her women win more gold medals than her men! But still, it is very hard for Australian women to get adequate financial support. Media coverage is equally abysmal.

I mention this because sport is a very important contributor to the Australian culture—the very masculine mateship and competitive tough Australian. When women try for a place on the sporting field they are not only striving for equality of funding and media coverage, they are challenging and changing our very culture. Its tough. It is equally as tough in our Parliament. Changing that very masculine culture is very hard and yet very necessary. It is necessary as a matter of fairness for the women already there and it is necessary because it is a great turn off for younger women considering politics. They find it very unattractive.

We have had some successes in changing our Parliament. When I first came into the Senate, I and my Labor colleagues used non-sexist language—men and women, he and she etc. But Hansard, which is supposed to be a record of all that is said in Parliament Usually changed it to the third person masculine. It wasn't until we raised this in a question to Madam President, that we got it changed. Now, what we say is actually recorded!

Another time, very late at night, certain ghosts or gremlins went into our King's Hall, where portraits of past politicians hang, and they brought out from behind two pillars the only portraits of two women there. They were exchanged with portraits of prominently placed men—pun intended. Next day they were replaced and there was outrage. The following night, the same gremlins acted again. Subsequently, I asked another Question of Madam President and he decided to rotate the portraits, as a result of which the women officially got a public place/face. We have got women's toilets now but it wasn't the case for women in the early 80's. We still don't have a child care centre, though we have two very large pool rooms, hardly ever used. We are currently campaigning for a `family' room—one step at a time.

I also started aerobics classes with a woman colleague, and just recently I introduced Yoga classes, which I attend. Parliament is often long days and nights sitting with no chance to shop. Our parliament has a shop that sells shaving cream and razors, I organised it to have stockings and women's things.

Our Labor caucus has a women's caucus and it has had some significant successes, particularly in questioning policies as they affect women. We have also used the caucus to promote the selection of women to senior positions in the Public Service and in private enterprise.

But we must see significant increases in women to boards of major companies and financial institutions. One or two women here and there is not sufficient to effect policy or culture changes in those institutions. It is the same challenge as for our Parliaments.

In my state of South Australia, women won the right to vote and stand for Parliament in 1894, just after New Zealand. It took 89 years for me to be elected to Federal Parliament, the first Labor woman so elected. I followed three women, two from the Liberal Party and one from the Democrats. I am the first South Australian Woman to be a Minister in the Federal Parliament.
It took a long time for the first achievements, but things are moving faster novv. And my Labor party rule change, means that I can expect more Labor women from South Australia in the near future.

Our Federal Parliament passed a law in 1902 giving women the vote Australia wide. However, it effectively excluded Aboriginal women and men from the vote. It was not until after the referendum in 1967 that Aboriginal people got the vote in their own country.

After the 1983 election, the Labor government established a mobile unit as part of the Electoral Commission. Its task was to go to rural and remote Australia, to teach people, particularly Aboriginal people, about voting and their rights. It is a model other countries have borrowed from us or copied.
Our new government has ceased all funding for it.

I have been reading Marilyn Waring's book Three Masquerades. The first chapter is a brilliant description of the hardship and loneliness of women in Parliament to this point. I recommend it to you all.

Against that, I am happy to report a meeting I had with many Indian women parliamentarians, on my last visit. Hosted by Madame Heptulla, there were women from every party, united and supportive in their campaign for success with the Reservation for Women Bill.

Reading Marilyn Waring's book made me realise how all that must be done will be achieved. Her description covers the years 1970—1990 roughly the break-through years. Things are not quite the same now. Younger women coming into Parliament have us to learn from, to answer questions, to show them the ropes. They are better educated on the whole, they have grown up with a generation of young men who are much less sexist than their fathers and grandfathers. They use computers like they catch buses and trains. Its usual for so many of them.

They are not the same as us—because we have made a difference! They move forward, they do not go over the same ground. They have economics degrees, they are scientists, they are doctors and lawyers and union representatives and teachers, and nurses. They climb mountains, they sail solo around the world, they run marathons. They work in many countries and speak many languages. They control their fertility and the number of babies they have. They are healthier and they will live longer. And many of them care passionately about other women and about how other women don't have it as good as them.

I am an incurable optimist, but even so I have a real optimism for our future. Some people can try to turn the clock back—but women who have learned to read won't stop reading. As the young woman said, "I don't want to go back to how it was for my mother and my grandmother". And they have us—to urge them on, to encourage and support them, and to celebrate with them.

I have often been struck by how women in the community are so proud of those of us who succeed in achieving high and public office. It will be the same for our daughters, but they won't be breaking down the barriers for the first time. They will find us there to cheer them on.

It is when our daughters stand alongside our sons, equally represented, that our parliaments will be truly representative. Let us make it our aim for 2020. In my former profession, medicine, that is a measure of perfect sight and a great vision for our world. We should have the same vision for politics.

Fifty years ago, Indian women and men achieved their country's independence. Fifty years on we acknowledge that great success and India's passionate commitment to democracy. In another 50 years, let us look back and see the journey to equal representation of women and men in your parliament long since completed.
Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in this adjournment debate I want to raise the issue of the coming phase-out of the analog mobile telephone system in this country. The decision to close the AMPS analog network was made by the previous Labor government, and the coalition has agreed to proceed with the phase-out of analog services by the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of reasons for proceeding with the analog phase-out. The AMPS analog network is placing a technological barrier to competition, as the information superhighway rolls out across Australia and the introduction of the GSM digital technology opens up the market to three carriers. Competition in this sector has delivered lower cost calls and increased service delivery across the country.

The licences issued to the carriers include terms requiring the closure of the analog service by the year 2000. Failure to honour these licence conditions could expose the Commonwealth to action from the carriers. Telstra, Optus and Vodafone have invested substantial sums of money in mobile digital infrastructure. They have all configured their business operations on the basis that the AMPS analog system will cease in Australia by the year 2000.

The closure of the analog system has been criticised by a group called APUMP, the Association for the Protection of Users of Mobile Phones. The thrust of their criticism is that the government is ignoring the legitimate concerns of regional mobile telephone users who rely on analog services. One of the main purposes in my speaking tonight is to put to rest this rather misleading campaign being run by APUMP. They are suggesting that analog will disappear and that regional Australia will be left without mobile services. That is clearly untrue, and I will explain the reasons for my saying that.

The misinformation that is being spread by APUMP could, indeed, encourage people in regional Australia to sell or trade their analog phones before actually needing to do so. The Association for the Protection of Users of Mobile Phones are making assertions about the policy that simply are not correct. Their claim that the government is ignoring the concerns of regional mobile telephone users is ill-informed nonsense. APUMP has, in a mischievous way, chosen to ignore the key elements of the government's policy on the phase-out of analog mobile services. The phase-out is planned, and it is linked to a number of safeguards—safeguards specifically designed to reduce inconvenience to mobile users, especially customers in rural and regional Australia.

Let me put on the public record the commitment given by the government and the minister, Senator Alston, in ushering in this necessary changeover. We intend to manage the upgrading of the mobile networks, being fully aware of the particular concerns of consumers in rural and regional Australia. The controlled phase-out of analog will continue to improve the service standard and competition of mobile telecommunications in this country. We intend to encourage new mobile players into the Australian market.

Our policy management approach to the upgrade is on the basis of this principle of a controlled phased changeover. In the transition period, regional and rural consumers will not lose access to analog until the digital network alternative is put in place.

The minister has set out a clear promise to regional consumers in recent weeks. The government will retain some AMPS analog spectrum in each existing rural planned service area, until alternative technology to deliver mobile telephony of equivalent or better quality is available. The AMPS analog spectrum will stay in those rural areas where the review of mobile services show that alternative technology will not deliver the similar service and coverage. Clearly, the minister is doing everything possible to respond to the needs of regional and rural mobile service users.

In line with our election commitment, the government is consulting widely on the need to effect a smooth transition from analog technology to digital technology. Consumer groups have figured prominently in this policy and this consultation. These groups include the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, the Consumers Telecommunications Network, the Australian Consumers Association and the National Farmers Federation. I am quite concerned that the Association for the Protection of Mobile Phone Users is so out of step on this issue; their claims lack credibility and they are spreading misinformation.

The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, is to be congratulated for managing this transition period to the benefit of all mobile customers. While moving to upgrade mobile telephony, regional and rural customers, and their particular concerns, are foremost in the government's mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The couple of minutes which are left to me in the adjournment debate will not enable me to do justice to an exhilarating event which occurred, the details of which I wanted to place on the record. This performance occurred at lunchtime in your presence, Madam President, and also in that of the Governor-General and Lady Deane. I am speaking of the rendition of a musical entitled Great Scott! by combined choirs of the Kings School Preparatory School, Sydney, and the Canberra Grammar Junior School.

SPEECH.PARA: Today's musical dramatisation of Scott's tragic expedition in 1911‐12 to the South Pole was portrayed excellently by the young people who were involved, and I would like to put on the record very briefly my appreciation for their magnificent effort. This musical was the creation of David Jensen, a master at the Kings School, who composed the music; and Mr David Burke, an author from Bowral, who has been to the Antarctic a number of times with a great Antarctican, Dr Phillip Law. Almost 200 young male voices contributed to today's performance, as well as the voice of one female—that being a young lady, who came from a sister school in Canberra, singing the part of Captain Scott's wife.

Of particular note, Great Scott! was performed in the year of the 50th anniversary of Australia's national research expeditions to the Antarctica. Its performance was organised and supported by the AAP Mawson's Hut Foundation, which is currently raising money to take an expedition to Commonwealth Bay in the Antarctic Territory in December to restore the huts that were first established in 1912‐13 by Australia's greatest Antarctic explorer, Sir Douglas Mawson.
This was a great performance today. Although time does not allow me adequately to describe it, I am pleased to mention it to honourable senators on the day it happened.
