ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation: Funding

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to $9.1 million set aside by the Government in the 1997‐98 Budget for the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO): (a) what will this money be used for; and (b) will it be adequate.

(2) (a) How long will it be before the Government provides a statement as to what it intends to do at Lucas Heights; and (b) will the Government be building a new reactor or refurbishing the old reactor.

(3) (a) What measures does the Government use in assessing the contribution of Australian nuclear science to the rest of the world; and (b) how will Australia's contribution to nuclear science be measured in comparison to the science conducted by others in the region, for example, Indonesia.

(4) Can the Government provide any estimated cost for a new reactor, given that John Stocker estimates $150‐300 million, Coopers and Lybrand estimate $200 million and ANSTO suggests between $230 and $478 million.
(5) Will the cost of a new reactor include an assessment of the environmental and health costs.
(6) If the Government is going to allow on‐site reprocessing at Lucas Heights, will new legislation be enacted to allow the Parliament to participate.
(7) (a) Does ANSTO produce technetium 99M; (b) is there a worldwide glut of technetium 99M; and (c) what is the economic justification for producing the isotope technetium 99M.
(8) What guarantees will be provided to the Australian taxpayers that a new reactor would not exceed the published costs.
(9) In assessing the costs and desirability of a new reactor, will the Government factor in the disposal of nuclear waste.
(10) What would be the cost of a nuclear waste reprocessing plant.
(11) What would be the cost of a synroc plant.
(12) What would be the costs of decommissioning the Lucas Heights reactor.
(13) (a) Will the Government build a new reactor if there is no economic justification; and (b) if there is a public interest/good component, how will the Government assess this.
(14) Are other reactors around the world cost effective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question to the former Minister for Science and Technology:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The money was set aside to provide interim relief to ANSTO's spent fuel storage facilities. (b) The Government has now decided to send all the spent fuel rods, which are of US and UK origin, overseas. The total cost of this is expected to be in the order of $88 million. Exact costings are dependent upon the completion of contractual arrangements with the US and UK. Additional money has been provided to fund the shipments.

(2) (a) and (b) The Government announced on 3 September 1997 that it intended to construct a replacement research reactor at Lucas Heights. It also announced that it would not build a spent fuel processing plant at Lucas Heights or anywhere else in Australia.

(3) (a) and (b) Most nuclear science in Australia is conducted either by ANSTO or using ANSTO facilities. Under the Triennium Funding Arrangements, ANSTO's performance is monitored against a set of performance indicators agreed by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, the Minister for Finance and ANSTO. These indicators embrace such issues as:
‐ the number of research and service contracts successfully completed for industry and government
‐ adoption by users of practices, instruments and processes developed by ANSTO
‐ external earnings for research and services
‐ level and quality of scientific and technical publications
‐ collaboration with industry and other research organisations
‐ provision of advice to government
‐ maintenance and extension of international networks and contribution to policy development in international bodies
‐ degree of usage of ANSTO's facilities by external users, and
‐ collaboration with the university sector.
Outcomes against these indicators are summarised in ANSTO's Annual Report.

Australia's publication rate in international nuclear science and technology journals is comparable to that of the most productive countries in the nuclear science and technology field. These countries are operating either nuclear power or research reactors.
The Government is satisfied with ANSTO's performance and that it is a world class research and development organisation. The response to part (21) of Question No 633 is also relevant.

(4) The total project is expected to cost in the vicinity of $300 million, including reactor island, all associated infrastructure and buildings. The final figure is dependent on the outcome of a competitive tendering process.
(5) The cost given in the answer to question (4) includes an allowance for environmental assessment under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.
(6) See response to question (2).

(7) (a) Yes. (b) No. The markets in which ANSTO is a participant are not exhibiting signs of a glut. (c) The use of technetium‐99m, and of other radiopharmaceuticals, provides benefits to both the health system and to patients. The economic justification is in terms of relative efficacy which results in cost benefits to the health system through, for instance, shorter patient time in hospital because nuclear medicine procedures replace investigative surgery. From the perspective of the patient, there are real, but intangible, benefits in terms of comfort and convenience. Depending on the patient's circumstances, there may also be cost savings.
(8) See response to question (4). The estimate of cost includes a contingency factor, and the project will be subject to scrutiny by the Public Works Committee.
(9) In making its decision to construct a replacement research reactor at Lucas Heights, the Government also took into account the issue of the disposal of nuclear waste.
(10) The Government has announced that it would not build a spent fuel processing plant at Lucas Heights.
(11) See response to question (10).

(12) The Government has not made a decision on the method of decommissioning the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights and has not, therefore, assessed the costs. This decision will be taken closer to 2005, when HIFAR is to be closed down.

(13) (a) and (b) The replacement reactor announced on 3 September will be a multi‐purpose reactor. It will continue to produce direct economic benefits in such areas as the health system and through support for the agricultural, manufacturing, mining and environmental management industries. These benefits can, to some degree, be quantified. It is conservatively estimated, for example, that the economic benefits from a research reactor amount to at least $100 million per annum for the minerals sector alone.

In addition, there is a national interest/public good component in the benefits to be derived from the reactor. This appears in such areas as the benefits of research, the training of scientists, technical support for the Government's nuclear policies, and the benefits to patients (as mentioned in the response to question (7)). These benefits are real, but cannot be easily quantified. The Government has taken its decision after considering both classes of benefits.

(14) The Research Reactor Review noted that "If HIFAR or the replacement reactor were required to balance income against expenditure solely through commercial activities, it would not be viable. This is in line with overseas experience, as no research reactors are financed solely on such a basis." This remains the case.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Education: Research and Innovation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role does education, research and innovation play in Australia's economy.
(2) Does innovation lead to economic growth.
(3) Does innovation result in job creation for the future.
(4) Does the Government intend to include science and technology in economic planning.
(5) What contribution does the application of Australian innovation make to the Australian economy.
(6) Is the contribution of Australian innovation relevant to economic growth and job creation.
(7) Why was there no reference to science and technology in the 1997‐98 Budget statement.
(8) Is there a link between innovation and economic performance: if so, what role does this link have in the Government's economic planning.
(9) Is innovation a relevant factor in determining the cost of production and the value of a product.
(10) What role does innovation play in determining competitiveness and is this relevant to the Australian economy: if so, how.
(11) Has the Government's commitment to support innovation and research been cut in real terms in the 1997‐98 Budget compared to the 1996‐97 Budget.
(12) Does short‐term economic expediency threaten Australia's research and innovation future.
(13) Will the Government reconsider the 150 per cent tax concession for private sector research and development: if so, when.
(14) Is the Factor (f) Scheme beneficial to the Australian economy: if so, what reasons does the Government have for not extending similar schemes to other areas of the Australian industry.
(15) Does Australia neglect its research and innovation base at our national peril.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Education, research and innovation allow the development, transmission and application of new knowledge in the service of economic growth and employment. They help economic players to adapt and be internationally competitive in the changing world economy. In particular, scientific research provides a body of knowledge that is a foundation and source for innovative ideas, and builds skills and capabilities that also form a resource for technological innovation.

There is a strong link between innovation and economic performance. Innovation involves the creation of new and improved products, services and processes which increase efficiency and market opportunities and thereby help a firm or industry to become more competitive. On a micro level, innovation is a factor in determining the cost of production and the value of products; on a macro level, through improved economic performance, innovation leads to economic growth. Like any other economy, the Australian economy could benefit from more innovative activity.

Data gathered from the Australian manufacturing sector illustrates the competitive advantages of innovation, and its significant role. The Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of innovation in the manufacturing sector in 1993‐94 showed that innovative firms employ 70 per cent of employees in the sector, and account for 80 per cent of manufacturing sales and 85 per cent of manufactured exports. Information on innovation in other sectors of the economy is sparse, but based on the survey of the manufacturing sector the overall contribution of innovation to the economy is considerable.

The relationship between innovation and job creation is complex and indirect. However insofar as innovation stimulates economic growth it will also result in job creation. The fact that innovative firms employ a large proportion of workers in the manufacturing sector indicates that Australian innovation contributes to job creation.

Government support for scientific research and innovation in Australia is substantial, amounting to an estimated $3551 million in 1997‐98. Government programs and policies are aimed at generally lifting the quality and quantity of research and development in Australia, and its application by industry, rather than being part of a specific economic or industrial plan for the nation. For example, the Government especially recognises the need for strong communication links between publicly‐funded research bodies and the business community. These links are facilitated by initiatives such as the $145 million Cooperative Research Centre program.

The Factor (f) Scheme is another beneficial program. The Scheme was created to counteract the tendency of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to artificially lower prices and so discourage pharmaceutical companies from expanding their activities, in particular their investment in R&D. The Scheme has been successful in boosting R&D, output and exports, and in generating jobs. Its effectiveness should be further enhanced by the changes accompanying its transition to the Pharmaceuticals Industry Investment Program. However, it should be noted that the Scheme is tailored to circumstances peculiar to the pharmaceutical industry and the incentive mechanisms it relies on may not be applicable in other areas of industry.

The full range of Government science and technology programs are brought together in the Science and Technology Budget Statement, which is tabled each year in the week that the Budget is brought down. Discussion of many aspects of the Government's science and technology programs can also be found in the Budget Statements. Budget Statement Number 3, for example, contains a section on the role of technological change in shaping the economy. Budget Statement Number 4 contains a section on General Research which includes coverage of scientific research. Other programs which support research are mentioned in relation to functional areas—for example health research is included in the section dealing with Health outlays.

The Science and Technology Budget Statement 1997‐98 shows that direct Commonwealth support for major science and innovation programs increased 0.8%, in real terms, between 1996‐97 and 1997‐98. When including indirect support through the industrial R&D tax concession, where there was a change in the rate which came fully into effect during 1997‐98, this gives a real decrease of 1.3% overall.

Neglect of Australia's research and innovation base would be detrimental. For this reason the Government has a wide range of programs in place which ensure that the base is maintained and enhanced. Comparisons with OECD countries show that as a proportion of GDP Australia is fifth overall in terms of R&D expenditure in universities and public sector agencies. In this situation it is hard to sustain any charge of short term economic expediency on the part of the Government. However, OECD comparisons do show that Australia's business sector has relatively low expenditure on R&D, despite improvements in recent years. Arguably, the business sector overall may tend to take a short term view and give inadequate recognition to the long term benefits of innovation. For this and other reasons, the Government aims to encourage the business sector to innovate through a number of programs, notably the R&D tax concession.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Privacy Legislation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government made the services of the Federal Privacy Commissioner available to the private sector to assist in the development of voluntary codes of practice.
(2) How many times, or on how many occasions, has the Federal Privacy Commissioner provided services to the private sector to assist in the development of voluntary codes of practice.
(3) Does the Federal Government have assurances from the States and Territories that they will not introduce privacy legislation that will regulate privacy in the private sector.
(4) Which States and Territories have provided such assurances.
(5) Which States and Territories have not provided those assurances.
(6) What compliance costs would have been increased by the introduction of a privacy regime for the private sector?
(7) What data or research did the Government have to confirm its decision that compliance costs would have been increased by introducing a privacy regime for the private sector.

(8) (a) Did the Government undertake any analysis that examined, or rely on any data, that showed the costs to Australian business in lost trade opportunities as a result of there being no privacy regime applying to the private sector; and (b) if there was no data or analysis to support the Government's decision not to extend the privacy regime to the private sector, what reasons did the Government have for its decision not to extend the privacy regime to the private sector.
(9) What are the projected compliance costs to Australian business if there is a patchwork of privacy regimes across the States and Territories.

(10) (a) Do departmental information technology (IT) contracts contain clauses relating to privacy; (b) what are those clauses; (c) are these clauses included in all IT contracts; if not, why not (d) are there any other clauses that relate to privacy that are included in any departmental IT contracts; if so, what are they; and (e) who decides which privacy clauses go into an IT contract; and from whom do they get advice.
(11) (a) What policy or guidelines does the department follow in preparing its IT contracts; and (b) are there or have there ever been any deviations from these guidelines in the past 7 years.
(12) Is any guidance or training provided to contractors about the privacy obligations set out in the IT contracts.
(13) Does the department allow subcontracting or include subcontracting provisions in any of its IT contracts; if so, what are these provisions.
(14) Do the terms relating to privacy in the principal contract bind the subcontractor.
(15) Is any guidance or training provided to subcontractors about the privacy obligations set out in the IT contracts.

(16) Are any contractors and subcontractors of IT located on departmental premises or do any have access to departmental databases which contain personal information; if so, what measures are taken to ensure those persons do not access personal information beyond the scope of their contract or subcontract.
(17) Have contractors and subcontractors breached information privacy principles in the past 7 years; if so, when and how.
(18) (a) Does the department have electronic mail; if so, what policy or guidelines apply to ensure personal information is not dealt with contrary to the information privacy principles.
(19) Is there any information that the department would never outsource.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney‐General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. At the Premier's Conference on 21 March 1997, the Prime Minister announced that the services of the Privacy Commissioner would be available to assist business in the development of voluntary codes of conduct and to meet privacy standards.

Assisting the private sector on matters concerning the handling of personal information is a statutory function of the Privacy Commissioner. Under section 27(n) of the Privacy Act 1988 the Privacy Commissioner is to encourage corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information that are consistent with the Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data issued in 1980 by the Organisation for Economic Co‐operation and Development (the OECD Privacy Guidelines).

(2) I am advised that the Privacy Commissioner receives numerous requests from the private sector for advice and assistance. In 1995/96, for instance, more than 800 telephone requests were received from private sector organisations other than credit providers. The Privacy Commissioner's office has frequently also given written advice on the application of privacy principles and a range of materials has been developed. There have been at least 18 occasions on which the Commissioner has become involved in substantive work on codes of practice that were being either reviewed or created by an individual company or an industry body. In most cases, these codes have covered broad ethical and service delivery issues and, while making a reference to privacy, they did not aim to address all aspects of the OECD Privacy Guidelines.

I am advised that since taking up duties in February 1997, and particularly since the Government's offer in March that the Privacy Commissioner would be available to assist business in the development of voluntary codes of conduct, the current Privacy Commissioner has met with companies and industry representatives on many occasions to discuss the development of appropriate practices and policies within the private sector. Since March discussions with the private sector have been focussed on seeking cooperation in the development of a consistent national framework.

On 18 August 1997 the Privacy Commissioner released a consultation paper, Information Privacy in Australia: A National Scheme for Fair Information Practices in the Private Sector, which put forward a proposal for a self‐regulatory information privacy scheme and invited public debate on the issues raised and feedback by 15 September 1997. The Privacy Commissioner is also holding a series of forums around Australia for the full range of stakeholders to discuss the issues and to gauge the level of interest in, and commitment to, the proposed national scheme.

(3) Discussions between the Commonwealth and the various States and Territories about extending privacy protection to the private sector are ongoing. Most recently discussions have occurred within the context of discussing a wide range of measures to advance the online economy. At the Online Council meeting on 12 September 1997 which was attended by Ministers from all levels of Australian governments, the Online Council recognised the desirability of a national approach to privacy and agreed, as a priority, to the establishment of an Online Council working party, working in conjunction with the Federal Privacy Commissioner, to develop the underlying principles of a data protection regime for the online economy.

More generally, the aim of the discussions between the Commonwealth and the various States and Territories is to reach an agreed national approach. Accordingly, it would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth to outline the respective positions of the States and Territories at this time.
(4) See answer to Question (3).
(5) See answer to Question (3).
(6) The compliance costs of a privacy regime for the private sector would depend on the particular elements of the regime and the methods by which it was put into place.
In general, there would be costs associated with:
. assessing existing record‐keeping practices and procedures against the particular information privacy standards required by the regime;
. making any necessary changes to those practices and procedures to ensure that they complied with the requisite standards;
. educating management and employees on the information privacy standards and what these would mean in terms of everyday work; and
. maintaining systems to comply with the standards.

(7) The Government's decision not to legislate on private sector privacy followed extensive consultation based on the discussion paper, Privacy Protection in the Private Sector, released in September last year by the Attorney‐General's Department (the Department). That discussion paper outlined a possible approach to privacy protection in the private sector. Its purpose was to enable business and the community generally to provide concrete comments.

The Department received more than 100 submissions in response to its discussion paper, many of which provided detailed comments. As well as formal submissions, a number of organisations took the opportunity to meet with the Attorney‐General's advisers and relevant officers of the Department to discuss areas of specific concern.

There was particular concern expressed about how a legislative regime would impact upon small and medium enterprises. Some argued strongly that there was no clear need for legislation in order to ensure privacy protection and that privacy concerns could be adequately addressed by business on a voluntary basis.

The Small Business Summit in June last year recognised the cost and frustration from unnecessary or overly complex regulation which falls on small business. A specially commissioned survey, `Working Overtime' has found that, on average, small businesses spend 4 hours a week on `compliance matters'. Over the course of a year this costs the average small business $7000.

The Government acknowledges that complying with current regulatory requirements already imposes a significant burden on Australian businesses and is committed to reducing the regulatory burden on all business. In opting for an approach to encourage the adoption of voluntary codes of conduct to enhance privacy protection in the private sector, the Government aimed to identify the right balance between ensuring adequate privacy protection and advancing the competitive interests of Australian business.

(8) (a) The Government has decided to support a voluntary approach to ensuring privacy protection in the private sector involving the development of voluntary codes of practice. The Privacy Commissioner has commenced consultations with the private sector on her proposal for a national self‐regulatory scheme for information privacy protection. Therefore, the Government does not agree that there will be no privacy regime applying to the private sector.

There were concerns expressed in some of the submissions made in response to the Department's September 1996 discussion paper about the potential impact on Australia of the European Union Directive on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data and on the Free Movement of Such Data (the EU Directive).

The Government has followed closely the development of the EU Directive. The Government has considered the question of the possible impact of the Directive on Australian trade opportunities with EU countries and will continue to monitor this issue closely. However, the interpretation of the EU Directive is still under consideration by the EU. In addition, the EU Directive contains a number of exceptions to these restrictions.

(b) See answer to Question (7). The decision not to implement a legislative privacy regime for the private sector was preceded by an analysis of the submissions received in response to the Department's discussion paper, Privacy Protection in the Private Sector, and other consultations by Government with industry and other relevantly interested parties.

(9) Business costs from any deviation from a national approach to protection of privacy in the private sector would only be able to be assessed when the nature of the differences was known. As indicated in answer to a previous question, ongoing discussions between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories about extending privacy protection to the private sector are aimed at reaching an agreed national approach.
(10) (a) I am advised that clauses dealing with Disclosure of Information are included in all the Department's IT contracts.
(b) The relevant clauses and contract annexure are outlined below:
DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION
Section 10

(1) The Consultant shall not, without the prior written approval of the Commonwealth, disclose to any person other than the Commonwealth, any Commonwealth Material or Contract Material. In giving written approval the Commonwealth may impose such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.

(2) The Commonwealth may at any time require the Consultant to give and to arrange for its employees and sub‐contractors engaged in the performance of the Consultancy Services to give written undertakings, in a form prescribed by the Commonwealth, relating to the non‐disclosure of confidential information. The Consultant shall promptly arrange for all such undertakings to be given.
PROTECTION OF PERSONAL INFORMATION CLAUSES—ANNEXURE A
Interpretation

"personal information" means information or an opinion (including information or an opinion forming part of a database), whether true or not, and whether recorded in a material form or not, about a natural person whose identity is apparent, or can reasonably be ascertained, from the information or opinion.
1. Security

The Contractor shall take all reasonable measures to ensure that personal information held in connection with this Agreement is protected against loss, and against unauthorised use, modification, disclosure or other misuse, and that only authorised personnel have access to the personal information.
The Contractor shall not vary the security procedures set out in the Agreement without the prior written approval of the agency.
2. Protection of Personal Information
The Contractor agrees, in respect of personal information held in connection with this Agreement:

(i) To use personal information only for the purposes of fulfilling its obligations under this Agreement. The Contractor shall immediately notify the agency where it becomes aware that a disclosure of personal information may be required by law.

(ii) not to disclose personal information without the written authority of the agency except for the purpose of fulfilling its obligations under this Agreement. The Contractor shall immediately notify the agency where it becomes aware that a disclosure of personal information may be required by law;
(iii) not to transfer personal information outside Australia, or allow parties outside Australia to have access to it, without the prior approval of the agency;

(iv) to ensure that an employee of the Contractor or of any sub‐contractor requiring access to any personal information makes an undertaking in writing not to access, use, disclose or retain personal information except in performing their duties of employment and is informed that failure to comply with this undertaking may be a criminal offence and may also lead the Contractor to take disciplinary action against the employee; and
(v) to immediately notify the agency where the Contractor becomes aware of a breach of clauses [1 and 2 (i)‐(iv)] by itself or any sub contractor.

(vi) to co‐operate with any reasonable requests or directions of [the agency's delegate] arising directly from, or in connection with the exercises of the functions of the Privacy Commissioner under the Privacy Act 1988 or otherwise including but not limited to the issuing of any guideline concerning the handling of personal information.
3. Liability

(i) The Contractor agrees to indemnify the Commonwealth in respect of any liability, loss or expense incurred arising out of or in connection with a breach of the obligations of the Contractor under clauses [1 and 2] of this Annexure or for a breach of an obligation of confidence whether arising under the Privacy Act 1988 or otherwise.

(ii) For the purposes of 3(i) "liability" includes any liability assumed by the agency on behalf of the Commonwealth to pay a person a reasonable amount as compensation for loss or damage suffered by that person as a result of any breach of clauses [1 and 2] by the Contractor for which the Commonwealth would have been liable under the Privacy Act 1988 if such a breach had been that of the agency.
4. Acknowledgment of the Effect of the Crimes Act 1914
The Contractor acknowledges in respect of personal information held in connection with this Agreement that:

(i) any unauthorised and intentional access, destruction, alteration, addition or impediment to access or usefulness of personal information stored in any computer in the course of performing, a contract with the Commonwealth is an offence under Part VIA of the Crimes Act 1914 for which there are a range of penalties, including a maximum of ten years imprisonment; and

(ii) the publication or communication of any fact or document by a person which has come to their knowledge or into their possession or custody by virtue of the performance of this Agreement (other than to a person to whom the Contractor is authorised to publish or disclose the fact or document) may be an offence under section 70 of the Crimes Act 1914, the penalty for which there is a maximum of two years imprisonment.
5. Handling of Complaints
A complaint alleging an interference with the privacy of an individual shall be handled by the agency in accordance with the following procedures:

(i) where the agency receives a complaint alleging an interference with the privacy of an individual by the Contractor, it shall immediately notify the Contractor of only those details of the complaint necessary to minimise any breach or prevent further breaches of the above clauses;

(ii) where the Contractor receives a complaint alleging an interference with the privacy of an individual by the Contractor, it shall immediately notify the agency of the nature of the complaint with that person's consent;

(iii) after the agency has given or been given notice in accordance with (i) or (ii), it shall keep the Contractor informed of all progress with the complaint as it relates to the actions of the Contractor in connection with the allegation of an interference with the privacy of an individual; and

(iv) the agency shall give the Contractor 14 days written notice of an intention to assume a liability, loss or expense in accordance with clause [3] including in that notice an explanation of how that liability loss or expense was assessed and the Contractor's proposed share or that liability.
6. Survival
Clauses [1 to 6] shall continue to have effect after the termination or expiration of the Agreement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 8 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the estimated cost of $300 million for the building of a new nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights cover the following associated costs, including: (a) decommissioning the existing High Flux Australian Reactor (HIFAR) at Lucas Heights; (b) complete spent fuel management, including export overseas, reprocessing, reimporting and storage and/or final disposal; (c) the handling and off site disposal of other waste which is currently kept at Lucas Heights; and (d) the eventual decommissioning of the proposed new reactor, and the subsequent costs of dealing with the spent fuel and other wastes associated with the new reactor if not, what are the estimated costs of the above (a) to (d).
(2) Will the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation be required to place monies in a bond to ensure the costs associated with (1)(d) are covered at the appropriate time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question to the former Minister for Science and Technology:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The associated costs listed in (a) to (d) are not included in the estimated costs of $300 million. This amount is the estimated cost of the replacement reactor and all associated infrastructure and buildings.
(a) The Government has not made a decision on the method of decommissioning for the Lucas Heights reactor. This decision will be taken closer to 2005.

(b) The Government has set aside $88 million for the return of 689 spent fuel rods to the US, the shipment of around 1300 spent fuel rods to the UK for reprocessing, and the return of the resulting concreted waste to Australia.

(c) Management costs for other radioactive waste currently at Lucas Heights are in the order of $1 million per annum and are met from ANSTO's budget. It should be noted that most of this waste does not arise from the operation of the reactor.

(d) It is not realistic to make estimates of these costs at this stage. The replacement reactor has not yet been designed or constructed, it will not be taken out of operation until about 50 years from now, and it will be, perhaps, 80 years from now when decisions are taken on the final decommissioning arrangements.

(2) No. The decisions relating to the matters specified in question (1(d) are primarily decisions for the Government. Funds required for the costs concerned will be provided by the Government at the appropriate time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor: Replacement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 8 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the 1993 Research Reactor Review conclude that: `if, at some later stage, a new reactor is envisaged, it should be assessed by a new panel possibly operating under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974'.
(2) Why has a panel not been established to assess any proposal for a new reactor.

(3) Does the Minister agree that requiring an environmental impact statement to be conducted for the proposal for a new reactor at Lucas Heights is not a replacement for the panel process recommended by the Research Reactor Review.
(4) Have local resident groups, including the Mayor of Sutherland, requested a full inquiry into both the need for, and siting of, a new reactor.

(5) (a) What other sites were investigated; (b) why were they ruled out; (c) against what criteria were they judged; and (d) if any research was conducted into alternative sites, can a copy of that research be provided.
(6) What form of public review will the Government conduct for a new reactor.
(7) Will any such review examine the need or otherwise for a new reactor.
(8) Has an investigation of the environmental and economic feasibility of importing medical radioisotopes been carried out; if so, can a copy of this research be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question to the former Minister for Science and Technology:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This statement was included in the text of the report, but was not a conclusion of the Research Reactor Review (RRR). The report of the Research Reactor Review (RRR) provides a useful background for Government decisions on the question of an on‐going research reactor capability in Australia, but its recommendations and conditions are not pre‐requisites for those decisions.

(2) The RRR, which was established by the previous Government and reported to it, was a public inquiry into the need for a replacement research reactor. Its report set out a number of conditions which it considered, if satisfied, would make it appropriate for a positive decision to be made on a replacement reactor after about five years. As outlined in the responses to Questions on Notice Nos 561 and 633, the conditions of the RRR have been generally satisfied. In the circumstances, it is apparent that nothing useful could be achieved by another public inquiry.

(3) No. The RRR made an observation about a panel process, not a recommendation. An assessment of the proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 is the next appropriate step. The assessment process will be by way of an environmental impact statement, and will provide the opportunity for members of the public to raise any issues that might be of concern to them in relation to the proposal.

(4) The Mayor of Sutherland initially requested another public inquiry. However, his subsequent Mayoral Minute, which was supported by the Sutherland Shire Council at its meeting on 8 September 1997, "acknowledged the Federal Government for making the hard decision to replace the ageing reactor at Lucas Heights with the most advanced technology available and not to create a reprocessing facility, and supported and recognised the Federal Government for calling for a full and open EIS into the replacement reactor."
(5) (a) The suitability of a number of regions for a research reactor was considered.
(b) The application of the criteria at 5(c), below, to these regions indicated their relative unattractiveness, compared with the known and proven site at Lucas Heights.

(In addition, at sites other than Lucas Heights, most or all of the facilities and infrastructure which support the present reactor, or depend on it, including the radiopharmaceutical production facilities, would have to be duplicated. The estimated total cost at those sites would be more than double the estimated cost of constructing a replacement reactor at Lucas Heights. Moreover, even if the replacement reactor were sited elsewhere, the Lucas Heights site must continue to operate for the production of radiopharmaceuticals from isotopes produced in the National Medical Cyclotron in Sydney, and for the care and maintenance of the HIFAR reactor, pending its final decommissioning. Operations at two sites would add significantly to costs.

(c) The selection of a site requires consideration of the applicable site selection criteria together with the requirements of the reactor users. These criteria have been developed jointly by ANSTO and the Nuclear Safety Bureau, using international guidelines, and cover such aspects as:

. Health and safety: low seismicity and stable geology; low cyclonic activity and low flood potential; favourable airborne dispersion characteristics and low potential for waterborne pathways; not affected by other hazardous or incompatible land use; feasible emergency response capability from local emergency services;
. Environmental protection: not in unique ecological or conservation areas; without potential for a reactor to have any significant adverse impact on the physical or cultural environment;
. Availability of resources: adequate and reliable power and water supplies; proximity to reliable service providers and contractors;

. Accessibility: within reasonable road travel of a major, preferably international, airport to facilitate shipment of radiopharmaceuticals; same day travel from major centres of research; proximity for staff to residential and research centres; and
. Cost factors: cost of site‐related construction, infrastructure and land acquisition; operating costs.
(d) Technical evaluations of siting characteristics were not undertaken.

(6) As noted in part (3) above, the replacement research reactor proposal will undergo an environmental assessment in accordance with the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, and that process will provide the opportunity for members of the public to raise issues that might be of concern to them.
(7) The need for a replacement reactor will be outlined in the environmental impact study. The question of alternatives to a reactor will also be discussed.

(8) The feasibility of importing medical radioisotopes was examined in the RRR in 1993. The report of that review is publicly available. The evidence of the RRR and the Government's experience over time with the importation of radiopharmaceuticals has led to the conclusion that it would not be practicable or desirable to rely on imports.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hazardous Waste

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 24 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the export of computer scrap from Australia to Hong Kong in September 1997, monitored by Greenpeace:
(1) Is it correct that a company trading as Hi Technology Metal Recyclers exported three containers of computer scrap from Sydney to Hong Kong on the freighter Zim Sydney in September 1997.

(2) (a) What hazardous materials are found in computer scrap; (b) if computer scrap is exported, is it hazardous waste that requires a permit or any other approval under Australian law; if so: (i) was a permit or other approval obtained for this shipment, (ii) when was the application made, (iii) to whom was it made, and (iv) how was it assessed; if not, (i) what criteria are applied to determine whether a particular shipment is hazardous, (ii) how was this shipment assessed, (iii) when was it assessed, and (iv) by whom was it assessed.
(3) If a shipment is illegal, what actions can the Government take to remedy the situation.
(4) Was this particular shipment illegal; if so (a) what action has the Government taken to have the material returned to Australia; and (b) what action is being taken against the exporter.
(5) When will the Government ratify the Basel Convention in Australian law and ban the export of hazardous waste to non‐Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This matter is under investigation by the Australian Federal Police and it would be inappropriate to comment on the alleged identities either of the shipper or the company involved.

(2) (a) A number of hazardous materials can be found in computer scrap material: including cathode ray tubes, nickel-cadmium batteries, mercury switches; contaminants can include cadmium, mercury, lead and polychlorinated biphenyls.

(b) Computer scrap containing components such as accumulators and batteries, mercury switches, glass from cathode-ray tubes and other activated glass and PCB capacitors, or contaminated with constituents such as cadmium, mercury, lead or PCBs to an extent that they possess hazardous characteristics, is considered to be hazardous waste under the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 and requires a permit. Computer scrap not containing these components or contaminants would not require a permit under the Australian Act. Whether a particular shipment is hazardous therefore depends on the content of that shipment.
In response to the other parts of the question, it would not be appropriate for me to comment given the incident is under investigation
I note, however, that for a material to be considered hazardous waste it must meet the definition of hazardous waste as set out in the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989.

Additional specific guidance is available through the operations of the Australian Hazardous Waste Technical Group established by Section 58E of the Act. The technical group takes account of the work of the Basel Convention Technical Working Group.
(3) It is an offence to export hazardous waste out of, or import it into Australia without a permit.

Under the Act, I can make an order in respect of the waste, ordering an exporter to reimport the waste in the case of an illegal export, or order an importer to export the waste in the case of an illegal import. I can also order a person to take such steps as I think proper to remedy or mitigate the damage caused by an illegal import or export.
Penalties under the Act can range up to $A1 million at present for a body corporate or 5 years imprisonment for individuals.
(4) Given that the matter is under investigation, it would not be appropriate for me to comment on the legality of the shipment.

(5) The Australian Government has already ratified the Basel Convention, and has ensured that all obligations under the Basel Convention are fully met through amendments to the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 which came into force in December 1996.
As a separate matter, Australia will make a decision, after appropriate consultation, on whether or not to ratify the ban amendment when the technical aspects of the Basel lists are finalised.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Budget 1997-98

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the 1997‐98 Budget documentation What's New, What's Different, which stated that of the children who qualified for the Child Disability Allowance in 1993, close to 21 per cent had no handicap and did not require personal help or supervision in performing self‐care, mobility or verbal communication:
(1) On which Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) publication or publications did the Minister base this statement.

(2) Is the Minister aware that, in a letter dated 3 July 1997 to the Geelong Community Legal Service, a senior member of the ABS stated that the figure used in this statement is not supported by data from the 1993 Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers.
(3) (a) Is it possible that data from a number of sources have been combined to produce this result; and (b) how can we be assured of its accuracy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The document What's New, What's Different is primarily an internal departmental publication used to inform staff of Budget measures which affect the Social Security portfolio. The statistic quoted was derived from the Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers 1993 and has been present in departmental documents for some years.

However, following a request from the Geelong Community Legal Centre for clarification of the source and validity of the ABS data cited in What's New, What's Different, the ABS advised that the data had not been correctly interpreted. The figures provided to the Department did not refer to the population of CDA children but the population of children (under 16 years) in families receiving CDA. As a result the ABS advises that it is not possible to draw any conclusions (either positive or negative) from this data about the conditions or level of impairment of children attracting CDA.

While the data from the ABS Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers cannot be interpreted as indicating that 21 per cent of children on CDA have no handicap, the Department has other data which suggest that a figure in excess of 20 per cent is realistic. Other data include information from the feasibility study of the new assessment tool conducted by Coopers and Lybrand in 1995 and the field testing of the new assessment tool conducted by Ernst and Young in 1996‐97.
(2) Yes.
(3) As indicated above, the data quoted from the ABS Survey were misinterpreted by the Department.
I am happy to offer Senator Allison a briefing from my Department about the new CDA assessment tool.
